description: v3-12 'Coverage Expansion': 454 existing + 54 new models from 4 sector deep dives (Accommodation/Food, Transportation, Construction, Admin/Support). Covers 50M+ additional workers (30% of US employment). VCR v2 fundamental scoring with independent capture/velocity analysis. All 508 models ranked on Transformation, Opportunity, and VC ROI.

SN.name: Structural Necessity
SN.description: Must this business exist given structural forces?

FA.name: Force Alignment
FA.description: How many F1-F6 forces drive it, weighted by velocity?

EC.name: External Context
EC.description: How much does international context materially change viability vs. US-only assessment?

categories.STRUCTURAL_WINNER: SN >= 8.0 AND FA >= 8.0 — must-exist business with multi-force convergence
categories.FORCE_RIDER: FA >= 7.0 — rides 3+ converging macro forces (and not STRUCTURAL_WINNER)
categories.TIMING_ARBITRAGE: TG >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — narrow entry window
categories.CAPITAL_MOAT: CE >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — cash-flow positive within 6 months
categories.FEAR_ECONOMY: Arises from fear friction: macro_source contains 'fear' or sector fear_friction_gap > 3
categories.EMERGING_CATEGORY: Doesn't map to existing NAICS or macro_source contains 'emerging'
categories.CONDITIONAL: Composite >= 60 but no other category matched (fallback)

notes: Models can have MULTIPLE categories assigned as a list
primary_category is the first matched in priority order
GEOGRAPHIC_PLAY removed — replaced by EC axis, no equivalent category
Batch normalization applied: v3-2_cycle (SN -1.5, FA -1.5, TG -2.5), new_macro_45 (SN -0.5, FA -0.3, TG -0.5)

MO.name: Market Openness
MO.description: How open is this market to new entrants? Measures current concentration, entry barriers, and trend direction.

scale.1-2: Monopoly/duopoly (>80% top-2 share), regulatory capture, structural barriers
scale.3-4: Oligopoly (3-5 players dominate), high capital/regulatory barriers
scale.5-6: Concentrated but with viable entry paths, moderate barriers
scale.7-8: Fragmented market, many players, low structural barriers

MA.name: Moat Architecture
MA.description: How fragile are incumbent moats? Higher = more fragile = better for entrants.

scale.1-2: Network effects + data moat + regulatory capture (nearly unbreakable)
scale.3-4: Strong data or network effects with some cracks
scale.5-6: Moderate moats (brand, scale) that technology could erode
scale.7-8: Weak moats primarily from switching costs or legacy relationships
scale.9-10: No meaningful moats, or moats about to be disrupted by technology shift

VD.name: Value Chain Depth
VD.description: How many independent defensible positions exist in the value chain? More layers = more ways to enter and differentiate.

scale.7-8: Multiple entry points at different stack levels, each independently viable
scale.9-10: Deep multi-layer stack where entrants can own unique positions

DV.name: Disruption Vectors
DV.description: How many plausible mechanisms exist that create openings for new entrants? Includes technology shifts, regulatory changes, incumbent weaknesses.

scale.1-2: No credible disruption path; incumbents have locked in
scale.3-4: Theoretical disruption but requires massive capital or rare conditions
scale.5-6: 1-2 plausible disruption paths actively in play
scale.7-8: Multiple disruption vectors simultaneously opening the market
scale.9-10: Incumbent position actively eroding from multiple simultaneous vectors

categories.WIDE_OPEN: OPP >= 75 — nascent/highly fragmented, no meaningful incumbents, multiple entry paths
categories.ACCESSIBLE: OPP >= 60 — fragmented with breakable moats, viable entry strategies exist
categories.CONTESTED: OPP >= 45 — incumbents exist but real disruption vectors create openings
categories.FORTIFIED: OPP >= 30 — strong incumbents with real moats, limited entry paths, niche-only
categories.LOCKED: OPP < 30 — monopoly/duopoly with structural moats, entry requires 100x capital

cla_system.dual_ranking_principle: Transformation Rank (5-axis composite) and Opportunity Rank (CLA composite) are independent analytical systems that sit side by side. They are NEVER merged into a single number. High Transformation + Low Opportunity = 'will happen but you can't play it.' Low Transformation + High Opportunity = 'accessible but may not materialize.' The most actionable models score high on BOTH dimensions.

MKT.name: Market Magnitude
MKT.description: Realistic capturable market in 3-5 years. Not hand-waving TAM but plausible revenue ceiling for a single company.

scale.9-10: $10B+ addressable, platform-scale outcome (log-scale, top quartile only)

CAP.name: Capture Feasibility
CAP.description: Can a seed-funded startup realistically capture meaningful share in 3-5 years? Measures actual capture mechanics, not hype.

scale.1-2: Incumbents own distribution, 24+ month sales cycles, regulatory blocks
scale.5-6: Mixed channels, some accessible, 6-12 month sales cycles
scale.7-8: Direct acquisition viable, PLG possible, 3-6 month cycles
scale.9-10: Greenfield with pull demand, viral/PLG, customers actively seeking

ECO.name: Unit Economics
ECO.description: Steady-state margin and capital efficiency. Architecture-driven — maps business model to known margin profile.

scale.5-6: Mixed model, 45-60% gross margins, some recurring revenue
scale.7-8: Software/SaaS, 65-80% gross margins, strong unit economics
scale.9-10: Pure software/data, 80%+ margins, near-zero marginal cost

VEL.name: Revenue Velocity
VEL.description: Speed from $0 to $5M ARR. Determines whether 3-5 year window produces markable outcome.

scale.1-2: 36+ months to first material revenue, deep-tech R&D
scale.3-4: 18-36 months, long enterprise sales or regulatory approvals
scale.5-6: 12-18 months, standard B2B SaaS sales cycle
scale.9-10: <6 months, viral/PLG with instant activation, pull demand

MOA.name: Moat Trajectory
MOA.description: Once you have traction, does the business get harder or easier to compete with? Measures 5-year defensibility arc.

scale.1-2: Commodity forever, anyone can replicate, no switching costs
scale.3-4: Moderate switching costs, relationship moat only
scale.5-6: Meaningful switching costs + some data effects, but displaceable
scale.7-8: Strong compounding moat — data flywheel, regulatory capture, multi-product lock-in
scale.9-10: Winner-take-most dynamics, data moat grows exponentially

granularity_framework.trigger: FORTIFIED/LOCKED + VD >= 4 + (T_rank <= 50 OR sector_emp >= 1M OR (T_comp >= 75 AND OPP <= 45))
granularity_framework.method: Value chain layer analysis with Independently Viable Business Test
granularity_framework.scoring: FA/EC inherited from parent; SN/TG/CE re-scored; CLA fully independent

models.name: Infrastructure Inspection & Drone Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered drone and sensor platform for bridge, road, and utility infrastructure inspection -- replacing dangerous manual inspections in the $38.2B drone inspection market by 2030, with the US infrastructure backlog creating $2.6T in needed repairs (ASCE)
models.macro_source: F1: AI + drones replacing manual infrastructure inspection. F3: IIJA allocates $110B for roads/bridges, requiring inspection at scale. Drone inspection market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI in drones: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets).

cla.rationale: Infrastructure inspection is the strongest convergence point in construction: (1) IIJA mandates inspection of 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges, (2) manual inspection is dangerous (inspector fatalities, lane closures causing accidents), (3) inspector workforce is aging and shrinking, (4) drone + AI technology is mature enough for deployment. Current players: DroneUp, Skydio (raised $750M, US-made drones for defense/infrastructure), Flyability (confined space), Gecko Robotics (wall-climbing robots for utilities), and various DOT-specific solutions. Market openness is moderate: Skydio dominates the hardware layer for US government use (Chinese drone ban benefits US manufacturers). The AI ANALYSIS layer (identifying cracks, corrosion, deformation from drone imagery) is where the value concentrates and where competition is fragmented. Demand visibility is extreme: $2.6T infrastructure backlog (ASCE 2025 Report Card) + IIJA spending mandate.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US infrastructure condition: ASCE 2025 Infrastructure Report Card grades US infrastructure C- overall, with $2.6T investment gap. 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges (7.5% of total). 40% of roads in poor or mediocre condition. 7,500 dam safety deficiencies. IIJA: $110B for roads and bridges, $55B for water, $65B for broadband -- all requiring inspection capacity. Current manual bridge inspection: $5-25K per bridge, requires lane closures (costing $50K+/day in economic impact), and exposes inspectors to fall risk. Drone inspection: $1-5K per bridge, no lane closure, higher-resolution data capture. Global drone inspection and monitoring market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific drone analysis: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR. The FAA BVLOS (beyond visual line of sight) waiver program is expanding, enabling autonomous long-range inspections. Skydio's $750M raise and US government contracts validate the hardware layer. The AI layer (automated crack detection, corrosion measurement, structural deformation analysis) is where the most defensible value lies -- each inspection adds training data that improves detection accuracy.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B (US infrastructure inspection services addressable by drone + AI, within $38.2B global drone inspection market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: US has 617,000 bridges, 4.2M miles of roads, 91,000 dams, 2.6M miles of pipeline -- all requiring periodic inspection. Path to $200M ARR by serving 500 state/municipal DOT contracts at $200K average + 2,000 utility/pipeline contracts at $50K average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Per-inspection: $1-5K (bridge), $500-2K (road segment), $2-10K (dam). Subscription: $50K-$500K/year per DOT or utility. Gross margins 60-70% (drone hardware and operator costs). Multi-year government contracts provide revenue visibility.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: IIJA funding creates 5-year demand window. Federal mandate: all bridges inspected every 2 years. State DOT procurement cycles: 6-18 months but once won, multi-year contracts. Emergency inspection demand after weather events.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: AI models trained on millions of infrastructure images (crack detection, corrosion grading, deformation measurement). Government security clearance and compliance (NDAA-compliant hardware). Historical inspection baseline database. Integration with DOT asset management systems.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $2600000M

models.name: Sports Betting Data Intelligence & Compliance Platform
models.one_liner: Real-time sports data feeds, odds optimization, and responsible gambling compliance infrastructure for the $18B US sports betting market expanding across 39 legalized states
models.macro_source: Grand View Research US sports betting ($17.9B in 2024, 10.9% CAGR to 2030); AGA Commercial Gaming Revenue Tracker ($157B+ handle FY2025); QCEW NAICS 7132 (116K workers, 4.2K establishments); iGaming revenue $8.4B in 2024 (+28.7% YoY)
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7132 (Gambling Industries) has 4,195 establishments employing 116,263 workers at $954/week ($49,628 annual), with employment growing 8.3% YoY. The US sports betting market was $17.94B in 2024 (Grand View Research), growing at 10.9% CAGR. Handle (total amount wagered) exceeded $157B in FY2025, with 20% of US adults placing sports bets (up from 12% in 2023). Sports betting is now legal in 39 states plus DC. The infrastructure opportunity is the data and compliance layer BENEATH the consumer-facing sportsbooks. Sportradar processes 1.5B+ data points per second. The sports data oligopoly (Sportradar, Genius Sports, Stats Perform) powers the entire ecosystem. But the COMPLIANCE layer is under-built: responsible gambling regulations are tightening across jurisdictions, with each state imposing different requirements for self-exclusion programs, bet limits, advertising restrictions, and problem gambling detection. A multi-state operator must comply with 39 different regulatory frameworks simultaneously. iGaming (online casino) adds another dimension: $8.41B revenue in 2024 across 7 active states, growing 28.7% YoY. As more states legalize iGaming, the compliance complexity multiplies. The regulatory moat is real: compliance infrastructure that handles multi-state responsible gambling mandates, real-time bet monitoring for suspicious activity, and automated regulatory reporting creates deep defensibility — regulators approve specific technology stacks, and switching requires re-certification.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): the data feed layer is dominated by Sportradar and Genius Sports (duopoly). But the compliance and responsible gambling technology layer is nascent — no dominant platform exists for multi-state regulatory compliance automation. GeoComply (geolocation compliance) proved the regulatory infrastructure category at $1B+ valuation. Moat Advantage is very strong (9): regulatory certification creates a 12-24 month barrier to entry per state. Once embedded in an operator's compliance stack, switching requires re-certification and regulatory approval — the strongest moat type in any sector. Value Density is high (8): compliance is non-negotiable — operators face license revocation for violations. Pricing of $50-200K/year per state per operator is justified by the alternative (losing a $100M+ state license). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 39 states with active licensing requirements, 20+ operators per state, and regulatory frameworks getting MORE complex, not less.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=regulatory_moat_builder, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $17.9B (US sports betting market 2024). Data and compliance infrastructure: estimated $2-4B (10-20% of operator revenue flows to technology infrastructure). Responsible gambling compliance specifically: ~$800M-1.5B.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Sportradar ($800M+ revenue) and Genius Sports ($500M+ revenue) dominate data feeds. GeoComply ($1B+ valuation) owns geolocation compliance. Responsible gambling compliance is fragmented: Playtech (UK-focused), Mindway AI, BetBuddy (acquired by Playtech). No US-dominant multi-state compliance platform exists.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Enterprise SaaS: 75-85% gross margins. $100-200K/year per operator per state. With 20+ multi-state operators across 39 states, TAM per operator averages $2-8M annually. LTV: $600K+ (3-year contracts typical for regulatory infrastructure). CAC: $50-100K (enterprise sales to compliance/legal teams). LTV:CAC of 6-12x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 5-8 mid-tier sportsbook operators at $100K/year per 5-10 state deployments. Target: operators beyond top 5 (DraftKings, FanDuel, BetMGM, Caesars, ESPN BET) who lack internal compliance infrastructure. Timeline: 12-18 months with regulatory relationships as key distribution.

falsification_criteria: Sports betting legalization stalls — remaining 11 states (including California, Texas) fail to legalize, capping the addressable market
Sportradar and Genius Sports vertically integrate compliance features, eliminating the standalone compliance platform opportunity
Federal regulation preempts state-level requirements, simplifying compliance to the point where operators build in-house

models.name: Defense Predictive Maintenance AI
models.one_liner: AI-powered predictive maintenance for military vehicles, aircraft, and ships, reducing downtime 40% and maintenance costs 25%.
models.key_v3_context: Military readiness is the peacetime metric that matters most, and it is chronically below target. Maintenance is 30-40% of lifecycle defense cost. F2 demographics means maintenance workforce is aging and shrinking. F1 AI capability can predict failures before they happen. The $90B/yr DoD maintenance budget is one of the largest single-customer addressable markets in the world. v2 had commercial predictive maintenance models but none targeting the defense-specific readiness problem.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle

cla.rationale: Lockheed Martin, Raytheon, BAE own maintenance contracts. OEM data access is critical bottleneck. ITAR restrictions, long-term contracts are hard moats. Entry through DoD-mandated data sharing programs or specific non-OEM subsystems.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform, buyer=multi, frag=9, tam_source=sector $350000M→$3500M addressable, defense penalty

falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Local service businesses resist technology adoption at rates exceeding 70% for 3+ years
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.name: Retail Media Network Platform
models.one_liner: Advertising platform built on retailer first-party data, transforming retail from margin business to media business. $69.3B market in 2026, growing 20% annually. Amazon (77% share) + Walmart Connect ($4.4B) dominate.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US retail media spending: $58.8B (2025) to $69.3B (2026), growing 20%/year. Amazon Ads at $56B, 77% market share. Walmart Connect $4.4B, up 27% YoY, +53% globally with Vizio acquisition. Retail media fundamentally changes retail economics: stores and logistics operate at near break-even, advertising generates profit margin. This is why Amazon can undercut on price -- they monetize traffic, not products. Mid-market retailers building their own networks (Kroger Precision Marketing, Target Roundel).
models.macro_source: F1: AI-powered ad targeting on first-party retail purchase data. F4: Advertising dollars shifting from social media to retail media where purchase intent is directly measurable.

cla.rationale: Amazon controls 77% of retail media ($56B). First-party purchase data + retailer exclusivity = near-unbreakable moat. Enabling tech layer (Criteo, CitrusAd, Kevel) exists but is thin and commoditizable. Google Ads could aggregate mid-market but doesn't solve the retailer-owned data problem. Entry limited to ad-tech tools, not the network itself. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [54.0 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.

vcr.rationale: Retail media $69B+ but Amazon controls 77%. Massive market, near-impossible capture at seed stage.

falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Retail footprint contraction accelerates beyond AI-optimization ability to offset
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.name: Autonomous Trucking Middleware Platform
models.one_liner: Full-stack software platform connecting autonomous truck OEMs with fleet operators and shippers -- orchestrating L4 truck dispatch, handoff zones, and mixed fleet management in the $42.9B autonomous truck market growing to $86.8B by 2032
models.macro_source: Aurora Innovation surpassed 250K driverless miles Jan 2026, guiding $14-16M 2026 revenue with 200+ trucks by year-end. Mordor Intelligence: autonomous truck market $39.5B (2025) to $65.7B (2030) at 10.7% CAGR. Fortune Business Insights: $42.9B (2025) to $86.8B (2032). L4 driver-out pilots surged 140% YoY in 2025. ATA: 60K driver shortage growing to 160K by 2028.

cla.rationale: The autonomous trucking stack has three layers: (1) AV technology (Aurora, Waymo, Kodiak -- $5-15B invested per company); (2) OEM integration (Paccar, Daimler, Volvo); (3) fleet orchestration middleware (relatively greenfield). Layer 1 is locked by billion-dollar incumbents. Layer 3 -- the middleware that lets a fleet operator run a mixed fleet of human-driven and autonomous trucks, manage transfer hub handoffs, and optimize AV utilization -- is the opportunity. MO is 5 because Aurora and Kodiak are building their own fleet management tools, but a neutral middleware platform serving multiple AV providers and multiple fleet operators creates network effects. MA is 7 because integration depth with each AV stack creates switching costs. VD is 9 because per-mile pricing on $875B US trucking market yields massive value density.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Aurora Innovation: $3M 2025 revenue, guiding $14-16M 2026, targeting $80M run-rate by end 2027. 250K+ driverless miles by Jan 2026, nearly 3x Oct 2025. 200+ driverless trucks by end 2026. Second-gen hardware kit mid-2026 cuts costs 50%, doubles lidar range to 1,000m. Kodiak: $770K Q3 revenue, 92.5% YoY growth, military contracts for autonomous logistics. US trucking: $875B revenue, 3.58M drivers, 60K shortage growing to 160K by 2028. L4 deployment reality: highway hub-to-hub corridors (Dallas-Houston, Phoenix-El Paso) first, urban later. Transfer hubs needed every 200-400 miles for driver handoff. Mixed fleet management is the transition-period software problem: most fleets will run 10-30% autonomous, 70-90% human for 5+ years. Whoever builds the orchestration layer for this transition captures the operating system of autonomous freight.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.5-8B by 2030 (middleware layer capturing 5-10% of autonomous trucking operating costs on $65-87B total market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible but requires deep integration partnerships with AV providers. Neutral positioning (working with Aurora AND Kodiak AND Waymo) is the moat, but each AV company will resist third-party fleet management. Most likely path: win with mid-size carriers first (500-5000 trucks) who cannot afford to build their own AV integration stack.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS + per-mile transaction fee model. Target $0.03-0.05/mile on autonomous miles (vs driver cost of $0.45-0.65/mile saved). Gross margins 70-80% once platform built. But development costs are high ($20-50M to build credible AV integration layer).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-12 months for fleet operators. Pilot deployments start small (5-20 trucks). Full deployment ramp 18-36 months per customer. Fastest adoption in hub-to-hub truckload corridors where AV utilization is highest.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Multi-AV-provider integration depth (API integrations with Aurora, Kodiak, Waymo are each 6-12 months of engineering). Fleet operator switching costs increase with data accumulation (route optimization, load matching, maintenance scheduling). Network effects: more carriers on platform = better load matching for autonomous trucks.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $875000M

models.name: Warehouse Robotics Orchestration Layer
models.one_liner: Multi-vendor warehouse robotics orchestration software managing AMRs, pick systems, and conveyors from multiple vendors in the $6.5-17.6B warehouse robotics market growing at 19-23% CAGR to $17-56B by 2030-2033
models.macro_source: Fortune Business Insights: warehouse robotics $6.5B (2025) to $25.4B (2034). Grand View Research: $4.3B (2022) to $17.3B (2030) at 19.6% CAGR. Straits Research: $17.6B (2025) to $55.7B (2033). GM Insights: $14.7B (2024), 23.1% CAGR to 2034. 26% of US warehouses now use some form of automation. Warehouse worker turnover 43%. Average warehouse wage $44K -- labor shortage is structural.

cla.rationale: Warehouse automation has dozens of hardware vendors: AMRs (Locus, 6 River/Ocado, Geek+), AS/RS (AutoStore, Swisslog), goods-to-person (Symbotic, Berkshire Grey), palletizing (Covariant, RightHand). Each has proprietary control software. The ORCHESTRATION problem: a large warehouse (500K+ SF) typically has 3-5 different robotic systems from different vendors that cannot communicate. The middleware/orchestration layer that manages multi-vendor robotics (task allocation, traffic management, slotting optimization) is the unseized opportunity. SVT Robotics raised $25M for exactly this but market is early. MO is 6 because warehouse management system (WMS) vendors (Manhattan Associates, Blue Yonder) are expanding into robotics orchestration. MA is 7 because deep integration with each robot vendor's API creates compounding switching costs.

models.deep_dive_evidence: 1.8M US warehouse workers, employment doubled since 2015. 26% of warehouses use automation but 74% still primarily manual -- massive adoption headroom. Average warehouse handles 3,000-10,000 SKUs; e-commerce warehouses handle 50K-500K SKUs (complexity drives automation need). Symbotic: $1.8B backlog, Walmart-exclusive initially but expanding. Locus Robotics: 95M+ units picked via AMRs. AutoStore: 1,200+ installations globally. Key pain: a warehouse running Locus AMRs, AutoStore cube storage, and conveyor sortation has THREE separate control systems. Workers must mentally bridge the gaps. Orchestration software that unifies these systems can improve throughput 20-35% based on early deployments. SVT Robotics (SOFTBOT Platform) is the earliest mover but raised only $25M. The market needs what Kubernetes did for cloud: a multi-vendor orchestration standard for warehouse robotics.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Warehouse automation ROI fails to justify capital expenditure for mid-size operators
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.5-5B by 2030 (orchestration software layer capturing 15-20% of warehouse robotics spend as software-to-hardware ratio increases)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible targeting large 3PLs and enterprise warehouses (500K+ SF) with multi-vendor robotics installations. Must support minimum 5 major robot vendors at launch. First-mover advantage significant because integration depth compounds. SVT Robotics is the reference startup but underfunded relative to opportunity.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing per robot managed: $200-500/robot/month. Large warehouse with 200 robots = $40-100K/month. Gross margins 80%+. Implementation services ($50-200K per warehouse) provide initial revenue. Annual contract value $500K-1.2M per large warehouse.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-12 months for enterprise warehouses. Proof of concept with 1 building, expand to multi-site. Fastest adoption at 3PLs who operate multiple client warehouses and need standardized multi-vendor management. Peak season performance (Q4) is the decision driver.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Integration depth with each robot vendor (6-12 months API work per vendor). Data compounding: task allocation algorithms improve with more throughput data. Network effects among 3PL operators: a 3PL running 50 warehouses standardizes on one orchestration platform. Robot vendor partnerships: becoming the recommended orchestration layer for Locus, AutoStore, etc.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=robotics_automation, buyer=enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $1800M

models.name: Intelligent Live Event Dynamic Pricing & Revenue Optimization
models.one_liner: AI dynamic pricing and yield management for live event venues and promoters, optimizing ticket pricing, inventory allocation, and ancillary revenue across the $88B global ticketing market
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence online event ticketing market ($88.4B by 2026); QCEW NAICS 7113 (164K workers, 10.8K establishments, +12.7% emp growth); Live Nation Q3 2025 results; MarketsandMarkets event management software forecast ($66B by 2033)
models.sector_name: Promoters of Performing Arts, Sports, and Similar Events
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7113 (Promoters of Performing Arts, Sports, and Similar Events) has 10,845 establishments employing 164,074 workers at $1,022/week ($53,157 annual), with 12.7% employment growth YoY — the fastest growing sub-sector in NAICS 71. The live events economy is booming: Live Nation sold 100M+ tickets in the first half of 2025 alone versus 98M in all of 2019, tracking toward 160M fans for full-year 2025. The online event ticketing market is estimated at $88.4B in 2026 (Mordor Intelligence). The pricing optimization opportunity is massive: Live Nation reported ticketing AOI up 21% driven by 12% increase in fee-bearing GTV — evidence that dynamic pricing drives material yield improvement. Currently, most non-Live Nation venues use static or basic tiered pricing. AI dynamic pricing (similar to airline revenue management) can increase per-event revenue 10-25% by optimizing price curves based on demand signals, historical patterns, artist popularity, weather, local events, and remaining inventory decay curves. The addressable market is venues and promoters NOT controlled by Live Nation — NAICS 711310 has 4,615 establishments with 124,096 workers in the venue-with-facilities segment. SeatGeek (primary ticketing deals with Dallas Cowboys, Brooklyn Nets) and AXS have proven alternatives exist. The DOJ antitrust case against Live Nation could create structural openings. Event management software market growing from $18.3B to $66B by 2033 (17.4% CAGR) confirms the infrastructure software opportunity.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): Live Nation/Ticketmaster controls 70%+ of US primary ticketing with exclusive venue contracts — the addressable market is the remaining 30% of venues and mid-tier events. SeatGeek, AXS, and Dice are competing alternatives but none has a dominant pricing intelligence layer. Moat Advantage is strong (7): pricing algorithms trained on venue-specific demand patterns compound in accuracy over time — a venue using the system for 2+ years gets materially better yield optimization than a new deployment. Integration with ticketing, POS, and CRM systems creates workflow lock-in. Value Density is high (8): 10-25% revenue lift on a $2M annual ticket revenue venue = $200-500K, easily justifying $2-5K/month SaaS. Demand Visibility is strong (8): every promoter and venue operator understands yield management — airlines proved the concept decades ago. The question is execution and integration, not demand education.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $88.4B (global online event ticketing 2026, Mordor Intelligence). US event management software: ~$8B. Dynamic pricing/yield management specifically for live events: ~$2-3B addressable.

models.name: Automated Jobsite Safety Monitoring Platform
models.one_liner: Computer vision + wearable IoT platform that detects safety hazards in real-time (fall risk, PPE compliance, struck-by exposure) on construction jobsites -- addressing the $4.6B construction worker safety market by 2030 within the broader $24.3B AI in construction market
models.macro_source: F1: AI safety/risk management fastest-growing AI-in-construction segment at 30.5% CAGR through 2030. Construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030). OSHA reporting ~1,000 construction fatalities/year and 200K injuries. GlobeNewswire Sept 2025, Grand View Research.

cla.rationale: Construction safety is the strongest demand signal in contech -- OSHA fines doubled in 2023, EMR (experience modification rate) directly impacts insurance premiums and bidding eligibility. Newmetrix (acquired by Oracle 2023) and Smartvid.io (acquired by Newmetrix) validated the category. Current leaders include Versatile (crane monitoring), Triax (wearables), and various startups. Market openness is moderate-high because no single platform dominates across all safety vectors (fall protection, struck-by, PPE, housekeeping, trenching). Oracle/Newmetrix is enterprise-focused. The mid-market (200K+ firms) is largely unserved. Demand visibility is the highest of any construction AI category: every GC faces OSHA compliance, insurance pressure, and moral obligation.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction is the deadliest major industry: 1,056 fatalities in 2023 (BLS), 200K+ non-fatal injuries. OSHA's 'Fatal Four' (falls 33.5%, struck-by 11.1%, electrocution 7.0%, caught-in/between 5.4%) are all detectable by computer vision. OSHA maximum penalties increased to $16,131 per serious violation and $161,323 per willful violation (2024 adjustment). The construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030) at 6.0% CAGR (GlobeNewswire/ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific safety solutions growing at 30.5% CAGR within this market (Grand View Research). Insurance incentive: a single fatality costs $5M+ in direct costs; EMR impacts persist for 3 years on all bids. AI safety platforms (camera-based + wearable) can reduce recordable incidents 40-60% based on pilot data from Newmetrix, Smartvid.io, and Suffolk Construction deployments. Pricing: $2-5K/month per active jobsite for camera-based monitoring, $5-15/month per wearable per worker.
falsification_criteria: Open-source or foundation model alternatives eliminate proprietary data moat advantages
Data privacy regulations (state-level CCPA variants) restrict data aggregation business model
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.6B (construction worker safety technology by 2030, AI-specific segment ~$1.8B)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Mid-market opportunity is strong: Oracle/Newmetrix serves enterprise GCs, leaving 200K+ mid-market firms underserved. Insurance companies are potential distribution partners (reduced EMR = reduced premiums = shared savings). Path to $150M ARR serving 5,000 jobsites at $30K/year average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $12K-$120K per firm (scaled by number of active jobsites). Hardware cost: $2-5K per jobsite for cameras. Wearables: $200-500 per unit. Gross margins 65-75% (hardware drag). Payback: one prevented serious injury ($50K+ direct cost) justifies annual subscription.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-60 days for mid-market (safety is urgent, not strategic). Insurance partnership channel accelerates adoption. OSHA citation is often the trigger event. Seasonal: Northern US jobsites slower in winter.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Computer vision models trained on millions of construction-specific images (PPE detection, fall zone identification, equipment proximity). Incident database creates predictive capability (which site conditions predict injuries). Integration with insurance carriers creates switching costs.

models.name: Climate Risk Analytics and Disclosure Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered climate risk modeling, scenario analysis, and regulatory disclosure platform for corporates and financial institutions — serving mandatory SEC and EU CSRD reporting requirements across 50,000+ affected companies
models.macro_source: SEC Climate Disclosure Rule (adopted March 2024, compliance beginning 2026); EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) effective January 2024; ISSB IFRS S1/S2 standards; TCFD adoption statistics; McKinsey climate risk quantification methodology
models.deep_dive_evidence: The SEC's climate disclosure rule (adopted March 2024, partially stayed pending litigation but Scope 1/2 reporting proceeding) requires public companies to report greenhouse gas emissions, climate risk governance, and transition plans. The EU's CSRD is more aggressive — requiring 50,000+ companies (including non-EU companies with significant EU revenue) to report under European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) starting 2024-2026 in phases. Together, these mandates create a structural requirement for climate risk analytics that did not exist 3 years ago. The climate risk analytics market is projected at $4.8B by 2029 (MarketsandMarkets, 22.3% CAGR). Current landscape: Persefoni (raised $101M) provides carbon accounting for SEC/CSRD compliance. Watershed (raised $100M, valued at $1.8B) serves enterprise carbon management. S&P Global, MSCI, and Moody's offer climate risk scoring but lack the granular physical risk modeling and disclosure automation that corporates need. The data moat opportunity: climate risk modeling requires integrating satellite imagery, weather data, supply chain mapping, emissions factors, and financial data into company-specific risk scores. Each client engagement generates proprietary risk data that improves models. Banks and insurers need portfolio-level climate risk aggregation for TCFD/ECB stress testing — JPMorgan alone has $3.4T in assets requiring climate risk assessment. The gap between regulatory requirement and corporate capability is enormous: Deloitte's 2025 climate survey found only 23% of affected companies have automated climate data collection, and 68% are relying on spreadsheets for CSRD reporting.

models.name: Commodity Row Crop Precision Input Management Platform
models.one_liner: Field-level prescription engine that ingests yield monitor data, soil EC maps, satellite NDVI, and weather models to generate variable-rate seeding, fertilizer, and lime prescriptions -- reducing input costs $15-40/acre on the 230M acres of US corn and soy
models.macro_source: F1: Variable-rate technology reduces input costs 15-25% on corn/soy (Purdue Extension, 2024 meta-analysis of 140 on-farm trials). F4: Fertilizer prices remain 40% above 2020 baseline post-Ukraine shock, intensifying input optimization demand. F6: Nitrogen management directly linked to N2O emissions and water quality regulation (EPA nutrient management plans required in 23 states).
models.deep_dive_evidence: US corn: 94.6M planted acres (2024 USDA), avg input cost $750/acre (seed $130, fertilizer $250, crop protection $80, fuel/equipment $160, land $130). Soy: 86.1M acres, avg input cost $430/acre. Variable-rate technology (VRT) is adopted on ~30% of corn acres and ~22% of soy acres (USDA ARMS 2023), meaning 125M+ acres are applying uniform-rate inputs despite known sub-field variability -- a $4-8B annual inefficiency. The data compounding moat: every acre-year of yield data correlated with inputs, soil, and weather makes prescriptions more accurate. Climate Corp (acquired by Bayer, formerly Monsanto, for $930M in 2013) attempted this but failed to gain farmer trust due to data privacy concerns and Monsanto association. Granular (acquired by Corteva for ~$300M) has 25M+ managed acres. Farmers Business Network (FBN) has 60M+ contributed acres of agronomic data from 60K+ farm members. The key insight: NO PLATFORM has closed the loop from prescription to verified yield outcome at scale. Current tools generate recommendations but do not automatically learn from what actually happened. Closing this feedback loop is the data compounding opportunity. Average ROI per trial: $22-38/acre on corn (Iowa State On-Farm Network, 2019-2024 average), $12-20/acre on soy. At $3-8/acre subscription price, payback is 3-5x in year one.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate because Deere Operations Center, Climate FieldView (Bayer), and Corteva Granular all compete in prescription generation. But none has closed the feedback loop, and all are mistrusted as seed/chemical company subsidiaries. An INDEPENDENT platform (not owned by an input company) has structural trust advantage. Moat advantage builds through acre-years of verified outcome data. Value density is moderate per-acre ($3-8/acre) but massive at scale (230M acres addressable). Demand is proven: FBN's $900M+ fundraising demonstrates farmer willingness to pay for independent agronomic intelligence.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.5-3.0B (precision ag decision support for commodity row crops, subset of $22.5B total precision ag market)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: consolidated at top, fragmented at delivery
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Subscription $3-8/acre/year. Average large grain farm: 2,500 acres = $7,500-$20,000/year ACV. Gross margins 75-85% (software + satellite data costs). CAC challenge: farmer sales cycle is seasonal (decisions made Oct-Feb for spring planting). Direct sales to 100K+ large operations is feasible; below 1,000 acres requires dealer/co-op channel.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Sign 300-500 large grain operations (2,000+ acres each) at $10-15K ACV average. Requires 2-3 years of on-farm trials to build credibility. Leverage Cooperative Extension and crop consultant partnerships for distribution. First $5M ARR achievable in year 3-4 with 400 paying farms.

falsification_criteria: If John Deere's Operations Center closes the prescription-to-outcome feedback loop for its 200M+ connected acres, eliminating the independent platform opportunity
If commodity prices collapse (corn below $3.50/bu sustained) to the point where farmers cut all precision ag spending to survive
If fertilizer prices normalize to pre-2020 levels, reducing the urgency of input optimization from 'survival' to 'nice-to-have'

models.name: iGaming & Casino Analytics Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered player analytics, fraud detection, and revenue optimization for casinos and iGaming operators in a $49.6K-avg-pay sector where iGaming revenue grew 28.7% YoY to $8.4B
models.macro_source: AGA Commercial Gaming Revenue Tracker; QCEW NAICS 713210 (64.7K workers, 441 establishments, $47.5K avg pay); Mordor Intelligence US online gambling ($6.89B in 2026 to $14.8B by 2031, 16.5% CAGR); iGaming revenue $8.41B in 2024 across 7 states
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 713210 (Casinos except Casino Hotels) has 441 establishments employing 64,734 workers at $913/week ($47,460 annual), with 5.1% employment growth. The broader gambling category (NAICS 7132) has 4,195 establishments and 116,263 workers. But the structural story is the DIGITAL SHIFT: combined iGaming revenue across 7 active US states reached $8.41B in 2024, growing 28.7% YoY (AGA). The US online gambling market is projected from $6.89B in 2026 to $14.79B by 2031 at 16.51% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). Physical casinos are not dying — total US commercial gaming revenue exceeded $68B in 2024 (AGA) — but the growth is overwhelmingly digital. The AI analytics opportunity spans both physical and digital: (1) Player analytics — AI profiles player behavior to optimize game floor layout, comp offers, and retention marketing. A 1% improvement in player retention at a $500M-revenue casino is $5M. (2) Fraud detection — iGaming fraud losses estimated at 3-5% of handle; AI real-time transaction monitoring can reduce fraud 40-60%. (3) Revenue optimization — AI-powered game recommendation engines, dynamic comp offers, and cross-channel (physical + digital) player management. (4) Responsible gambling compliance — AI behavioral analysis to detect problem gambling patterns before self-exclusion, required by regulators in all active states. The challenge: casino operators are conservative, highly regulated, and often have significant internal technology teams. Tribal casinos (500+ in the US) have additional sovereignty and compliance considerations.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): major operators have significant in-house analytics (MGM's BetMGM platform, Caesars' Caesars Digital). But mid-tier operators, tribal casinos, and new iGaming entrants lack these capabilities. The tribal casino segment alone (500+ establishments) is underserved by technology vendors. Moat Advantage is very strong (8): player behavior data compounding creates deep defensibility — models trained on millions of player sessions across multiple properties identify patterns invisible to new entrants. Regulatory approval of analytics/compliance systems creates certification moat. Value Density is high (8): casinos and iGaming operators generate massive revenue per establishment — the 441 QCEW establishments average 146 workers each, suggesting large operations where even small efficiency gains are highly valuable. Demand Visibility is strong (7): every casino operator understands the value of player analytics — the question is build vs buy.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $14.8B (US online gambling by 2031). Casino analytics and compliance technology: estimated $2-4B. iGaming-specific infrastructure: ~$1.5B.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Aristocrat Gaming (game content + analytics). IGT/Scientific Games (gaming systems). GAN Limited (B2B iGaming platform). Nuvei/Paysafe (gaming payments). SAS/Teradata (legacy analytics in casinos). No dominant AI-native cross-channel (physical + digital) analytics platform.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Enterprise SaaS: 75-80% gross margins. $50,000-200,000/year per casino property. iGaming platform analytics: $100-500K/year per operator. Average ARPU: $150,000/year. LTV: $450,000 (3-year contracts). CAC: $50-100K (gaming industry conferences, regulatory relationships). LTV:CAC of 4.5-9x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 25-35 casino/iGaming operator contracts at $150K/year average. Target: mid-tier casino operators (5-20 properties) and tribal gaming operations. Entry via responsible gambling compliance module (regulatory mandate creates urgency), expand to full analytics. Timeline: 18-24 months.

BUT most existing platforms are telematics-first (GPS, ELD, dashcam) with analytics bolted on. models.name: Cold Chain Monitoring & Compliance AI
models.one_liner: End-to-end IoT + AI platform for cold chain visibility, FSMA compliance, and temperature excursion prediction across the $91.1B US cold chain logistics market growing to $109.8B by 2030
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: US cold chain logistics $91.1B (2025) to $109.8B (2030) at 6.7% CAGR. Global cold chain $361-413B (2025) growing at 6.4-13.8% CAGR. Refrigerated transport leading at 7.1% CAGR. Deep-frozen segment (mRNA vaccines, biologics) at 8.5% CAGR. FSMA 204 food traceability rule enforcement expanding 2025-2026. GLP-1 drug cold chain creating $5B+ incremental demand.

cla.rationale: Cold chain monitoring is fragmented with many point solutions: Sensitech (Carrier subsidiary -- market leader in pharma cold chain), Emerson/Copeland (temperature monitoring), Tive (real-time visibility), Controlant (pharma cold chain -- monitored all Pfizer COVID vaccines). However, most solutions are MONITORING-only (alerting after temperature excursion). The AI opportunity is PREDICTIVE: predicting temperature excursions BEFORE they happen (based on door open/close patterns, ambient temperature, load configuration, equipment age) and automatically triggering corrective actions. FSMA 204 traceability requirements create compliance automation opportunity. MO is 6 because Sensitech and Carrier have strong pharma positions. But food cold chain (70% of market) is underserved by pharma-grade solutions.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US cold chain: $91.1B market (2025). $35B+ annual food waste attributed to cold chain failures. FDA FSMA 204 food traceability rule: requires end-to-end digital tracking of high-risk foods from farm to retail. Enforcement expanding through 2026. Temperature excursions cause 10-15% of pharmaceutical product losses ($15-35B globally). GLP-1 drugs (Ozempic, Mounjaro) require 36-46F storage -- $50B+ market creating cold chain demand surge. Biologics/mRNA vaccines require -70C storage, driving deep-frozen segment growth. Current cold chain monitoring: 60% still use single-use data loggers (no real-time visibility). Only 15% use predictive analytics. The gap between monitoring (what HAPPENED) and prediction (what WILL happen) is the AI opportunity. A reefer truck breakdown costs $5-25K per load in spoiled product. Predicting the breakdown 4 hours earlier (based on compressor vibration, condenser pressure, ambient temperature) saves the entire load.
falsification_criteria: Hardware component costs fail to decline on expected trajectory
Software-only solutions prove sufficient, eliminating need for specialized hardware
Warehouse automation ROI fails to justify capital expenditure for mid-size operators
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.5-6B by 2030 (cold chain visibility + predictive + compliance software on $110B US cold chain market, 3-5% software penetration)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in food cold chain (70% of market, fragmented, underserved by pharma-focused incumbents). FSMA 204 compliance is a forcing function creating urgency for digital cold chain tracking. Must provide both hardware (IoT sensors) and software (AI platform) for seamless deployment.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: IoT sensor hardware $50-200/unit (installed on pallets, trucks, containers). SaaS monitoring fee $5-20/asset/month. Enterprise cold chain operator with 500 monitored assets = $30-120K ARR. Hardware margins low (15-25%) but SaaS margins 80%+. Blended gross margin 55-70%.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: FSMA compliance deadline creates urgency (must-buy, not nice-to-have). Sales cycle 3-6 months for food distributors, 6-12 months for pharma. Fastest adoption in high-value cold chain (pharma, biologics, premium food). Seasonal produce shipping creates natural pilot windows.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: predictive models improve with more cold chain data (equipment failure patterns, route-specific temperature risks, seasonal variations). Compliance data creates regulatory switching cost (auditors rely on historical data in your platform). IoT hardware installed base creates physical switching cost. Industry-specific models (dairy vs frozen vs pharma vs floral) create depth that horizontal IoT platforms lack.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=iot_platform, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $109800M

models.name: Retail Data Clean Room & Privacy-Safe Collaboration Platform

cla.rationale: MO=6: LiveRamp/Habu is the early leader after acquisition, but market is still forming. Snowflake, AWS, Google all have clean room products — no single dominant player. WPP acquired InfoSum, creating another competitor. Market fragmented enough for new entrants but consolidating. MA=7: Incumbent moats are moderate. LiveRamp has identity graph advantage but clean room interoperability standards are emerging (reducing lock-in). Cloud platforms (AWS, Snowflake) have distribution advantage but not clean-room-specific moats. No dominant data network effect yet — each retailer-brand pair is a distinct relationship. VD=3: Within clean rooms, the value chain is shallow — identity resolution, computation engine, policy enforcement, reporting. These are features of a platform, not independent businesses. DV=8: Strong disruption vectors: (1) Privacy regulation forcing adoption (GDPR, state laws, cookie death); (2) retail media fragmentation requiring neutral data collaboration infrastructure; (3) open-source privacy-preserving computation could democratize the technology layer; (4) cloud platform commoditization of basic clean room functionality pushes value to vertical specialization; (5) clean room consolidation (Habu, InfoSum acquired) creates market gaps as independents disappear.

vcr.rationale: Retail data clean rooms. $2B→$10B by 2033. Privacy regulation tailwind. Platform moat.

falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features

models.name: Creator Economy Business Operations Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered business management for professional creators — income tracking, rights management, brand deal optimization, and tax compliance across the $254B creator economy
models.macro_source: Market.us creator economy ($254B in 2025, 23% CAGR); QCEW NAICS 7115 (59.6K workers, 39.8K establishments, $151.9K avg pay, -10.3% wage decline); NAICS 7114 (29.6K workers, 6.7K establishments, $132.5K avg pay, +15.9% emp growth); Goldman Sachs creator economy research
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data shows two related sub-sectors: NAICS 7115 (Independent Artists, Writers, Performers) with 39,808 establishments and 59,575 workers at $151,858 avg pay, and NAICS 7114 (Agents/Managers) with 6,698 establishments and 29,621 workers at $132,534 avg pay. The critical signal: NAICS 7115 wages DECLINED -10.3% YoY while employment grew 2.1% — a Baumol compression signal where AI is already compressing creative worker earnings. Meanwhile, NAICS 7114 saw explosive 15.9% employment growth as the intermediary/management layer expands with the creator economy. The creator economy reached $254B in 2025 (Market.us), with 91% of US/UK creators now using AI tools. But the business operations side is primitive: most creators manage finances through spreadsheets, lack proper rights tracking, and overpay on taxes. The typical mid-tier creator (100K-1M followers) manages 3-5 revenue streams (ad revenue, sponsorships, merchandise, subscriptions, licensing) across 2-4 platforms with zero integrated financial visibility. AI creator business tools secured $300M+ in funding in 2025. The Coasean thesis applies directly: a creator who previously needed a 5-person team (manager, agent, accountant, lawyer, social media manager) can potentially operate with AI + 1 human coordinator. This is the full-service-replacement architecture: replacing the agency model with an AI-native operations platform. This extends the existing PC8-FSR-TALENT-01 and PC8-FSR-INDARTIST-01 model cards with deeper business operations scope and evidence.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (8): no dominant creator business operations platform exists. Karat Financial (creator banking), Stir (creator finance), and Lumanu (creator payments) serve fragments of the need but none provides unified business management. The 39.8K NAICS 7115 establishments plus broader 50M+ content creators globally represent massive unmet demand. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): financial data integration (connecting YouTube, TikTok, Patreon, Shopify, Stripe, bank accounts) creates switching costs once established, but individual features risk commoditization. Rights management and tax optimization create deeper defensibility. Value Density is moderate (6): $50-300/month from individual creators, $500-2,000/month from creator agencies and MCNs (multi-channel networks). Demand Visibility is strong (8): 91% of creators use AI tools already — the adoption barrier is low. Every creator who earns $50K+ annually needs financial and business management.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=full_service_replacement, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $254B (global creator economy 2025). Creator business tools and infrastructure: ~$10-15B. US-specific creator business operations: ~$3-5B.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Fragmented. Karat Financial (creator banking), Stir (financial management), Lumanu (payments), Spring/Teespring (merch), Patreon (subscriptions), Gumroad (digital products). No unified business operations platform. YouTube Studio and TikTok analytics are platform-specific, not cross-platform.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Freemium SaaS: 80-85% gross margins. $100/month average for individual creators, $1,000/month for MCNs/agencies. Transaction-based revenue on brand deal facilitation (5-10% of deal value). Blended ARPU: $150/month. LTV: $2,700 (18-month retention at $150/mo). CAC: $50-200 (PLG via creator communities, influencer marketing, TikTok/YouTube content about the tool). LTV:CAC of 13.5-54x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 3,000-4,000 creators at $100/month + 50-100 MCNs/agencies at $1,000/month. Target: mid-tier creators ($50K-500K annual income) who are too big for spreadsheets but too small for traditional management. PLG distribution via creator-to-creator referral. Timeline: 12-15 months.

falsification_criteria: Platform-native business tools (YouTube Studio, TikTok Creator Fund analytics) become comprehensive enough that third-party tools are unnecessary
Creator economy consolidation reduces the mid-tier creator population — if only top 0.1% of creators earn meaningful income, the addressable market for business tools shrinks
AI content generation collapses creator economics entirely — if AI produces content at near-zero marginal cost, human creator income evaporates and there is no business to manage

models.name: Crop Insurance Risk Modeling & Claims Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: ML-powered crop insurance platform that underwrites, prices, and adjusts claims using satellite imagery, weather data, and yield history -- reducing the $4.2B in annual loss adjustment costs and $1.8B in fraud within the $20B Federal Crop Insurance Program
models.macro_source: F1: Satellite resolution now sub-meter (Planet Labs) enabling field-level yield verification without physical inspection. F4: Federal Crop Insurance Program: $20B in premiums, $12B in federal subsidies (2024). Total indemnities paid: $19.3B in 2022 (drought year). F3: Climate volatility increasing claim frequency -- 2012-2024 avg indemnities 2.3x higher than 2000-2011 average.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Federal Crop Insurance Program (FCIP): 1.16M policies, 490M acres insured, $20.0B in total premiums (2024, USDA RMA). Federal subsidy: $12B (government pays 60% of premium). 16 Approved Insurance Providers (AIPs) underwrite FCIP policies: top 5 (Crop Risk Services/Zurich, Rural Community Insurance Services, NAU Country, Great American, ProAg) control ~65% of market. Loss adjustment: 6,500+ contracted adjusters physically inspect fields for claims -- avg cost $650/claim, total $4.2B/year. Fraud estimate: $1.5-2.0B/year (GAO reports, primarily overstated losses and prevented planting claims). SATELLITE OPPORTUNITY: Planet Labs' 3-meter daily imagery can detect: (1) planting verification (was the field actually planted?), (2) prevented planting fraud (was there actually standing water?), (3) yield estimation within 5-8% of actual (vs 15-20% for ground-based APH). Descartes Labs, CIBO Technologies, and Understory (weather intelligence) are building components. NO integrated platform serves the full insurance lifecycle: underwriting risk model + premium pricing + satellite-based loss adjustment + fraud detection. The $4.2B in annual adjustment costs is the immediate TAM reduction opportunity. An AI platform that replaces 40-60% of physical adjustments saves $1.7-2.5B/year. AIP willingness to pay: proven, as they bear loss adjustment expense (LAE) directly.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate: the 16 AIPs are sophisticated buyers, and USDA RMA sets rules. But NO AIP has built a comprehensive satellite-based adjustment platform, and all are motivated by LAE reduction. Moat advantage is strong: historical yield data correlated with satellite imagery across millions of field-years creates compounding accuracy. Value density is HIGH: $4.2B in annual adjustment costs means even a 20% reduction = $840M in savings. Demand visibility is strong: every AIP CFO knows their LAE ratio and wants it lower.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.0-4.0B (crop insurance technology: underwriting analytics + satellite loss adjustment + fraud detection within $20B FCIP premium market)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: consolidated buyers, fragmented tech
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS licensing to AIPs: $2-5M/year per AIP (16 AIPs = $32-80M TAM from direct licensing). Per-claim adjustment: $150-300 satellite-based vs $650 physical = $350-500 savings/claim. Volume: 700K+ claims/year across FCIP. Transaction fee model: $50-100/claim processed = $35-70M revenue at scale. Gross margins 80%+ (satellite data costs declining, compute is primary variable cost).
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Win 2-3 of the 16 AIPs with pilot programs processing 50K+ claims each via satellite analytics. $1.5-2.5M/year per AIP in licensing + per-claim fees. First $5M ARR in year 2-3 because buyer concentration (16 AIPs) means each sale is large. USDA RMA approval process may add 12-18 months for policy changes allowing satellite-primary adjustment.

falsification_criteria: If USDA Risk Management Agency resists satellite-based loss adjustment (regulatory barrier to replacing physical inspection for FCIP claims)
If satellite yield estimation accuracy stalls at 10%+ error rates, insufficient for insurance-grade loss verification
If the 16 AIPs each build proprietary satellite analytics internally rather than buying from a platform (they have the data and the incentive)

models.name: Industrial MRO Distribution Rollup Platform
models.one_liner: Acquire Silver Tsunami distributors in fragmented $500B industrial MRO market, deploy unified ERP + AI demand forecasting to lift fill rates from 92% to 97%+ and compress DSO from 48 to 35 days
models.macro_source: F2: 67% of industrial distributors lack succession plans, avg owner age 60+ (Distribution Strategy Group 2024). models.sector_name: Motor Vehicle and Machinery Parts Wholesale / Industrial MRO
models.deep_dive_evidence: US industrial distribution is a $500B+ market with extreme fragmentation: 100K+ distributors, top 50 hold <25% combined share. Grainger ($16.5B revenue, 5% share), Fastenal ($7.3B, 2% share), MSC Industrial ($3.8B, <1% share), HD Supply ($7B, 1.5% share). The remaining ~90% of market is served by independent distributors averaging $5-15M in revenue and 15-50 employees. The Silver Tsunami is the defining catalyst: NAW Industrial Distribution Survey (2024) found 67% of owners over 55 have no documented succession plan. EBITDA multiples for independent distributors: 5-7x for $5-15M revenue, 7-9x for $15-50M. A rollup deploying standardized technology (unified ERP, AI demand forecasting, dynamic pricing, route optimization) can generate 200-400bps EBITDA expansion per acquired location within 18-24 months. Evidence: Winsupply (HVAC/plumbing, 700+ locations, $7B revenue) and SRS Distribution (roofing, $10B+, acquired by Home Depot for $18.25B in 2024) prove the model at scale. AI-specific impact: McKinsey estimates AI-driven demand forecasting improves inventory turns 15-25% and reduces stockouts 20-30% in distribution. At $500B market with 4% EBITDA, even 1% market share capture at improved margins generates $25M+ EBITDA.

cla.rationale: Market is maximally open — 100K+ potential acquisition targets, no gatekeeper blocking entry, sellers are motivated (retirement). Moat advantage is strong: each acquisition adds local customer relationships, vendor lines, and market knowledge that compound. Value chain depth is moderate — core value is buy, integrate, optimize, not deep technology differentiation. Demand visibility is excellent: industrial MRO is recurring, essential, and counter-cyclical. The primary risk is execution: integrating 15-30 acquisitions per year while maintaining fill rates and customer relationships requires operational excellence.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=rollup_consolidation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $500B (US industrial MRO distribution, addressable rollup segment ~$200B in fragmented independents)

Target 15-30 acquisitions/year at $3-5M avg deal size = $50-150M capital deployed/year. Revenue per location $8-20M. Gross margin 22-28%. Operating leverage from shared procurement, logistics, back-office.

models.name: Construction Digital Twin & BIM Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered digital twin platform that converts BIM models into living project replicas with real-time progress tracking, clash detection, and lifecycle management -- serving the $15.4B BIM market by 2030 and $155B digital twin construction market
models.macro_source: F1: BIM market growing from $9.0B (2025) to $15.4B (2030) at 11.3% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). Digital twin in construction projected to reach $155B by 2030 at 19.0% CAGR. Federal BIM mandate expanding to all projects >$5M.

cla.rationale: Autodesk (Revit, ACC) and Bentley Systems dominate BIM authoring. But the AI layer -- converting static BIM into living digital twins with computer vision progress tracking, automated clash detection, and predictive analytics -- is nascent. Doxel (YC, $45M raised) and OpenSpace ($116M raised) lead AI progress monitoring but haven't closed the BIM-to-twin loop. The opportunity is the INTEGRATION layer: connecting BIM design data to field reality via computer vision, IoT sensors, and AI analytics. Moat advantage is high because training data (thousands of project scans correlated with outcomes) creates compounding accuracy. Value density is strong: $50K-$500K per project for large commercial/infrastructure.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The BIM market is valued at $9.04B (2025) growing to $15.42B by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets, 11.3% CAGR). Digital twin in construction: $64.9B (2025) to $155.0B (2030) at 19.0% CAGR (NextMSC). BIM adoption is ~75% on commercial projects but only ~30% on residential. Federal mandate: all GSA projects >$5M require BIM. 8 states have adopted BIM requirements for public projects. The gap is BIM-to-reality: models are created in design but rarely updated during construction or used in operations. OpenSpace (360-degree photo capture, 2M+ captures) and Doxel (AI progress tracking, claims 'visual intelligence') are proving the computer vision approach. A digital twin platform that maintains BIM-to-field synchronization throughout construction and into facility operations creates a $50K-$500K value proposition per commercial project (reducing rework costs that average $31.3B/year in the US per NIST). The lifecycle operations market (building management using the as-built digital twin) extends the TAM into facilities management ($1.1T globally).
falsification_criteria: Hardware component costs fail to decline on expected trajectory
Software-only solutions prove sufficient, eliminating need for specialized hardware
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8.5B (AI/analytics layer on BIM + digital twin for construction by 2030)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup opportunity is in the analytics/intelligence layer on top of BIM, not BIM authoring itself (Autodesk's moat). Doxel and OpenSpace have proven willingness to pay. Path to $200M ARR by serving 2,000 large commercial/infrastructure projects at $100K average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $50K-$500K for commercial/infrastructure. $5K-$20K for mid-market. Gross margins 70-80%. Hardware capture costs declining (LiDAR on iPhone, $500 360-cameras vs $5K+ 5 years ago). Professional services component ~20% of revenue.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-18 months for enterprise. BIM mandates create regulatory pull. Owner/developer mandates flow to GCs which flow to subs (top-down adoption). IIJA infrastructure spending creates 5-year demand runway.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Training data from thousands of scanned projects creates accuracy advantage. BIM model library for clash detection. Integration depth with Autodesk, Trimble, Bentley ecosystems. Switching costs once embedded in project workflows.

models.sector_name: Administration of Human Resource Programs (Public Health)
models.deep_dive_evidence: COVID exposed fatal gaps in US public health surveillance: CDC received COVID case reports via FAX and manual data entry from states. The $2.1B CDC Data Modernization Initiative (2020-2025) is upgrading infrastructure but progress is slow. 3,006 local health departments (NACCHO 2023) serve 330M Americans — median budget $2.8M, median staff 17 FTEs. 75% still use paper-based or spreadsheet-based disease reporting. Wastewater surveillance, proven during COVID (detecting outbreaks 4-7 days before clinical testing), now covers 1,400+ sites through NWSS but lacks AI-powered analytics at most sites. Hospital data integration: ONC/CMS interoperability mandates (TEFCA) create new data flows but no intelligence layer exists to synthesize them. The INFORMED platform (Innovation Network for Fusion of Real-time Disease Surveillance) at Johns Hopkins APL demonstrated that AI can detect outbreaks 2-3 weeks earlier than traditional reporting. Pharmacy claims data (200M+ prescriptions/month for antivirals, antibiotics, OTC remedies) is a leading indicator that most health departments cannot access. The AI opportunity: integrate disparate data streams (clinical, wastewater, pharmacy, emergency room, school absenteeism) into a real-time surveillance intelligence platform that gives every local health department CDC-level analytical capability.

cla.rationale: The public health data infrastructure is shockingly fragmented: 54 state/territorial health departments and 3,000+ local health departments each run independent surveillance systems, most based on 1990s-era architecture. CDC's BioSense Platform, ESSENCE, and NNDSS are federal backbone systems that are underfunded and under-integrated. Palantir deployed HHS Protect during COVID ($90M+ contract) proving the concept, but the platform was an emergency deployment, not a sustainable product. MO is 6 because the federal layer has incumbent presence (Palantir, IBM, MITRE) but the 3,000 local health departments are essentially greenfield — most use Excel and manual reporting. MA is 8 because longitudinal health surveillance data creates compounding intelligence (each season of flu, each outbreak, each vaccination campaign improves models). DV is 8: post-COVID, every state legislature has funded public health modernization bills.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.8B by 2030 (AI-powered public health surveillance within $9.3B total public health informatics market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Federal level: compete with Palantir and MITRE for CDC/HHS contracts (FORTIFIED). State level: 54 state health departments, $50-500K ACV per state, more accessible via state procurement. Local level: 3,000 health departments, $5-50K ACV, extremely fragmented but ACCESSIBLE. ARPA-H ($6.5B authorized) and CDC ($2.1B DMI) provide large non-dilutive funding opportunities. The local-to-state-to-federal ladder is the scaling path.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Local health department: $2K-$5K/month ($24-60K ACV). State health department: $20K-$50K/month ($240-600K ACV). Federal agency: $1M-$10M/year. Gross margins 75-80%. CDC Data Modernization funds available for qualifying platforms. Implementation requires public health domain expertise (not just engineering).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 3-6 months for local (grant-funded), 6-12 months for state, 12-24 months for federal. Post-outbreak urgency accelerates procurement (COVID demonstrated this). PHAB accreditation requirements create compliance pull. ASTHO and NACCHO conferences are key distribution channels.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Longitudinal surveillance data compounds in value (multi-year baselines for outbreak detection, seasonal adjustment, endemic vs epidemic classification). Multi-jurisdictional data network creates cross-border detection capability. Integration depth with hospital EHR systems, lab information systems, and vital records. Domain expertise in epidemiology and public health practice.

models.falsification_criteria: If CDC Data Modernization Initiative successfully builds a unified national surveillance platform that serves local health departments directly (eliminating the market for third-party platforms). If Palantir expands HHS Protect into a permanent public health intelligence product. If public health funding retracts post-COVID (2024-2025 budget cuts suggest this is already happening in some states). If health data privacy concerns (HIPAA, state laws) prevent the data integration necessary for comprehensive surveillance.

Harvard study tracking 62M workers across 285K firms found junior positions 'shrinking at companies integrating AI.' The cascade: AI automates junior tasks -> companies stop hiring juniors -> 5 years later, no mid-career talent exists -> leadership pipeline collapses. 42% of global employers already expect talent availability to decline 2025-2030 (WEF). This is the 'talent doom cycle' (CNBC). The business model: sell AI-powered career compression that gives workers the equivalent of 5 years of on-the-job judgment training in 12-18 months through simulated client interactions, case study engines, and AI-mentorship systems.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Entry-level hiring decline data: 35% since Jan 2023 (Revelio Labs). India engineering colleges: <25% placement rates. US 22-25 year olds in AI-exposed jobs seeing concentrated employment declines (Stanford Digital Economy Lab). In accounting specifically, Big 4 firms reduced campus recruiting 40-60% while accelerating AI adoption. The 'vacancy chain' mechanism is broken: when a senior leaves, mid-level moves up, but no junior enters at bottom. Current solutions (bootcamps, online courses) teach skills but not judgment. The gap is simulated professional judgment -- navigating ambiguous client situations, making decisions with incomplete information, managing stakeholder politics. AI can simulate these at scale. Revenue model: B2B (employers pay $5-15K/employee for 12-month accelerated development program) + B2C ($2-5K for individual career compression courses). models.name: Optimized Liquid Cooling for Data Centers
models.one_liner: Intelligent direct-to-chip and immersion liquid cooling systems for AI data centers — replacing air cooling that cannot handle 120kW+ GPU racks, serving a $12.5B data center cooling market growing at 20% CAGR as AI compute density doubles annually
models.macro_source: NVIDIA Blackwell GPU TDP 1,000W+ per chip; Schneider Electric and Vertiv data center cooling product roadmaps; Dell'Oro Group data center physical infrastructure forecast; CoolIT Systems, GRC, LiquidCool Solutions deployment data; Microsoft, Google, Meta liquid cooling announcements
models.deep_dive_evidence: AI data center power density is outstripping air cooling physics. NVIDIA's Blackwell B200 GPU draws 1,000W per chip; a rack of 8 GPUs with networking and compute overhead reaches 100-150kW per rack — versus 15-25kW for traditional server racks. Air cooling physically cannot remove 100kW+ from a standard 42U rack without unacceptable airflow velocities and temperature differentials. This is not a preference — it is a thermodynamic constraint. The data center cooling market was $9.2B in 2024 and is projected to reach $25.5B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence, 18.3% CAGR), with liquid cooling specifically reaching $12.5B. Three architectures compete: direct-to-chip (cold plates on CPUs/GPUs with liquid loops — deployed by CoolIT Systems at 4M+ nodes), rear-door heat exchangers (retrofit for existing racks), and full immersion (submerging servers in dielectric fluid — GRC, LiquidCool Solutions). Microsoft deployed liquid cooling across Azure AI data centers in 2024. Google uses liquid cooling for TPU pods. Meta is transitioning to liquid cooling for GPU clusters. NVIDIA mandates liquid cooling capability for Blackwell-based systems. The AI optimization layer is the differentiation: intelligent coolant flow control that adapts to GPU workload patterns (LLM inference has different thermal profiles than training), predictive maintenance using vibration and temperature sensors, and energy optimization that can reduce PUE from 1.3 (air) to 1.05-1.10 (liquid). CoolIT Systems (private, profitable) is the market leader in direct-to-chip but serves primarily hyperscalers — the enterprise and colocation segments remain underserved. Vertiv ($VRT, stock up 400%+ in 2024) and Schneider Electric are developing liquid cooling products but are not yet shipping at scale. The urgency is extreme: data center capacity is the binding constraint on AI scaling, and cooling is the binding constraint on density.
