models.name: Hotel Revenue Management AI
models.one_liner: AI-powered dynamic pricing and demand forecasting for independent and boutique hotels, targeting the $2.2B hotel revenue management system market growing at 15% CAGR to $7.9B by 2034
models.macro_source: Hotel revenue management system market forecasts (multiple sources: $2.19B in 2025 to $7.87B by 2034); QCEW NAICS 7211 (1.78M workers, 67K establishments); STR hotel performance data

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): IDeaS (SAS), Duetto, and Atomize are established RMS vendors for large hotels, and OTAs (Booking.com, Expedia) have built pricing tools. However, independent hotels (67K establishments minus ~20K chain-managed = ~47K independent/boutique properties) are underserved — legacy RMS tools are too complex and expensive ($500-2,000/month). Moat Advantage is strong (7): pricing algorithms trained on property-specific demand patterns compound in accuracy over time — a hotel that has used the system for 2 years gets better recommendations than a new user, creating natural retention. Value Density is high (8): revenue management directly drives topline — a 2-5% RevPAR improvement on a $5M/year hotel is $100-250K, justifying $500-2,000/month fees easily. Demand Visibility is strong (8): hotel operators universally understand revenue management value; the gap is that independent/boutique hotels cannot afford or operate enterprise RMS tools.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7211 (Traveler Accommodation) has 67,147 establishments employing 1.784M workers at $806/week ($41,934 annual). Hotel revenue management system market projected from $2.19B (2025) to $7.87B (2034) at 15% CAGR. Cloud-based RMS now 58% of deployments (up from 35% in 2020). The independent hotel segment is the gap: major chains (Marriott, Hilton, IHG) have proprietary or enterprise-grade RMS systems. But ~47K independent properties (70% of establishments) rely on manual pricing or basic rule-based systems. STR data shows RevPAR recovery to $97 in 2025 (US average), with independent hotels averaging 5-15% lower RevPAR than branded properties — a gap that AI revenue management can close. Hotel hospitality management software market projected to reach $10.55B by 2030 (GlobeNewsWire), with AI-driven personalization as the fastest-growing segment. The LLM revolution enables a new generation of RMS: instead of requiring revenue managers to interpret dashboards, AI can explain pricing decisions in natural language, recommend specific actions, and auto-execute rate changes across OTA channels. This democratizes revenue management for properties without dedicated revenue managers.
falsification_criteria: Open-source or foundation model alternatives eliminate proprietary data moat advantages
Data privacy regulations (state-level CCPA variants) restrict data aggregation business model
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.2B (hotel RMS in 2025, growing to $7.9B by 2034). Independent/boutique hotel segment: ~$700M by 2028.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup targets 2,000-5,000 independent hotels in 5 years. At $800/month average: $19-48M ARR. Category leaders (IDeaS, Duetto) focus upmarket — the mid-market and boutique segment is wide open.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Pure software: 85-90% gross margins. $500-1,500/month ARPU depending on property size. Implementation cost of $1,000-3,000 per property (PMS integration, historical data import). LTV: $24,000 (30+ month retention at $800/mo — revenue management systems are extremely sticky). CAC: $3,000-6,000 (hotel industry conferences, PMS partner channels). LTV:CAC of 4-8x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: 30-60 day proof of value: AI can demonstrate pricing recommendations against actual rates within first month. Revenue lift is directly measurable on monthly P&L. Hotel industry conferences (HITEC, ALIS) provide concentrated buyer access. PMS partnership channels (Cloudbeds has 20,000+ properties, Mews has 5,000+) provide distribution leverage.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Property-specific demand model that improves with historical data creates switching cost (losing 2 years of trained models is painful). Multi-property portfolio optimization (pricing one property relative to competitor properties nearby) creates network-level intelligence. OTA channel management integration (auto-pushing rates to Booking/Expedia/Airbnb) creates workflow dependency.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=predictive_analytics, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $10550M

models.name: Emergency Management & Disaster Response Coordination Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered disaster response coordination platform integrating sensor networks, satellite imagery, social media intelligence, and resource tracking to optimize emergency response across 3,143 US counties — targeting the $9.7B emergency management market by 2030
models.macro_source: F1: Emergency management software market: $6.2B (2025) to $9.7B (2030) at 9.4% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). F6: Climate-driven disasters accelerating — NOAA: 28 billion-dollar weather events in 2023, most in history. $92.9B in total climate-related damage (2023). F3: FEMA budget: $33.4B (FY2025). Stafford Act declarations averaged 60+/year 2020-2025 vs 40/year 2010-2019.
models.sector_name: Justice, Public Order, and Safety Activities (Emergency Management)
models.deep_dive_evidence: The US experienced 28 separate billion-dollar weather/climate events in 2023, the most in recorded history (NOAA). Total damage: $92.9B. 2024 continued the trend with 27 events. FEMA processed 165,000+ Individual Assistance applications for Hurricane Milton alone. The emergency management coordination problem: (1) Multiple agencies (fire, police, EMS, public works, Red Cross, National Guard) must coordinate in real-time without shared situational awareness. (2) Resource allocation is largely manual — emergency managers use spreadsheets and phone calls to track available resources. (3) Damage assessment takes days-to-weeks using ground-based inspection when satellite + drone + AI could provide 90% accuracy in hours. (4) Evacuation modeling uses static assumptions when real-time traffic, road condition, and population density data could optimize routes dynamically. Existing platforms: WebEOC/Juvare (incident management, 3K+ installations), Everbridge ($500M, mass notification), Esri (GIS/mapping, ubiquitous in EM), D4H (operations management). AI startups: One Concern (catastrophe modeling, $130M raised), Carto (geospatial analytics), Maxar/Planet (satellite imagery). The integration opportunity: connecting these point solutions into an AI-native coordination platform that provides predictive situational awareness, not just reactive incident tracking.

cla.rationale: Emergency management technology is fragmented across multiple layers: mass notification (Everbridge $500M revenue, Rave/Motorola), incident management (D4H, Juvare/WebEOC, NC4), GIS (Esri dominates), and decision support (mostly manual). No single platform integrates ALL layers with AI. MO is 6 because Everbridge and Juvare are established but neither has AI-native capabilities. The AI opportunity is in PREDICTIVE response: using historical disaster data, real-time sensor networks, and satellite imagery to predict impact zones, optimize evacuation routes, pre-position resources, and coordinate multi-agency response. DV is 9 because every hurricane, wildfire, and flood demonstrates the need — and climate change ensures increasing frequency. The federal opportunity (FEMA contracts) is moderately contested. State/local emergency management agencies (3,143 county-level plus 19,500 municipal) are accessible but tiny-budget.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.2B by 2030 (AI-specific emergency management within $9.7B total market — predictive analytics, satellite analysis, resource optimization)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: County emergency management agencies: 3,143 counties, most with $100K-$1M EM budgets. State emergency management: 50 states with larger budgets ($5-50M per state EM agency). FEMA: centralized procurement for national systems. BRIC (Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities) grants: $2.3B+ fund pre-disaster mitigation technology. HMGP (Hazard Mitigation Grant Program): $4B+ post-disaster. DHS grants are the primary funding mechanism for local adoption.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: County EM agency: $1K-$5K/month ($12-60K ACV). State EM agency: $10K-$50K/month ($120-600K ACV). FEMA national: $1M-$10M contracts. Gross margins 75-80%. Revenue is lumpy: post-disaster demand surges (6-12 months of urgency after major event) followed by budget normalization.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 3-6 months for county (often using grant funds with spending deadlines). 6-18 months for state. 12-24 months for FEMA. Trigger events: major disaster in region (creates 6-12 month procurement window), FEMA after-action report findings, new BRIC/HMGP grant cycle. IAEM (International Association of Emergency Managers) conference is the primary distribution channel.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Historical disaster data (response times, resource deployments, outcome correlations) creates predictive models that improve with each event. Multi-agency integration (fire, police, EMS, public works data sharing) creates switching costs. Geospatial intelligence trained on specific regions (flood plains, fire risk zones, earthquake zones) creates local accuracy advantages. FEMA integration (IPAWS, NEMIS, Grants Portal) creates compliance moat.

models.falsification_criteria: If FEMA builds a comprehensive national coordination platform through Next Generation Warning System (NGWS) that serves all levels of government. If Everbridge or Juvare successfully adds AI-native capabilities that prevent vertical challengers. If climate-related disaster frequency plateaus (unlikely based on NOAA projections). If budget cuts reduce FEMA and state emergency management funding below levels necessary to adopt new technology.

models.name: Autonomous Warehouse Orchestration Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered multi-robot fleet coordination, dynamic path planning, digital twin simulation, and real-time task allocation software for warehouses deploying heterogeneous automation (AMRs + pick arms + conveyors + humanoids). The 'brain' that makes diverse robots work together.

cla.rationale: MO=5: Manhattan Associates ($1B+) and Blue Yonder ($3.1B, Panasonic-owned) are formidable WMS incumbents with deep warehouse operator relationships. SAP and Oracle have large enterprise footholds. However, AI-native orchestration (multi-robot coordination, real-time re-planning, digital twin) is genuinely new and incumbents are playing catch-up. Market is concentrated for traditional WMS but more open for AI-native orchestration. MA=5: WMS incumbents have moderate moats — deep integrations with existing warehouse systems, long sales cycles that favor incumbents, and data from years of warehouse operations. But their moats are in TRADITIONAL WMS functionality, not in AI orchestration. A pure-play AI-native entrant could bypass legacy WMS competition by targeting the orchestration layer specifically. VD=4: Within orchestration, sub-layers exist: path planning, fleet management, demand forecasting integration, digital twin, task allocation. Some of these (digital twin specifically) could be independent businesses. Moderate depth. DV=6: Disruption vectors: (1) heterogeneous automation creating demand for vendor-neutral orchestration; (2) AI foundation models enabling better real-time planning than rules-based WMS; (3) warehouse complexity exceeding human management capacity; (4) WMS incumbents' legacy architecture making AI integration slow and costly.

vcr.rationale: Warehouse orchestration software. Multi-vendor robot coordination. Pure SaaS, data moat.

falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
General merchandise retail consolidates to 3-4 dominant players, locking out new technology vendors

models.name: Acquire + Modernize Plastics Injection Molding Shop
models.one_liner: Acquire retiring-owner injection molding shops, deploy AI process optimization + robotic part handling, capitalize on sustainability-driven retooling
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW 2023: 12,048 establishments, 599,626 workers at $65,996 avg pay. Employment declining -2.1% while wages rise +4.1% (classic Baumol release). Injection molding is >60% of plastics manufacturing. AI process optimization reduces cycle times 10-20%, scrap 25-40%. Sustainability mandates: California, EU, and 15+ states require recycled content minimums by 2025-2030. Bioplastics market growing 16% CAGR. Retiring owner demographics align with broader manufacturing Silver Tsunami.
models.macro_source: Silver Tsunami + plastics Baumol release (employment -2.1%, wages +4.1%) + sustainability mandates forcing process redesign (recycled content, bioplastics)

cla.rationale: Plastics shows the clearest Baumol release in manufacturing: employment declining 2.1% while wages rise 4.1%. This means the sector is ALREADY automating -- an acquirer accelerates what is happening organically. Injection molding is one of the most automatable manufacturing processes: repetitive cycles, measurable quality parameters, high-volume output. AI process optimization can reduce cycle times 10-20% and scrap rates 25-40%. Sustainability mandates create a retooling wave that favors well-capitalized acquirers over independent operators struggling to reformulate for recycled content.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=acquire_and_modernize, buyer=smb_mid, frag=5, tam_source=sector $800000M→$8000M addressable

models.name: Autonomous Restaurant Operating System
models.one_liner: Unified AI-powered back-office platform for independent restaurants — scheduling, inventory, accounting, vendor management in one system targeting the $14.7B restaurant management software market by 2030
models.macro_source: Grand View Research restaurant management software forecast; QCEW NAICS 7225 (10.95M workers, 611K establishments, $26K avg pay); NRA operator surveys 2025

cla.rationale: Toast dominates restaurant tech at 120K+ locations but charges $69-$165/mo per terminal plus payment processing — leaving massive room for AI-native challengers that compress multiple point solutions. Market Openness is moderate (6): Toast, Square, Clover have distribution but independents remain deeply underserved (only 38% use digital ordering). Moat Advantage is strong (7): data compounding across scheduling, inventory, and accounting creates switching costs once embedded — the restaurant OS becomes the system of record. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-400/mo ARPU from small restaurants with high churn (56-day avg employee tenure mirrors owner turnover). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 611K restaurants with <$3K/year tech spend is the most visible unmet demand in any sector. The gap between chain sophistication and independent capability is the largest technology adoption gap in the US economy.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data confirms 610,970 restaurant and eating places establishments (NAICS 7225) employing 10.95M workers at $502/week ($26,097 annual) — a Baumol score of 0.36, the lowest in the economy. Grand View Research projects the restaurant management software market reaching $14.7B by 2030 from $5.79B in 2024 (17.4% CAGR). The core thesis: independent restaurants (90%+ of establishments) spend less than $3,000/year on technology versus chains spending $15,000-50,000+/year per location. This $12-47K gap per location across 550K+ independents represents a $6.6-25.8B annual technology spend gap. Toast proved the category ($1.2B+ revenue) but charges payment processing spreads on top of SaaS fees — the AI-native entrant can offer a unified OS (scheduling via AI demand prediction, inventory via computer vision waste tracking, accounting via transaction auto-categorization, vendor management via price comparison) at lower total cost by monetizing the software layer rather than payment spreads. The 2022-2023 QCEW data shows establishments growing 2.5% YoY while employment grows 3.5% — new restaurants are opening and hiring, validating continued demand. Average workers per establishment of 17.9 means the buyer is a small-business owner who needs simplicity, not enterprise features.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $14.7B (restaurant management software by 2030, Grand View Research). US-specific serviceable addressable: $4.8B based on 600K+ independents at $8K/year average technology spend potential.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture 2-5% of US independent restaurants in 5 years (12,000-30,000 locations) at $3,600/year ARPU = $43-108M ARR. This is achievable given Toast's 120K location trajectory from 2017-2026. PLG motion with free tier possible for smallest restaurants.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Software-only model targets 75-80% gross margins versus Toast's ~22% gross margin on payments. At $300/mo ARPU, LTV of $3,600 (assuming 12-month avg retention for independents, improving to 24+ months for multi-unit). CAC of $800-1,200 via digital + restaurant supply channel partnerships. LTV:CAC of 3-4.5x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fast adoption cycle: restaurant owners make technology decisions in 1-4 weeks (not enterprise 6-12 months). Monthly billing reduces commitment friction. COVID permanently shifted owner willingness to adopt digital tools. 73% of operators cite labor as #1 challenge — any tool that reduces scheduling pain has immediate pull demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: once the system tracks scheduling patterns, inventory usage, vendor pricing, and financial performance, switching costs increase monthly. Integration with POS/payment/delivery platforms creates ecosystem lock-in. Network effects emerge if vendor marketplace is built (restaurants collectively negotiate better food prices).

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, buyer=smb_mid, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $14700M

models.name: Digital Freight Brokerage & Load Matching
models.one_liner: AI-powered freight matching platform automating the $19.7B US freight brokerage market, targeting the digital brokerage segment growing from $2.0B to $8.4B by 2030 at 27.3% CAGR
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: US freight brokerage market $19.7B (2025) to $28.2B (2030) at 7.4% CAGR. Grand View Research: US digital freight brokerage $2.03B (2024) to $8.42B (2030) at 27.3% CAGR. Digital freight matching platforms projected to reach $47.3B by 2030 at 29% CAGR. Convoy acquired by Flexport (2023). Uber Freight $1.3B revenue. C.H. Robinson $18B gross revenue as largest incumbent.

cla.rationale: Freight brokerage is the most contested digital transformation in transportation. Major digital players: Uber Freight ($1.3B revenue), Flexport ($2.5B, acquired Convoy), Loadsmart (AI pricing), Transfix, Convoy (acquired). Traditional incumbents: C.H. Robinson ($18B), Echo Global, TQL. The market is massive enough that multiple winners can coexist but differentiation is hard. MO is 5 because well-funded competitors abound. MA is 7 because AI matching accuracy improves with data volume -- network effects are real but take years to build. VD is 8 because average broker margin $150-300 per load on millions of loads. DV is 9 because demand is unambiguously proven -- freight moves every day. The opportunity for startups is in VERTICAL specialization: temperature-controlled freight, hazmat, oversize/overweight loads where generic platforms underperform.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US freight brokerage: 17,500+ companies, $19.7B market (2025). 80% of loads still booked via phone/email -- massive digitization headroom. Digital penetration <15% of total freight transactions. Average broker handles 5-8 loads/day manually; AI platforms handle 50-200+. C.H. Robinson: $18B gross revenue, 15% market share, but net revenue margins compressed to 14-16%. Uber Freight: $1.3B revenue, still unprofitable, but AI matching reduces empty miles 15-20%. Convoy failed despite $3.8B valuation -- unit economics matter more than funding. Key insight: the VERTICAL niche strategy works because generic platforms optimize for volume (dry van truckload) while specialized freight (reefer, flatbed, hazmat, LTL) has 2-3x higher margins and less competition. Temperature-controlled freight alone is a $45B US market with fragmented brokerage.
falsification_criteria: Supply-side participants disintermediate the platform through direct relationships
Network effects fail to materialize due to low transaction frequency in the sector
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8.4B digital freight brokerage by 2030 (Grand View Research), with vertical-specialized digital platforms capturing $1.5-3B of that
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture most feasible in vertical niches (temperature-controlled, hazmat, oversize) where generic platforms underperform and margins are 2-3x higher. Must reach 5,000+ loads/month within 18 months to achieve data flywheel. Convoy's failure at $3.8B valuation proves that volume without unit economics is fatal.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Take rate 10-18% on gross freight charges (industry standard). Average load revenue $1,500-2,500 = $150-450 margin per load. At 10,000 loads/month, that's $1.5-4.5M monthly gross margin. Requires scale: fixed costs for platform, sales, and carrier relations are $2-4M/month. Breakeven at ~8,000-12,000 loads/month.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-90 days for shippers (trial with 10-50 loads). Carrier acquisition faster (carriers will try any platform that offers loads). Seasonal demand spikes (Q4 produce, holiday retail) create natural onboarding windows. Fastest adoption among mid-market shippers ($5-50M freight spend) who are underserved by C.H. Robinson and too large for local brokers.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Network effects: more carriers = faster load coverage = more shippers = more loads = more carriers. AI pricing accuracy improves with volume (each completed load refines dynamic pricing model). Specialized vertical knowledge (reefer temperature requirements, hazmat compliance, oversize routing) creates domain expertise that generalists lack.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $45000M

models.name: Government Cybersecurity & Zero-Trust Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered cybersecurity platform purpose-built for government networks, implementing CISA zero-trust mandates, FISMA continuous monitoring, and FedRAMP compliance — targeting the $28.7B government cybersecurity market by 2030
models.macro_source: F1: Government cybersecurity market: $19.8B (2025) to $28.7B (2030) at 7.7% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). AI-specific government cybersecurity: $5.1B (2025) to $12.4B (2030) at 19.5% CAGR. F3: CISA zero-trust mandate (EO 14028) requires all federal agencies to implement zero-trust architecture by 2027. SolarWinds, MOVEit, Change Healthcare attacks demonstrated catastrophic government supply chain risk. F4: Federal cybersecurity spending: $22B+ (FY2025), growing 10-15% annually.
models.sector_name: Executive, Legislative, and Other General Government Support
models.deep_dive_evidence: Federal cybersecurity spending: $22B+ in FY2025, representing the fastest-growing IT category. CISA's CDM (Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation) program is the backbone, with $6.1B+ in contracts to Leidos, Booz Allen, ManTech, and others. Zero-trust mandate (EO 14028, OMB M-22-09): all federal agencies must implement zero-trust by FY2027. As of 2025, <30% of agencies have achieved full zero-trust compliance. FISMA audit findings: 65% of federal agencies have 'significant' cybersecurity weaknesses (IG reports). State/local: 1,900+ cyberattacks on US government entities in 2024 (StateScoop/CyberScoop). 160+ government ransomware incidents. Average ransom demand: $1.5M. Most local governments (population <50K) have zero cybersecurity staff. The AI-specific opportunity: (1) automated threat detection and response (SOAR platforms for government), (2) zero-trust implementation automation (identity verification, micro-segmentation, continuous validation), (3) FISMA/FedRAMP compliance monitoring automation, (4) supply chain risk assessment (monitoring vendor security posture). CrowdStrike leads with $946M government revenue (2025) and LogScale/Falcon platform. Palo Alto Networks expanding Cortex XSIAM for government. Zscaler and Netskope competing for zero-trust SSE contracts.

cla.rationale: Government cybersecurity is the MOST FORTIFIED sub-market in all of GovTech. The federal tier is locked by CrowdStrike ($946M government revenue, IL5 authorized), Palo Alto Networks ($800M+ gov segment), Zscaler (FedRAMP authorized zero-trust), Tenable (CISA CDM program prime), SentinelOne (FedRAMP High), and Mandiant/Google Cloud (incident response). These companies spent 3-5 years and $10M+ each on FedRAMP authorization and have deep integrator relationships. MO is 2 at federal because switching costs are enormous and security clearance requirements create hiring moats. MA is 8 because threat intelligence data compounds (more government networks monitored = better detection). VD is 9 because a single breach costs $9.5M average (IBM 2024) and government breaches trigger congressional investigations. DV is 10: CISA mandates create non-discretionary spending. The state/local opportunity is somewhat more open (MO 5) — many local governments have NO dedicated cybersecurity and are relying on shared services or nothing.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=regulatory_moat_builder, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $12.4B by 2030 (AI-specific government cybersecurity within $28.7B total)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Federal: FORTIFIED. Only viable for companies with existing FedRAMP authorization and cleared workforce. Takes 3+ years and $20M+ to build federal cybersecurity market presence from scratch. State/local: more accessible — MS-ISAC (Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center) provides collective procurement vehicle. Startup path at state/local: managed security services for small governments at $2-10K/month, leveraging cloud AI detection. Scale through state-level cooperative purchasing agreements.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Federal agency: $500K-$10M+ ACV (enterprise cybersecurity platform). State agency: $100K-$1M ACV. Local government managed security: $2K-$10K/month ($24-120K ACV). Gross margins 70-80%. Government payment terms: net 30-60 federal, net 45-90 state/local. Cleared personnel cost: 30-50% salary premium over commercial.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Federal sales cycle: 12-24 months minimum. State: 6-18 months. Local: 3-6 months for managed services. Trigger events: breach incident (within government or peer agency), FISMA audit finding, zero-trust compliance deadline, ransomware attack on peer municipality. DHS grants ($1B+ SLCGP, State and Local Cybersecurity Grant Program) fund local adoption.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: FedRAMP authorization (12-18 months, $1-3M) is the primary moat — only ~340 products authorized. Security clearance requirements (TS/SCI for some government networks) limit workforce. Government-specific threat intelligence (nation-state TTPs targeting government infrastructure) creates unique training data. Integration with government-specific systems (PIV/CAC authentication, CDM sensors, .mil/.gov network architectures).

models.falsification_criteria: If CrowdStrike, Palo Alto Networks, or Zscaler successfully integrates comprehensive AI threat detection that serves all government tiers, preventing vertical entrants. If government cybersecurity budgets flatten or decline (unlikely given threat landscape but possible under deficit-cutting pressure). If the CISA zero-trust mandate deadline extends indefinitely (reducing urgency). If a major AI-security vendor has a catastrophic breach that undermines confidence in AI-powered security for government.

models.name: Harvest Robotics & Autonomous Equipment Fleet
models.one_liner: Autonomous harvest robots for labor-intensive specialty crops (strawberries, leafy greens, apples, table grapes) using computer vision picking and gentle manipulation -- targeting the $18B US fresh produce harvest labor market where 65% of costs are hand labor and H-2A workers are increasingly unavailable
models.macro_source: F1: Ag robotics market $7.2B (2025) to $15.1B (2030) at 16.0% CAGR. Harvest robotics specifically: $1.8B (2025) to $5.4B (2030). F2: H-2A certified positions grew 89% (2017-2023) reflecting domestic labor collapse. Average farm labor wage $17.55/hr (USDA NASS 2024), up 42% since 2019. F3: Immigration enforcement directly threatens 1.0-1.1M undocumented farmworkers -- any disruption cascades to food availability within weeks.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US fruit and vegetable production: $55B farm-gate value (2023). Hand harvest labor accounts for 40-65% of production costs depending on crop (strawberries 65%, leafy greens 50%, tree fruit 55%). Fresh produce farm labor: ~500K workers, of which USDA ERS estimates 50%+ are undocumented. H-2A program: 378K certified positions (FY2023), but processing delays (avg 42 days) and compliance costs ($1,200-$2,000 per worker for transportation, housing, wages) make H-2A expensive and unreliable. California (50%+ of US fruit/vegetable production) faces acute labor shortage: farm employment down 15% from 2012 peak despite rising output. Key harvest robot companies: Advanced Farm Technologies (strawberry harvester, raised $75M, picks 8 berries/second at 80% success rate), Abundant Robotics (apple harvester, shut down 2021 -- cautionary tale), Harvest CROO (strawberry, $60M+ raised, acquired by Yamaha), Tortuga AgTech (greenhouse harvesting), Agrobot (strawberry). The CORE CHALLENGE: biological variability. Unlike a warehouse where items are standardized, each strawberry is different size, ripeness, orientation, hidden by leaves. Success rates of 80-85% are achievable but below the 95%+ needed to fully replace human pickers. Current economics: robot harvester costs $500K-$1M, replaces 10-15 human pickers for 6-month season. At $18/hr all-in labor cost x 10 workers x 1,000 hours = $180K/season labor savings. Payback: 3-6 seasons for purchase, or $15-25K/month for Robotics-as-a-Service. Robots operate 20+ hours/day vs human shifts of 8-10 hours, partially offsetting lower pick rates.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high because no harvest robot has achieved commercial scale -- Abundant Robotics' failure cleared the apple segment, and strawberry/greens remain pre-commercial. Moat advantage is strong because computer vision models trained on millions of crop-specific images create crop-by-crop accuracy advantages (strawberry vision model is useless for apples). Value density is high: replacing $180K/season of labor per unit is compelling. Demand visibility is extreme: every specialty crop grower in California, Florida, and Washington state will tell you labor is their #1 problem.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=robotics_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.0-6.0B (US harvest robotics for specialty crops by 2030, subset of $15.1B total ag robotics)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented, pre-commercial
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: RaaS model: $15-25K/month per robot during harvest season (4-8 months depending on crop/region). Robot COGS: $500K-$1M. Useful life: 5-7 years with annual refurbishment. Gross margins on RaaS: 35-45% (heavy hardware, maintenance, logistics). Per-acre economics: robot harvest cost $2,500-$4,000/acre vs hand harvest $4,000-$8,000/acre for strawberries.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Deploy 25-40 harvest robots across 10-15 large specialty crop operations in California Central Valley and Florida. Focus on ONE crop first (strawberries or leafy greens) to nail the computer vision and manipulation. $150-200K ACV per robot deployment. First $5M ARR in year 3-4 with 30 deployed units. CAPITAL INTENSIVE: requires $20-40M to build initial fleet.

falsification_criteria: If harvest robot pick success rates stall below 85% for delicate crops (strawberries, leafy greens), making them uneconomical vs human labor even at rising wages
If H-2A visa program is expanded and streamlined (processing time cut to 14 days, housing requirements relaxed), reducing the labor scarcity forcing function
If indoor/vertical farming scales for strawberries and leafy greens, moving production into controlled environments where different (simpler) robots are needed

models.name: Public Safety Evidence Management & Analytics Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform for law enforcement evidence management, body camera video analytics, and investigative intelligence — serving 18,000 US law enforcement agencies generating 15PB+ of body-worn camera footage annually within the $22.6B public safety analytics market
models.macro_source: F1: Public safety analytics market: $15.8B (2025) to $22.6B (2029) at 9.4% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). Body-worn camera market: $2.5B (2025) to $4.3B (2030) at 11.4% CAGR. F5: 73% of Americans concerned about AI in law enforcement (Pew 2024). F2: Law enforcement facing recruitment crisis — 50K+ unfilled sworn officer positions nationally; PERF survey shows 47% of agencies below authorized strength.
models.sector_name: Justice, Public Order, and Safety Activities
models.deep_dive_evidence: 18,000 US law enforcement agencies employ 780K+ sworn officers. Body-worn camera adoption: 80%+ of large agencies (250+ officers), 47% of all agencies (BJS 2024). A single officer generates 2-4 hours of BWC footage per shift = 15PB+ annually across US agencies. Less than 1% of this footage is ever reviewed by a human. Evidence management is broken: average homicide investigation involves 500+ evidence items, detectives spend 40% of time on administrative tasks rather than investigation. AI can: (1) automatically transcribe and tag BWC footage, (2) search across millions of hours of video for specific events/objects/people, (3) identify use-of-force incidents for review, (4) surface exculpatory evidence (Brady material) for defense disclosure, (5) cross-reference evidence across cases for pattern detection. Axon Draft One: AI writes police reports from BWC audio — 82% time savings per report. But this is just transcription; investigative analytics are the larger opportunity. The public trust constraint is severe: facial recognition bans in 12+ jurisdictions, predictive policing discontinued in LA, New Orleans, and other cities. Any analytics platform must be built for TRANSPARENCY and ACCOUNTABILITY, not surveillance.

cla.rationale: Axon Enterprise ($2.1B revenue, $20B market cap) dominates body cameras (80%+ market share) and Evidence.com (450K+ users). MO is LOW (3) because Axon's hardware-SaaS flywheel creates enormous switching costs — departments standardize on Axon body cameras and are locked into Evidence.com for storage. Draft One (Axon's AI report writer) launched 2024 and addresses the highest-value use case. However, Axon's analytics layer is still shallow: video search, automatic transcription, and basic tagging. The DEEP analytics opportunity — cross-case pattern recognition, investigative lead generation, exculpatory evidence identification, use-of-force analysis — requires AI capabilities Axon has not built. MA is 8 because evidence databases are deeply proprietary and switching is nearly impossible once ingested. Startups must either partner with Axon (build on Evidence.com API) or target the non-Axon agencies (20% of market). Mark43, Motorola Solutions, and Genetec compete in the broader public safety platform space.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.2B by 2030 (AI-specific analytics within $22.6B public safety analytics market — evidence management, investigative AI, accountability analytics)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Must navigate Axon's dominance: either build ON Axon's API (Evidence.com partner ecosystem) or target the 3,600+ agencies NOT using Axon. Partnership approach is faster but creates platform dependency. Independent approach is harder but defensible. CJIS compliance (FBI Criminal Justice Information Services) is table stakes — requires specific data handling, encryption, and audit capabilities. Path to $100M ARR: 2,000 agencies at $50K ACV.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing: $30-100K/year per agency (scaled by department size). Per-officer pricing: $10-25/month. Hardware required: none (integrates with existing BWC infrastructure). Gross margins 75-80%. Government payment terms (net 45-90 days) create working capital drag.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-18 months (government procurement). Trigger events: high-profile use-of-force incident, consent decree (DOJ pattern-or-practice), new chief of police. COPS Office grants ($500M+ annually) fund technology adoption. Pilot deployments typically 30-60 officers for 90 days.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: CJIS-compliant evidence database creates the deepest switching cost in government technology — agencies CANNOT migrate evidence mid-case. AI models trained on law enforcement-specific scenarios (use of force, pursuit, DUI, domestic violence) require labeled data that is extremely hard to obtain. Cross-jurisdictional pattern recognition improves with each agency onboarded.

models.falsification_criteria: If Axon builds comprehensive AI analytics into Evidence.com, eliminating the gap for third-party analytics layers. If public backlash leads to legislation restricting AI analysis of body camera footage. If the 'defund/reform police' movement reduces agency technology budgets below sustainable levels. If privacy regulations (CCPA, state biometric laws) make video analytics legally untenable.

models.name: Autonomous Wholesale Procurement Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: Aggregate wholesale transaction data across 400K+ distributors to build the Bloomberg Terminal of B2B trade — pricing intelligence, demand signals, and supply chain mapping for $6T in wholesale flows
models.macro_source: F1: AI in supply chain analytics market $10.1B (2025) to $40.5B (2030) at 32% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). F3: Tariff volatility and nearshoring require real-time supply chain visibility. Every transaction through the platform reveals pricing patterns, demand cycles, and supply chain relationships that compound into defensible intelligence.
models.sector_name: Wholesale Electronic Markets and Agents and Brokers
models.deep_dive_evidence: Wholesale trade generates $6T+ in annual transaction volume across 400K+ establishments, yet pricing intelligence remains opaque. Unlike public equities (Bloomberg, $12B revenue) or commodities (Platts/OPIS for petroleum), most B2B wholesale pricing is negotiated bilaterally with no transparent market. Distributors maintain proprietary price books with 50K-500K SKUs, updated manually on spreadsheets or legacy ERP systems. The data compounding thesis: start as an AI-powered procurement tool (price comparison, vendor scoring, demand forecasting) for mid-market distributors. Each transaction processed reveals: (1) real-time pricing across product categories, (2) regional demand patterns, (3) supplier lead time and reliability data, (4) seasonal and cyclical demand curves. At 10K transactions: useful procurement tool. At 100K: predictive pricing intelligence. At 1M+: the definitive B2B wholesale market data platform. Precedent: Faire ($12.4B valuation, wholesale marketplace for independent retail) proved B2B wholesale platforms can reach massive scale. But Faire is retail-wholesale; the industrial/commercial wholesale intelligence layer is unbuilt. ZoomInfo ($6B+ revenue, B2B data for sales) proves enterprise data compounding can reach massive scale.

cla.rationale: Market is open — no wholesale pricing intelligence platform exists at scale. Moat advantage is the strongest of any model in this deep dive: data network effects mean the first platform to aggregate 1M+ transactions becomes nearly impossible to displace. Value chain depth is significant: pricing data, demand forecasting, supplier scoring, risk alerts, and market reports represent 5+ monetizable layers. Demand visibility is moderate — distributors recognize the need for pricing intelligence but may resist sharing their own data to create it.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8B (B2B supply chain intelligence and procurement analytics, wholesale-specific segment ~$2.5B by 2030)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented — no dominant wholesale-specific intelligence platform. Adjacent players: Zilliant (B2B pricing optimization, $100M+ ARR), PROS Holdings ($330M revenue, AI pricing), Vendavo ($150M+ revenue). None focused on cross-distributor data aggregation.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Land with freemium procurement tool ($0-500/month). Expand to intelligence subscription ($2K-10K/month for mid-market, $25K-100K/year for enterprise). Data licensing to financial services, consulting, government: $100K-500K/year per customer. Target: 5,000 distributor customers at $15K ACV = $75M ARR.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Free procurement tool to 500 distributors in Year 1 (target: electrical and HVAC where fragmentation is highest). Convert 20% to paid intelligence tier at $2K/month = $2.4M. Add 100 enterprise customers at $25K = $2.5M. Total ~$5M ARR by Month 18-24.

falsification_criteria: If distributors refuse to share transaction data even anonymized — competitive sensitivity may block data ingestion at the 10K+ transaction threshold
If Amazon Business builds wholesale pricing transparency as a feature, commoditizing the data layer
If incumbent ERP vendors (SAP, Oracle, Epicor, Infor) add sufficient pricing intelligence features to their distribution modules, eliminating standalone demand

models.name: Skilled Trades Workforce Marketplace & Upskilling Platform
models.one_liner: Two-sided marketplace connecting 2M+ specialty trade workers with 540K contractor firms, with embedded skills verification, credential management, and AR-powered upskilling -- addressing the 650K worker shortage in a $130B temporary staffing market where 17.2% of gig workers are in construction
models.macro_source: F2: 650K unfilled construction positions, 77% of firms report hiring difficulty (AGC 2025). F3: Immigration enforcement constraining 24% foreign-born workforce. CSIS analysis: US needs 140K additional electricians, HVAC techs, equipment operators by 2030. Global temp staffing market $130B by 2030 (Spherical Insights).

cla.rationale: No dominant digital marketplace exists for construction labor. Current solutions: (1) Traditional staffing agencies (Tradesmen International, $1.5B+ revenue; PeopleReady) -- high-fee, low-tech. (2) Workrise (formerly RigUp, $500M+ raised) -- primarily oil & gas, expanding to construction. (3) Instawork, Wonolo -- general gig, not construction-specific. (4) Hireup (construction-focused, early). The gap is a construction-native platform with: credential verification (licenses, OSHA cards, drug tests), skill-matching (an electrician is not a plumber), project-based scheduling (not gig-by-gig), and embedded upskilling (AR training for new certifications). Market openness is high because traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup and the 'Uber for construction workers' has not been built. Demand visibility is the highest possible: 650K unfilled positions is not a forecast, it is a measured gap.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction workforce crisis by the numbers: 650K+ unfilled positions (Feb 2026 estimate based on AGC survey + BLS JOLTS data). 77% of firms report difficulty filling hourly craft positions (AGC 2025 Workforce Survey). Average construction worker age 42.5 and rising. Net annual deficit: ~100K workers/year (retirements exceed new entrants). 24% of construction workforce is foreign-born (Pew Research), concentrated in residential (30%+) -- directly exposed to immigration enforcement. Electrician shortage: 80K+ nationally (IBEW). HVAC technician shortage: 45K+. CSIS (Jan 2026): US needs 140K additional skilled trade workers by 2030 just for clean energy and data center construction. Traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup; digital marketplace could reduce to 15-20% while improving matching speed from days to hours. Credential management is a massive pain point: the average specialty contractor carries 15-25 different licenses, certifications, and insurance documents that must be current for each project. An integrated marketplace with embedded credential verification, AI skill-matching, and AR upskilling modules creates a 3-sided platform (workers, contractors, training providers).
falsification_criteria: Supply-side participants disintermediate the platform through direct relationships
Network effects fail to materialize due to low transaction frequency in the sector
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Immigration policy reversal fills labor gaps, reducing demographic pressure on automation

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $22B (construction segment of US temporary/contract staffing, growing at 9% CAGR)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Construction staffing is ~$22B of the $130B US temp staffing market. Platform take rate 12-18% vs traditional agency 30-50%. Path to $500M GMV / $75M revenue in 5 years by serving 50K active workers. Network effects: worker density in a metro creates contractor liquidity.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: GMV per placement: $3-8K/week. Platform take rate: 12-18%. Revenue per active worker: $2-4K/year. CLTV/CAC ratio needs to exceed 3x. Worker acquisition via trade schools, unions, immigration services. Contractor acquisition via demonstrated fill rates.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fastest adoption where shortage is most acute: electricians, HVAC, data center trades. Sales cycle: 1-7 days (contractors need workers NOW). Seasonal variation but data center and infrastructure provide year-round demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Worker credential database (verified licenses, certifications, drug tests, safety records). Network effects (more workers attract more contractors attract more workers). Training content library for upskilling. Reputation/rating system creates trust layer that word-of-mouth lacks.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $130000M

models.name: Sports Fan Engagement & Stadium Experience Platform
models.one_liner: Digital fan engagement, in-stadium experience, and second-screen platform for sports teams and venues — integrating mobile ordering, AR overlays, loyalty, and betting data for the $203K-avg-pay spectator sports sector
models.macro_source: QCEW NAICS 7112 (156K workers, 8.3K establishments, $203K avg pay, 9.3% emp growth); Grand View Research sports analytics ($3.8B in 2024 to $22.1B by 2030, 34.2% CAGR); US sports betting handle $157B+ FY2025; sports media rights deals exceeding $150B
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7112 (Spectator Sports) has 8,309 establishments employing 156,036 workers at $3,911/week ($203,346 annual) — the highest Baumol score (2.80) in NAICS 71, driven by professional athlete salaries. Employment growing 9.3% YoY. Sports Teams and Clubs (711211) is the core: 3,473 establishments, 109,252 workers at $265,815 avg pay — the highest sub-sector wage in the entire NAICS 71 taxonomy. The fan engagement opportunity sits at the intersection of three converging forces: (1) Sports betting integration — 20% of US adults now bet on sports, and in-stadium/second-screen betting creates massive engagement data. Sports betting handle exceeded $157B in FY2025 with 80%+ wagered on mobile. (2) Stadium digitization — mobile ordering (reducing concession wait times 40-60%), AR stat overlays during live games, real-time replays and alternative camera angles on personal devices, and NFC-enabled cashless transactions. (3) Fan data monetization — teams that own first-party fan data (purchase history, attendance patterns, engagement metrics, betting behavior) can dramatically improve sponsorship yield and personalize marketing. Sports analytics market growing from $3.8B to $22.1B by 2030 at 34.2% CAGR (Grand View Research). The existing model card (PC8-FSR-SPORTSTCH-01) covers AI analytics for team performance — this card focuses on the fan-facing and venue-facing experience layer. Key constraint: sports teams are franchise monopolies with concentrated decision-making — there are only ~150 major professional team buyers (NFL, NBA, MLB, NHL, MLS) plus ~350 minor league and college programs.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): the buyer universe is concentrated — ~500 professional teams/venues in the US making centralized decisions. Major incumbents include Fanatics (merchandise + data platform), Legends (hospitality + venue experience), and VenueNext (acquired by Shift4). But no platform integrates fan engagement, mobile ordering, betting data, and loyalty into one stack. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): fan data accumulation and team-specific engagement models create switching costs over seasons, but the core technology (mobile ordering, digital ticketing) is not deeply defensible. Betting data integration is the differentiation layer. Value Density is high (8): professional sports teams generate $200M-1B+ annually per franchise — a 1-3% improvement in fan monetization is $2-30M per team. Demand Visibility is strong (7): every major sports organization is investing in digital fan engagement — the NFL, NBA, MLB, and MLS all have active technology partnerships.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Fanatics ($31B valuation, merchandise + data). Legends (premium hospitality, venues, joint venture with ASM Global). Shift4/VenueNext (stadium payments/POS). Satisfi Labs (AI conversational platform for venues). Betgenius/Sportradar (betting data). No unified fan engagement + betting + commerce + loyalty platform.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Enterprise SaaS + transaction fees: 65-75% gross margins. $200-500K/year per professional team/venue. Transaction-based revenue on mobile ordering (2-5% of GMV) adds $100-500K/year per venue. LTV: $2.1M (3-year contracts at $700K/year blended). CAC: $100-200K (enterprise sales to team CTO/CDO). LTV:CAC of 10.5-21x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 10-15 professional sports teams/venues at $400K/year average. Entry via mobile ordering or betting integration module, expand to full fan platform. Target: mid-market teams (MLS, NHL, minor leagues) before scaling to NFL/NBA. Timeline: 18-24 months.

models.one_liner: Platform enabling rapid development of AI applications built on India's unique digital infrastructure (Aadhaar, UPI, DigiLocker) -- the 890+ GenAI startups need middleware that bridges global AI models with India's 1.4B-person identity and payments layer

The business model: middleware that lets any AI application authenticate via Aadhaar, transact via UPI, and verify credentials via DigiLocker -- turning India's public digital infrastructure into a competitive moat for AI applications serving 1.4B people.

models.name: Robot Fleet Operations & Predictive Maintenance Platform
models.one_liner: Cloud SaaS platform for monitoring, predictive maintenance, performance optimization, and lifecycle management of warehouse robot fleets across multi-vendor deployments. Addresses the $8.7B+ automation maintenance market as robot populations scale to 50K-100K humanoid units plus millions of AMRs.

cla.rationale: MO=8: No dominant standalone robot fleet management platform exists. OEMs bundle basic monitoring but it's single-vendor and primitive. The multi-vendor, AI-powered fleet management market is greenfield. Predictive maintenance platforms (Augury, Uptake) exist for industrial equipment broadly but are not robot-fleet-specific. MA=8: No meaningful moats exist yet. OEM bundling is weak (operators want vendor-neutral tools). No network effects yet (fleet management data is per-customer, not cross-customer). First mover could build data advantage from fleet performance data across many deployments, but this moat doesn't exist yet for anyone. VD=3: Within fleet management, sub-layers (monitoring, predictive maintenance, performance benchmarking, lifecycle planning) are features of a platform, not independent businesses. Shallow value chain. DV=7: Disruption vectors: (1) multi-vendor robot deployments creating demand for vendor-neutral fleet management; (2) humanoid deployment wave creating massive new fleet management demand; (3) IoT/predictive maintenance becoming standard expectation; (4) OEM-bundled tools being single-vendor and inadequate for complex deployments.

vcr.rationale: Robot fleet maintenance SaaS. $8.7B market. Predictive maintenance + fleet mgmt. High margins, recurring.

falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
General merchandise retail consolidates to 3-4 dominant players, locking out new technology vendors

Current HR and operations tools assume 100% human workers. Current AI tools assume 100% AI execution. The hybrid reality needs a new management layer. This is an EMERGING CATEGORY with no NAICS code because the hybrid human-AI workforce did not exist 2 years ago. v2 had staffing destruction models (P-027) but no models for what REPLACES traditional workforce management.
models.macro_source: AI Adoption at Scale + Workforce Transformation

models.name: Fitness & Recreation Center Operating System
models.one_liner: AI-native gym management platform unifying member management, scheduling, retention prediction, and revenue optimization for the 44K-establishment fitness center market with 50%+ annual churn
models.macro_source: QCEW NAICS 713940 (621K workers, 44.1K establishments, $21.5K avg pay); Verified Market Research gym management software ($16.9B in 2024 to $38B by 2032, 14.3% CAGR); IHRSA industry data; ABC Fitness Glofox acquisition (EUR 200M+); Mindbody ClassMonkey acquisition 2025
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 713940 (Fitness and Recreational Sports Centers) has 44,125 establishments employing 620,848 workers at $414/week ($21,530 annual) — the LOWEST average pay in NAICS 71 and among the lowest in the entire economy. This is the employment center of the arts/entertainment/recreation sector: 621K workers across 44K locations, with employment growing 8.1% YoY and establishments growing 2.9%. The gym management software market was valued at $16.88B in 2024, projected to reach $38.05B by 2032 at 14.3% CAGR (Verified Market Research). The sector's structural problem is CHURN: industry average member churn exceeds 50% annually. At Planet Fitness pricing ($10-25/mo), even small churn rate improvements translate to massive revenue impact. AI can predict churn 30-60 days before cancellation based on visit frequency decay, class booking patterns, and engagement signals — enabling proactive retention interventions. The competitive landscape is consolidating rapidly: ABC Fitness Solutions acquired Glofox for EUR 200M+; Mindbody acquired ClassMonkey (15K+ clients) in February 2025. But extreme fragmentation (44.1K establishments) means no player has dominant share. The average fitness center has 14.1 workers — these are small businesses needing integrated operations, not enterprise software. The AI opportunity: automated class scheduling based on demand prediction, dynamic pricing for off-peak hours, personalized member engagement via AI, equipment maintenance prediction via IoT, and integrated billing/payment processing. 68.9M Americans now have gym memberships — an all-time high — validating sustained demand.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): despite Mindbody and ABC Fitness consolidation, no single platform has >15% share of 44K establishments. The market is so fragmented that it supports multiple winners. Boutique studios (Barry's, Orangetheory, F45) have different needs than budget gyms (Planet Fitness, Crunch) and traditional health clubs — creating segmentation opportunities. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): member data and billing integrations create switching costs, but the core product (member management, scheduling) risks commoditization — differentiation comes from AI-powered retention prediction and revenue optimization. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-500/month ARPU from price-sensitive small businesses — fitness center operators watch every dollar. Demand Visibility is proven (9): 44K establishments each needing management software is the definition of visible demand. The ABC/Glofox ($200M+) and Mindbody/ClassMonkey acquisitions confirm category value.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $38B (gym management software by 2032, VMR). US fitness center-specific: ~$6B. AI-powered retention and revenue optimization layer: ~$2B addressable.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Mindbody (wellness-focused, 15K+ clients), ABC Fitness/Glofox (gym-focused, EUR 200M+ acquisition), Zen Planner, PerfectGym, Virtuagym, ClubReady. Market highly fragmented — no dominant player. Planet Fitness uses proprietary systems internally.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: 75-80% gross margins. $300-500/month ARPU for independent gyms, $1,000-3,000/month for multi-location chains. LTV of $5,400 (18-month retention at $300/mo for independents, longer for chains). CAC of $800-1,500 (digital marketing + fitness industry trade shows). LTV:CAC of 3.6-6.8x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 1,000-1,500 gym locations at $350/month average. Target: independent gyms and boutique studios in top 20 metros. PLG motion with free tier for scheduling, upsell to AI retention and revenue optimization. Timeline: 12-18 months.

falsification_criteria: ABC Fitness/Glofox or Mindbody achieve 40%+ market penetration through acquisition roll-up, closing the independent gym management gap
Planet Fitness and other franchise models continue capturing share, reducing the independent gym establishment count below 30K
Gym member churn proves resistant to AI intervention — members leave for lifestyle/motivation reasons that software cannot address

models.name: Smart Municipal Infrastructure Operations Platform
models.one_liner: IoT + AI platform for municipal infrastructure management — water system monitoring, road condition assessment, traffic optimization, and asset lifecycle management — serving 19,500 municipalities managing $4.6T in public infrastructure assets
models.macro_source: F1: Smart city market: $1.3T (2025) to $2.8T globally by 2030 at 16.4% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). Smart water management: $19.8B (2025) to $34.6B (2030) at 11.8% CAGR. F6: US water/wastewater infrastructure needs: $434B over 20 years (EPA). 6M+ lead service lines must be replaced per EPA Lead and Copper Rule. F4: IIJA: $55B for water infrastructure, $110B for roads and bridges, $65B for broadband — the largest infrastructure investment since the Interstate Highway System.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US municipalities manage $4.6T in public infrastructure assets (ASCE 2024 update). Infrastructure grades (ASCE): roads C, bridges C, drinking water C-, wastewater D+, stormwater D. Annual infrastructure spending: $220B+ (federal, state, local combined). Key pain points: (1) WATER: US has 2.2M miles of water distribution pipes, average age 50+ years. 6B gallons lost daily to leaks (14-18% of treated water). 240K water main breaks annually. AI leak detection (Xylem, FIDO, Echologics) can reduce non-revenue water by 30-40%. EPA Lead and Copper Rule requires replacement of 6M+ lead service lines — AI helps prioritize which lines to replace first. (2) ROADS: 4.2M miles of public roads. FHWA estimates $176B annual investment gap for road/bridge maintenance. AI pavement assessment (Roadbotics: $25M raised, uses smartphone cameras on city vehicles to assess road conditions) replaces manual inspection at 10x speed and 1/5 cost. (3) TRAFFIC: AI signal optimization (Google Green Light in 12 cities, Rapid Flow Technologies, SynchroGreen) reduces stop time 10-30% and emissions 10-20%. (4) ASSET MANAGEMENT: Cartegraph (OpenGov subsidiary) and Brightly (Siemens) provide asset management platforms but lack AI-native predictive capabilities. Most municipalities still track infrastructure in spreadsheets or paper records.

cla.rationale: Municipal infrastructure technology is deeply fragmented by asset type: water (Xylem/Sensus, Itron, Badger Meter for metering; Bentley/Autodesk for pipe network modeling), roads (Roadbotics/Michelin for AI pavement assessment, Cartegraph/Brightly for asset management), traffic (Miovision, FLIR/Teledyne for sensors, Iteris for analytics). No platform integrates across all infrastructure types with AI. MO is 6 because each vertical has established players but none provides the unified 'operating system' for municipal infrastructure. MA is 7 because sensor data compounds (years of water pressure readings, pavement condition scores, traffic patterns create predictive models). VD is 7 because infrastructure failure costs are enormous ($1-10M per water main break in large cities, $15-35K per pothole injury claim). DV is 8 because IIJA funding creates a 5-year window of guaranteed infrastructure investment.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $6.8B by 2030 (AI-specific municipal infrastructure management within $34.6B smart water + $15B smart roads + smart traffic markets)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: The cross-infrastructure platform opportunity is large but requires deep domain expertise in each vertical. Most viable path: start with ONE infrastructure type (water is highest-pain, best-funded via IIJA) and expand horizontally. 19,500 municipalities, average water system budget $2-10M for municipalities 10K-100K population. IIJA and EPA grants fund technology adoption. State revolving fund (SRF) loans are the primary financing mechanism for water infrastructure.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Water monitoring: $2-10K/month per municipality (scaled by pipe miles). Road assessment: $5-20K/year per assessment cycle. Traffic optimization: $3-15K/month per intersection cluster. Full platform: $50-200K/year per municipality. Gross margins 60-70% (hardware/IoT sensor component drags margins vs pure SaaS). IIJA-funded projects can absorb premium pricing.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 6-12 months for municipalities (water department directors are pragmatic buyers). IIJA application cycles create procurement windows. State revolving fund disbursements are continuous. EPA consent decrees for water quality violations create urgency. AWWA (American Water Works Association) is the primary water infrastructure distribution channel.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Multi-year sensor data creates infrastructure-specific baselines (pipe pressure norms, pavement degradation rates, traffic patterns by time/weather). Integration with SCADA and utility billing systems creates deep operational lock-in. Geographic density effects: monitoring a water system requires sensors throughout the network — partial deployment has limited value. Cross-infrastructure analytics (correlating water, road, traffic data) creates unique insights that single-vertical competitors cannot match.

models.falsification_criteria: If Siemens/Brightly, Xylem, or Bentley builds a comprehensive AI-native municipal infrastructure platform that prevents cross-vertical challengers. If IIJA funding disbursement is significantly slower than planned, reducing the investment window. If municipalities prove unable to deploy IoT sensors at the density required for AI analytics (capital cost, maintenance, connectivity challenges). If cybersecurity concerns about connecting critical infrastructure (water systems) to cloud platforms prevent adoption.

models.name: Securities Compliance Automation Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered SEC/FINRA compliance for broker-dealers and RIAs -- automate 80% of regulatory reporting at 5x lower cost than compliance staff. SEC 2026 exam priorities targeting AI use creates urgent demand.

structural_drivers: SEC 2026 exam priorities explicitly target AI in advisory -- every RIA must demonstrate AI compliance
SEC enforcing 'AI washing' under Section 206 anti-fraud provisions -- firms must prove AI claims
148K establishments in NAICS 523 need compliance infrastructure, fragmentation means most cannot build in-house
RIA M&A creates compliance complexity as merged firms harmonize regulatory obligations
Compliance staff costs $269K avg -- Baumol 3.71x makes dedicated compliance officers unaffordable for small firms

F1_technology.mechanism: AI parses regulations, auto-generates compliance reports, monitors trading violations, maintains audit trails. NLP/LLM makes regulatory text interpretation production-ready.

F3_geopolitics.mechanism: Cross-border regulatory divergence (US vs EU MiFID II vs UK FCA) creates multi-jurisdiction compliance automation demand.

F4_capital.mechanism: RIA consolidation creates compliance complexity. Fee compression makes compliance cost larger share of revenue -- automation preserves margins.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $20-80K/yr per firm (tiered by AUM and complexity)
unit_economics.cost_advantage: 5-8x vs dedicated compliance staff ($40K platform vs $200K+ compliance officer)

fear_friction.note: Fear of SEC AI examination DRIVES demand. Fear IS the sales trigger. Compliance is non-discretionary.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Legacy regtech (RegEd, ComplySci, COMPLY) serves larger firms. AI-native small-RIA focused: <5 entrants. Analogous to CMMC defense compliance (MC-DEF-011 scored 82.5).
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: 85K+ RIAs + 3,500 broker-dealers + 20K+ fund managers = 108K+ firms. At $40K avg ARR = $4.3B direct TAM. Jevons expansion to unserved micro-advisors = $6B+ total.
deep_dive_evidence.note: Highest composite in securities deep dive at 80.50 but SN 8.0 < 9.0 prevents STRUCTURAL_WINNER classification. Regulatory moat + counter-cyclical demand + highest CE. Also qualifies as TIMING_ARBITRAGE (TG 8.5 >= 8.5 and composite >= 65).

cla.rationale: RegTech market fragmented. No dominant AI-native compliance platform for broker-dealers/RIAs. Legacy compliance tools (NICE Actimize, Broadridge) are heavyweight, not AI-native. SEC/FINRA enforcement increasing. 80% of compliance work automatable. AI can monitor 100% of communications vs legacy 2-5% sampling — 20-50x coverage advantage.

vcr.rationale: Securities compliance automation. 4K broker-dealers. SEC regulatory tailwind. SaaS with regulatory moat.

falsification_criteria: Regulatory framework simplifies or deregulates, eliminating compliance complexity advantage
Incumbent compliance vendors add AI features faster than startups can build regulatory expertise
Interest rate normalization eliminates distress-driven financial services opportunities

models.name: Healthcare Revenue Cycle Automation
models.sector_name: Other Ambulatory Health Care Services (Revenue Cycle Management)
models.one_liner: End-to-end AI platform replacing traditional healthcare operations with automated workflows, from client intake through delivery

deep_dive_evidence.rcm_market: US healthcare RCM market: $250B+ (5-6% of $4.3T healthcare spend). Growing 12% CAGR as healthcare spending increases and payer complexity compounds.
deep_dive_evidence.coding_accuracy: AMA reports average medical coding accuracy of 63-65%. AI coding systems (3M, Fathom Health, Nym Health) demonstrate 88-95% accuracy in peer-reviewed studies. The accuracy gap = $125B+ in annual waste from denials, undercoding, and rework.
deep_dive_evidence.pe_distress_urgency: 30% of US hospitals PE-backed. Median PE healthcare deal leverage: 6.2x EBITDA. Rising interest rates + $930B refinancing wall = immediate cost-cutting pressure. RCM is the largest operational cost line item after labor.
deep_dive_evidence.change_healthcare_aftermath: Feb 2024 Change Healthcare cyberattack disrupted billing for 1/3 of US healthcare transactions. Health systems are actively diversifying RCM vendors — creating the largest market opening in a decade for new entrants.
deep_dive_evidence.competitive_note: Despite 10+ funded competitors, the market is $250B+ and highly fragmented. No single vendor has >15% market share. AI-native entrants target the 'mid-market gap' — too large for manual billing, too small for Optum enterprise contracts.

models.macro_source: Healthcare revenue cycle management is a $250B+ industry processing $4.3T in annual healthcare spending. Coding accuracy rates average 63-65% (AMA), creating $125B+ in annual waste from denials, rework, and undercoding. PE-backed systems entering distress need immediate margin improvement — RCM automation delivers 15-30% cost reduction with zero patient interaction. This is the Baumol cure entry point for healthcare: start with back-office (no trust barrier), prove ROI, expand to clinical adjacencies.

cla.rationale: Healthcare services market has large incumbents (HCA, UHS, DaVita). AI-native full replacement is new. Regulatory moats (licensure, insurance networks) are significant. AI can automate admin (30%+ of costs). Best entry through admin automation, not clinical. Clinical AI requires FDA pathway.

vcr.rationale: Healthcare revenue cycle AI. Massive TAM (140K providers) but slow buyer, complex implementation.

falsification_criteria: Incumbent firms successfully deploy AI internally, eliminating third-party replacement demand

models.name: Semiconductor Test & Packaging Services Platform
models.sector_name: Semiconductor and Other Electronic Component Manufacturing
models.one_liner: AI-optimized semiconductor test and advanced packaging facility serving CHIPS Act fabs -- the capacity bottleneck behind the fab buildout
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW 2023: 3344 (semiconductor equipment/components) has 6,907 establishments, 395,312 workers at $143,228 avg pay. CHIPS Act: $32.5B in grants, $380B+ private investment. 500K jobs across 140 projects. TSMC Arizona ($65B), Intel Ohio ($32B). BUT: 85%+ of global OSAT in Asia. NVIDIA CoWoS packaging bottleneck drives $500B+ orders. Advanced packaging market $44B (2025) growing to $85B+ (2030). Amkor is only major US-based OSAT, primarily operating in Asia. National security case for domestic OSAT is strong.
models.macro_source: CHIPS Act: $630B+ invested, 500K jobs, 140 projects. But fabs produce wafers -- test & packaging (OSAT) is the bottleneck. 85%+ of global OSAT capacity is in Asia. Reshoring test/packaging is the next CHIPS Act wave.

cla.rationale: This is the structural bottleneck behind the CHIPS Act buildout. TSMC Arizona and Intel Ohio fabs will produce wafers, but 85%+ of test and packaging capacity is in Asia. AI-optimized test (reducing test time and cost per die) plus advanced packaging (chiplets, 2.5D/3D integration) are the highest-value portions of the semiconductor supply chain after design and fabrication. Capital barriers are HIGH (MO=5) and incumbents are entrenched (MA=4), but the STRUCTURAL NECESSITY is extreme: you cannot have a domestic semiconductor supply chain without domestic OSAT. CHIPS Act Round 2 funding will target this.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=physical_production_ai, buyer=enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $500000M

Reshoring momentum reverses as tariff policy changes eliminate onshoring economic rationale

models.name: Micro-Fulfillment & Dark Store Automation
models.one_liner: Turnkey micro-fulfillment center technology (robotics + software + deployment) enabling sub-2-hour delivery for grocery and convenience in the $7.3B micro-fulfillment market growing at 38% CAGR to $46B by 2030
models.macro_source: LogisticsIQ: micro-fulfillment center market $7.3B (2025) growing at 38% CAGR. Allied Market Research: dark store market $17.5B (2024) to $117.7B (2032) at 27.5% CAGR. Grocery e-commerce now 12-15% of total grocery sales (up from 3% pre-COVID). Same-day grocery delivery demand: 42% of consumers use weekly. Major deployments: Walmart (6,500+ pickup locations), Kroger (Ocado partnership), Instacart Caper carts.

cla.rationale: Micro-fulfillment is contested by well-funded players: Ocado (Kroger partnership, $2B+ invested), AutoStore (cube storage), Fabric/CommonSense Robotics (acquired by Walmart), Alert Innovation (acquired by Walmart), Takeoff Technologies, Dematic. However, most solutions are either (1) massive and expensive ($5-50M per installation for Ocado/AutoStore) or (2) acquired by a single retailer (Walmart buying Fabric and Alert Innovation). The opportunity for a TURNKEY mid-market solution ($500K-2M per installation) serving independent grocers, convenience chains, and specialty retailers remains open. MO is 5 because large players are spending billions. But the mid-market (independent grocers, regional chains, non-food retailers) is underserved by enterprise solutions.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US grocery e-commerce: $120B+ (2025), 12-15% of total grocery sales. Same-day delivery demand: 42% of consumers use grocery delivery weekly (vs 18% pre-COVID). Last-mile delivery from central warehouses is unprofitable for most grocers (average cost $10-15 per order). Micro-fulfillment centers (3,000-10,000 SF, inside or adjacent to existing stores) can fulfill orders in 5-10 minutes for $2-4 per order. Walmart: deployed micro-fulfillment in 6,500+ locations. Kroger: Ocado partnership for large automated fulfillment centers ($55M each). The GAP: 40,000+ independent grocery stores and regional chains in the US cannot afford $5-50M Ocado-style automation. A turnkey solution at $500K-2M that can be deployed in 4-6 weeks inside an existing store is the mid-market opportunity. AutoStore cube storage + picking robotics + order management software as an integrated package. Dark stores (dedicated fulfillment locations, no walk-in customers) growing 27.5% CAGR for pure-play delivery services.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Warehouse automation ROI fails to justify capital expenditure for mid-size operators
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.0-8B by 2030 (mid-market micro-fulfillment technology targeting 40K+ independent grocers and regional chains at $100-200K average annual technology spend)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible but requires hybrid model: hardware (robotics) + software (order management, inventory optimization) + deployment services (4-6 week installation). Capital requirements are moderate ($5-10M to develop turnkey solution). Must demonstrate payback within 18 months (order fulfillment cost reduction from $12 to $3-4 per order). Best entry: partner with existing grocery tech distributors for channel access.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Hardware + installation: $500K-2M one-time. Annual software/maintenance: $60-120K. Hardware margins 25-35%, software margins 80%+. Blended gross margin 45-60%. For a grocer doing 500 delivery orders/day, cost drops from $6,000/day (manual picking) to $1,500-2,000/day (automated) = $4K/day savings = 6-12 month payback.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 3-6 months for regional chains, 6-12 months for larger independents. Pilot with 1 store, then expand to chain. Seasonal grocery delivery peaks (holidays, back-to-school) create urgency. COVID-era delivery infrastructure investments reaching end-of-life, creating replacement cycle opportunity.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Installed base creates switching costs (physical robotics in-store). Inventory optimization AI improves with more SKU/order data from each store. Deployment expertise (having installed in 50+ stores reduces per-store deployment time and cost). Integration with grocery POS and inventory systems creates operational stickiness.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=robotics_automation, buyer=enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $120000M
