models.name: Construction Robotics Fleet Platform
models.one_liner: Robotics-as-a-service platform deploying task-specific construction robots (bricklaying, rebar tying, drilling, finishing) to trade contractors facing 650K worker shortages -- targeting the $3.5B construction robotics market by 2030 at 17.5% CAGR
models.macro_source: F1: Construction robotics market $1.12B (2024) to $3.5B (2030) at 17.5% CAGR (Grand View Research, Strategic Market Research). F2: 650K unfilled construction positions, avg worker age 42.5. Robots fill positions that CANNOT be filled by humans who do not exist.

cla.rationale: Construction robotics is early-stage with no dominant platform. Current players are task-specific: FBR (Hadrian X bricklaying, ASX-listed), Advanced Construction Robotics (TyBot rebar tying), Hilti (Jaibot drilling), Canvas (drywall finishing), Dusty Robotics (layout). Boston Dynamics and Figure are humanoid but not construction-focused. Market openness is HIGH because no one has built the fleet management / RaaS platform layer yet. Each robot manufacturer sells directly. The platform opportunity (manage multiple robot types across jobsites, handle logistics, training, maintenance) is unoccupied. Moat builds through multi-vendor integration, deployment data, and contractor relationships. Value density is high: a bricklaying robot replaces 3-4 masons at $80K+/year each.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction robotics market: $1.12B (2024) to $2.76B-$3.66B (2030) depending on source (Strategic Market Research, Grand View Research). Key deployed systems: Hadrian X (lays 200 blocks/hour vs 300-500/day for human mason), TyBot (ties rebar autonomously, deployed on 50+ bridge projects), Hilti Jaibot (autonomous overhead drilling, 400+ deployments), Canvas (drywall finishing robot, 1M+ SF finished), Dusty Robotics (BIM-to-layout robot, 10,000+ layouts). NVIDIA Jetson compute ($1,999) and declining sensor costs (LiDAR from $10K to $500) are reducing robot unit economics. BUT adoption is extremely early: <500 construction robots deployed across US jobsites in 2025. The constraint is not technology but deployment complexity: every jobsite is different, robots need human supervisors, weather/terrain variability high. RaaS model ($5-15K/month per robot) lowers the capital barrier for contractors who won't spend $150-500K on a robot purchase.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected

models.name: Agricultural Carbon Credit Verification & Trading Platform
models.one_liner: MRV (measurement, reporting, verification) platform using remote sensing, soil sampling protocols, and biogeochemical modeling to generate and trade agricultural carbon credits -- bridging the trust gap in the $500M-$1B voluntary ag carbon market where verification costs consume 30-40% of credit value
models.macro_source: F6: Voluntary carbon market for agriculture: $500M-$1B (2025), projected $3-5B by 2030 as corporate net-zero commitments accelerate. F4: Carbon credit prices volatile ($8-35/ton, ag soil carbon at low end) creating both risk and upside. F1: Satellite-based MRV (remote sensing + ML models) reduces per-field verification cost from $15-25/acre to $3-8/acre.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Voluntary carbon markets (all sectors): $2B globally (2024), down from $2.7B peak (2021) due to quality concerns (Verra, Gold Standard integrity questions). Agricultural soil carbon is the MOST CONTESTED carbon credit type because: (1) soil carbon sequestration is real but highly variable (0.2-1.5 tons CO2e/acre/year depending on practice, soil type, climate), (2) permanence is uncertain (tillage releases stored carbon), (3) measurement is expensive ($15-25/acre for physical soil sampling at 2.4 cores/acre). Key ag carbon platforms: Indigo Ag Carbon (1.6M enrolled acres, but <200K credits actually issued -- gap between enrollment and verification is the #1 problem), Nori ($30M+ raised, blockchain-based registry), Bayer Carbon Program (paying $3-9/acre for verified practices), Corteva Carbon Initiative. The CORE PROBLEM: verification costs consume 30-40% of credit value at current soil carbon prices ($8-15/ton). A $12/ton credit on 0.5 tons/acre = $6/acre revenue, minus $4-8/acre verification cost = negative or near-zero farmer payment. Solution: satellite-based MRV using Sentinel-2 multispectral, ECOSTRESS thermal, and SAR data combined with biogeochemical models (DNDC, DAYCENT) can reduce verification costs to $3-8/acre while maintaining acceptable uncertainty bounds. Regrow Ag ($55M raised) and Perennial are building these ML-based MRV systems. If verification costs drop below $3/acre AND carbon prices rise above $25/ton (both plausible by 2028), the ag carbon market becomes viable at scale.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high because no platform dominates MRV for ag carbon -- Indigo enrolled 1.6M acres but issued <200K credits, proving the gap. Moat builds through satellite model accuracy (trained on verified soil sampling data) and registry relationships. Value density is LOW at current carbon prices ($6-15/acre/year) but could 3-5x if prices reach $25-40/ton. Demand visibility is moderate: corporate net-zero commitments drive buyer demand, but buyer willingness to pay for ag credits (vs cheaper alternatives like avoided deforestation) is uncertain.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $500M-$1.5B (agricultural carbon credit verification and trading, US + global, by 2030)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented, early-stage
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Platform take rate: 15-25% of credit value. At $15/ton average and 0.5 ton/acre: $7.50/acre credit value, $1.50-1.88/acre platform revenue. Need 5M+ verified acres to reach $7.5M revenue. Verification cost: $3-8/acre (satellite-based MRV). Gross margins 50-65% depending on ground-truthing requirements.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Enroll 3-5M acres of row crops in cover crop/no-till programs. Generate and verify 1.5-2.5M tons of carbon credits. Sell at $12-20/ton with 15-20% platform fee. Requires partnership with 10-20 major crop input retailers or co-ops for farmer enrollment. First $5M ARR in year 3-4. Risk: carbon price volatility could extend timeline significantly.

If soil carbon permanence studies show reversal rates above 20% within 5 years of practice change, undermining the entire credit methodology
If compliance carbon markets (cap-and-trade) incorporate agriculture, making voluntary markets redundant for ag carbon

models.name: Oilfield Services Predictive Maintenance & Downhole Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform for predictive maintenance of artificial lift systems, wellbore integrity monitoring, and downhole sensor analytics — targeting $12B+ US artificial lift market where rod pump failures cost operators $50-200K per event and 750,000+ US wells use some form of artificial lift
models.macro_source: EIA: 750,000+ US wells use artificial lift (rod pump, ESP, gas lift, plunger lift). Rod pump systems on 500,000+ US wells. Average rod pump failure interval: 18-24 months. Average rod pump failure cost: $50-200K (workover rig, lost production, replacement parts). US artificial lift market: $12B+ annually. Submersible pump (ESP) market: $3.5B by 2030. Permian Basin alone operates 180,000+ horizontal wells, majority requiring artificial lift within 12-24 months of completion. Field service technician average age: 47. Pump-off controllers installed on <30% of wells with smart monitoring capability.
models.sector_name: Support Activities for Mining — Oil & Gas Field Services
models.deep_dive_evidence: Artificial lift is the most maintenance-intensive component of oil and gas production. After initial flowback, unconventional wells (horizontal wells with hydraulic fracturing) decline rapidly — 70-80% production decline in year one — and require artificial lift to continue producing. 83% of US wells use some form of artificial lift. Rod pumping (beam pumps, 'pump jacks') is the most common method, installed on 500,000+ US wells. The average rod pump operates for 18-24 months before failure (rod part, tubing leak, pump wear). Each failure requires a workover rig ($20-50K/day), replacement parts ($10-30K), and causes production downtime ($5-50K in lost revenue). Total failure cost: $50-200K per event. Across 500,000+ rod pump wells, this represents a $15-50B annual maintenance and failure cost burden. Current monitoring: most rod pump wells have basic pump-off controllers (POCs) that shut down the pump when the well 'pumps off' (no fluid to lift). Advanced controllers from ChampionX, Lufkin (Baker Hughes), and Weatherford collect dynamometer cards (load vs position curves) that reveal pump condition. BUT: (1) <30% of wells have smart POCs capable of data transmission, (2) data from different controller vendors is incompatible, (3) analysis of dynamometer cards is typically done manually by technicians who are retiring in large numbers (average age 47). The AI opportunity: (1) Install IoT edge devices on existing rod pump motors to collect vibration, current, and load data without replacing the pump controller ($500-2,000 per well vs $5-15K for full controller replacement). (2) Apply ML to predict rod part, tubing leak, and pump wear 2-6 weeks before failure — enabling scheduled workovers (cheaper, less production loss) vs emergency workovers. (3) Optimize pump settings (stroke length, pumping speed) to maximize production while minimizing wear. Companies: Ambyint (AI rod pump optimization, acquired by Ovintiv for internal use), Kelvin (AI artificial lift optimization, 5-15% production increase claimed), Silverwell (ESP monitoring), Weatherford (ForeSite production optimization platform). The competitive landscape is fragmented because OFS companies are hardware-first (they want to sell pumps, not analytics) and E&P companies are building internal capabilities (ConocoPhillips, Devon, Pioneer/ExxonMobil have internal data science teams).

cla.rationale: MO is 5 because major OFS companies (SLB, Halliburton, Baker Hughes, ChampionX) have artificial lift product lines and are building digital monitoring capabilities. ChampionX (formerly Apergy) is the largest pure-play artificial lift company ($3.8B revenue). BUT their monitoring platforms are hardware-locked (you buy ChampionX rod pump controllers to get ChampionX analytics). MO opens for a hardware-agnostic analytics platform that works across vendors. MA is 7 because pump failure pattern data compounds — ML models trained on 100,000+ pump failure events across different formation types, pump configurations, and operating conditions significantly outperform single-well diagnostic models. VD is 8 because preventing one rod pump failure saves $50-200K in workover costs plus $20-100K in lost production. DV is 7 — artificial lift is essential for 83%+ of US wells (all wells that don't flow naturally require some lift method).

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $12B+ US artificial lift market (hardware + services). Predictive maintenance/optimization software layer: $1.5-3B by 2030 (estimated 12-25% of artificial lift value shifts from reactive repair to predictive software). Direct addressable: 500,000+ rod pump wells x $1-5K/year analytics subscription = $500M-2.5B.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in the mid-market gap: too small for SLB Delfi, too sophisticated for spreadsheet tracking. Target independent operators with 50-500 rod pump wells who lack internal data science capability. Hardware-agnostic approach (work with any pump controller or add IoT edge device) differentiates from OFS-locked platforms. Ambyint's acquisition by Ovintiv (E&P company) validates the technology but removes it from the commercial market, creating opportunity.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $100-500/well/month for predictive maintenance + production optimization. IoT hardware (edge device): $500-2,000 per well upfront or bundled in subscription. 5,000-well deployment = $6-30M ARR. Gross margins 65-75% (IoT hardware + cloud analytics). Customer payback: preventing 1 rod pump failure per year per 10 wells = $50-200K saved vs $12-60K annual platform cost for 10 wells — 3-5x ROI. Fast payback (90-day proof of value).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Permian Basin well count increasing (180,000+ horizontal wells) but workforce not growing — operators need technology to maintain wells without proportionally more field technicians. Average well age increasing (wells drilled in 2018-2020 are now in high-maintenance phase). PE-backed operators managing acquired portfolios need standardized monitoring across heterogeneous assets. Field technician retirement (average age 47) accelerating knowledge loss — AI captures diagnostic expertise.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Pump failure prediction data compounds: each confirmed failure event (rod part, tubing leak, pump wear) labels training data that improves the model. Cross-operator, cross-basin learning (anonymized failure patterns from Permian apply to Bakken with adjustment) creates data network effects. Hardware-agnostic integration (works with ChampionX, Lufkin, Weatherford controllers + proprietary IoT edge devices) avoids OEM lock-out. Formation-specific models (Wolfcamp A/B/C pump performance differs from Bone Spring) create geological specialization.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) ChampionX, Baker Hughes, or Weatherford make their artificial lift analytics platforms hardware-agnostic, closing the integration gap; (2) Oil prices decline below $45/bbl sustained, eliminating workover budgets for marginal wells (operators let wells die rather than repair); (3) E&P companies refuse to share well-level production data with third-party platforms due to competitive concerns; (4) ESP (electric submersible pumps) replace rod pumps as the dominant lift method in unconventional wells, requiring different sensor and analytics approaches that make rod pump-focused platforms less relevant.

models.name: HVAC/Plumbing Distribution Acquire-and-Modernize Platform
models.one_liner: Acquire retiring HVAC/plumbing distributors in the $120B market, deploy AI-driven inventory management and electrification product expertise as heat pump mandates reshape 50% of the product mix by 2030
models.macro_source: F2: HVAC/plumbing distribution — average owner age 62, Winsupply (700+ locations) proves rollup model. F6: Heat pump mandates in 9 states require distributors to carry and advise on new product categories; 70% of independent HVAC distributors report inadequate knowledge of heat pump systems (HARDI 2025 survey). F4: PE firms paid 7-10x EBITDA for HVAC distribution assets in 2024-2025.
models.sector_name: Professional and Commercial Equipment Merchant Wholesalers (HVAC/Plumbing)
models.deep_dive_evidence: HVAC and plumbing distribution is a $120B+ market within the broader NAICS 4234 (professional/commercial equipment wholesale). Key players: Winsupply ($7B revenue, 700+ locations — the proof case for HVAC/plumbing rollup), Ferguson Enterprises ($30B, plumbing and HVAC #1), Hajoca ($3B, plumbing), Johnstone Supply ($4B+, HVAC co-op), and RE Michel ($2B+, HVAC). Below the majors: 15,000+ independent HVAC and plumbing distributors, typically single-location operations with $2-15M revenue. The electrification transition is the structural catalyst: 9 states now mandate heat pumps in new residential construction. The DOE Inflation Reduction Act provides $8.8B in HOMES/HEEHRA rebates for heat pump installation. Heat pump shipments in the US grew 21% in 2023 (AHRI data). This means HVAC distributors must: (1) stock an entirely new product category (cold-climate heat pumps, mini-splits, VRF systems), (2) provide technical training to contractor customers on heat pump installation, (3) manage dual inventory (legacy fossil + electrification products) during the transition. Independent distributors with 62-year-old owners and 30 years of gas furnace expertise cannot navigate this transition alone. An acquire-and-modernize strategy: buy retiring distributors at 5-7x EBITDA, deploy AI inventory management (predict heat pump vs gas furnace demand by geography, building code, and weather), and build electrification product expertise as a competitive moat. Winsupply's model (local autonomy with shared services) demonstrates this works at 700+ locations.

cla.rationale: Market is open — 15K+ independent HVAC/plumbing distributors with Silver Tsunami ownership demographics. Winsupply and Ferguson are large but fragmented market still has decades of consolidation runway. Moat advantage is strong: electrification product expertise (heat pumps, VRF, mini-splits) combined with local contractor relationships creates a differentiated value proposition vs commodity-only distributors. Value chain depth is moderate — distribution, inventory, training, and installation support. Demand visibility is excellent: HVAC distribution is essential, recurring (contractors need parts daily), and growing via electrification mandates.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=acquire_and_modernize, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented — Ferguson ($30B), Winsupply ($7B), Hajoca ($3B), Johnstone Supply ($4B). Long tail of 15K+ independents. Consolidation is early: top 10 hold ~35% share.

vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Not SaaS — distribution revenue model. Path to $100M revenue: acquire 8-10 branches at $8-15M revenue each within 18 months. $40-80M equity raise, 2-3x leverage. Electrification expertise creates organic growth on top of acquired revenue base (15-25% of product mix shifts to higher-margin heat pump products within 24 months of acquisition).

falsification_criteria: If Ferguson Enterprises or Winsupply accelerate acquisition pace to 50+ per year, crowding out independent acquirers with balance sheet advantage
If heat pump adoption stalls due to cold-climate performance concerns, grid capacity constraints, or political reversal of electrification mandates

models.name: Municipal Digital Permitting & Zoning Automation Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform automating building permit review, zoning compliance checking, and inspection scheduling for 19,500+ US municipal jurisdictions — reducing the average commercial permit from 6-12 months to 2-4 months within the $6.3B digital permitting market
models.macro_source: F1: Digital permitting market: $2.8B (2025) to $6.3B (2030) at 17.6% CAGR (Allied Market Research). 19,502 municipal jurisdictions in the US (Census of Governments). Average commercial building permit: 6-12 months. NAHB estimates permit delays add $32,000 to the cost of a new single-family home. F5: Building departments are among the most change-resistant government units — inspectors have decades of tacit knowledge and resist AI review.
models.sector_name: Administration of Housing, Urban Planning, and Community Development
models.deep_dive_evidence: 19,502 municipal jurisdictions in the US, each responsible for building permits, zoning compliance, and inspections. The permitting process is the single largest government friction point for the private sector: NAHB estimates regulatory costs (including permitting delays) account for 23.8% of single-family home prices ($93,870 on a $394,300 home). Average time for a commercial building permit: 6-12 months. Residential: 2-4 months. Each permit application involves plan review against 50+ code sections (structural, fire, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, energy, accessibility, zoning). Plan review is 90%+ a code-compliance-checking exercise — exactly the kind of rule-based cognitive task where AI excels. AI plan review (companies like Novade, Autodesk, TestFit) can check code compliance in hours vs weeks. Inspection scheduling optimization (using ML to predict inspection readiness and route inspectors efficiently) can increase inspector productivity 30-40%. Current state: ~20% of US jurisdictions have any digital permitting. 80% still use paper applications, PDF plan submissions reviewed on screen, and manual scheduling. The housing affordability crisis creates political pressure for faster permitting. California (SB 423), Minnesota (statewide zoning reform), and 15+ states have passed legislation to streamline local permitting. Each legislative mandate creates demand for technology to implement compliance.

cla.rationale: The digital permitting market is ACCESSIBLE due to extreme fragmentation: 19,500 municipal jurisdictions, each with independent purchasing. No single vendor has >5% market share. Existing players: Accela ($200M+ revenue, legacy on-premise being pushed to cloud), Tyler Technologies (EnerGov — included in broader Tyler suite), OpenGov ($150M+, cloud-native budgeting + permitting), PermitFlow (YC startup, ~200 municipal deployments), GovBuilt (cloud permitting for smaller municipalities). MO is 7 because no dominant player and thousands of municipalities still use paper/PDF. MA is 7 because AI plan review models trained on local building codes (each municipality has unique amendments to ICC codes) create local moats. DV is 9 because every builder, developer, and homeowner experiences permit friction — demand is universal and visceral. The NIMBY/YIMBY political dynamic creates additional urgency: housing supply advocates pushing for faster permitting.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $6.3B by 2030 (total digital permitting market — AI-specific plan review and automation is $2-3B subset)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: WIDE OPEN for startups due to extreme fragmentation. Path: start with small/mid-size municipalities (population 10K-100K) that have no digital system. Land 200-500 municipalities, then move upmarket to larger cities. PermitFlow model: charge per permit application ($15-50/permit) for volume-based economics, or $500-$5K/month SaaS for smaller municipalities. No FedRAMP required — municipal procurement is simpler than federal.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Per-permit pricing: $15-50/permit application. SaaS pricing: $500-$5,000/month for small-mid municipalities, $10K-$50K/month for large cities. Average ACV: $15K (small), $120K (mid), $500K (large city). Gross margins 80%+. Implementation: 30-90 days for basic permitting portal, 6-12 months for AI plan review with local code customization.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 30-90 days for small municipalities (often single decision-maker), 6-12 months for mid-size cities, 12-24 months for large cities. Housing affordability crisis creates political urgency. State permitting reform mandates create compliance demand. ICMA and NLC conferences are key distribution channels. Word-of-mouth among city managers is the primary referral mechanism.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Local code customization (each municipality's amendments to ICC codes) creates per-jurisdiction configuration moat. Historical permit data (plan review outcomes, inspection pass rates, violation patterns) trains local AI models. Integration with GIS, tax assessment, and utility systems creates workflow lock-in. Network effects: contractors who learn one system push other municipalities to adopt it.

models.falsification_criteria: If Accela or Tyler Technologies successfully launches AI plan review that satisfies municipal customers, consolidating the fragmented market before challengers scale. If municipalities resist AI plan review due to liability concerns (who is responsible if AI approves a structurally deficient plan?). If housing construction slowdown reduces permit volume, decreasing urgency for permitting modernization. If state preemption of local zoning authority reduces the number of jurisdictions making independent permitting decisions.

models.name: Farm-to-Fork Traceability & FSMA Compliance Platform
models.one_liner: Blockchain-anchored traceability system tracking produce from field to retail shelf with FSMA 204(d) compliance automation, lot-level recall capability in <24 hours vs the current 7-14 day industry average -- serving 45,000+ FDA-registered produce farms under the 2026 FSMA traceability rule
models.macro_source: F3: FDA FSMA Rule 204(d) (Food Traceability Final Rule) requires traceability records for high-risk foods effective Jan 2026 -- 45,000+ farms, packers, distributors must comply. F1: IoT sensors + blockchain reduce traceability record-keeping from 40+ hours/week manual effort to automated capture. F5: Consumer trust in food safety at 10-year low after 2023-2025 romaine/onion recalls.
models.deep_dive_evidence: FDA FSMA Section 204(d) Traceability Rule: effective January 20, 2026, requires additional traceability records for foods on the Food Traceability List (FTL). FTL includes: leafy greens, tomatoes, peppers, melons, sprouts, tropical tree fruits, fresh herbs, shell eggs, nut butters, fresh-cut fruits/vegetables, finfish, crustaceans, molluscan shellfish, and ready-to-eat deli salads. Affected entities: ~45,000 farms + 175,000 packers/distributors/retailers. Compliance requires: Key Data Elements (KDEs) at each Critical Tracking Event (CTE) -- essentially, who had what lot of food, when, where, and what they did with it. Current industry state: 80%+ of small/mid-size farms use paper-based or spreadsheet traceability. Average recall response time: 7-14 days to trace contaminated product to source (2023 FDA recall data). Target: <24 hours source identification. Key players: FoodLogiQ (acquired by Controlant, $100M+), Trustwell (FoodLogiQ parent), IBM Food Trust (blockchain, largely abandoned by IBM), Walmart/Hyperledger (mandated blockchain traceability for leafy greens suppliers in 2023). Startup opportunity: GS1-compliant traceability SaaS for the 45K farms that MUST comply by Jan 2026 but lack any digital system. At $200-$500/month per farm, the immediate compliance TAM is $108M-$270M/year. Expand to packers/distributors for $500-$2,000/month: $1.05B-$4.2B addressable.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high because 80%+ of affected farms have no digital traceability system and the Jan 2026 deadline is imminent. FoodLogiQ/Controlant focuses on enterprise food companies, not farms. Walmart mandated its own system but only for Walmart suppliers. Moat advantage is moderate: GS1 compliance is standardized, so differentiation comes from ease-of-use for non-technical farm operators and integration breadth (connect to multiple downstream buyers). Value density is moderate per farm ($200-500/month) but the regulatory mandate creates inelastic demand. Demand visibility is the HIGHEST of any ag model: it is literally a federal compliance deadline.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $800M-$2.0B (food traceability software for farms + packers/distributors affected by FSMA 204(d) and retailer mandates)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Farm tier: $200-$500/month ($2,400-$6,000 ACV). Packer/distributor tier: $500-$2,000/month ($6,000-$24,000 ACV). Gross margins 80%+. CAC: low for compliance-driven sales (farmers seeking out solutions). Partner channel through produce distributors, food safety consultants, and Cooperative Extension.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Sign 1,000-1,500 farms at $300/month average by Q3 2026 (compliance deadline creates urgency). Focus on leafy greens (Salinas Valley) and tomatoes (Florida) as initial verticals -- highest recall risk, most buyer pressure. Layer packer/distributor sales ($1,000/month avg) for revenue acceleration. First $5M ARR achievable in 12-18 months post-rule-effective-date.

falsification_criteria: If FDA delays FSMA 204(d) enforcement beyond 2027 (as happened with previous FSMA rules), removing the compliance urgency
If major retailers (Walmart, Kroger, Costco) mandate their OWN traceability platforms for suppliers, fragmenting the market into walled gardens
If farms find that paper-based records satisfy FDA inspections with minimal penalties, removing the digital adoption driver

models.name: Food Service Robotics-as-a-Service
models.one_liner: Robotic food preparation and delivery systems deployed as RaaS subscriptions to QSR and fast-casual chains, targeting the $6.8B food robotics market by 2030
models.macro_source: Grand View Research food robotics market forecast ($6.81B by 2030, 20.6% CAGR); Bear Robotics deployment data; Sweetgreen Infinite Kitchen announcements; NRA labor shortage surveys

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): capital intensity ($50-150K per unit) and long deployment cycles (3-6 months for kitchen integration) create barriers, but major chains are actively seeking solutions — Chipotle invested in Hyphen, Sweetgreen built Infinite Kitchen, White Castle deployed Flippy. Moat Advantage is strong (8): robotics IP, proprietary kitchen integration data, and regulatory compliance (food safety, OSHA) create deep defensibility — competitors cannot easily replicate 10,000+ hours of real-world food preparation data. Value Density is strong (7): RaaS pricing of $2,000-5,000/month per unit against $3,500-5,000/month labor cost per FTE replaced — clear ROI story. Demand Visibility is strong (7): 4.6M limited-service restaurant workers at $22.5K/year making automation ROI clear, but adoption requires solving integration with existing kitchen workflows.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The food robotics market was valued at $1.81B in 2023 and is projected to reach $6.81B by 2030 (20.6% CAGR, Grand View Research). QCEW data shows limited-service restaurants (722513) employ 4.606M workers at $434/week ($22,553 annual) — the lowest-wage major employment category in the US economy. Labor scarcity is structural: NRA reports 62% of operators cannot find enough workers in 2025. Bear Robotics has deployed its Servi robot to 1,000+ venues globally. Miso Robotics' Flippy has been deployed at White Castle, CaliBurger, and several other chains. Sweetgreen's Infinite Kitchen automated assembly processes 500+ bowls/hour. The economics are compelling: a robotic food prep station operating 16 hours/day at $2,500/month RaaS fee replaces 1.5-2 FTEs at a combined cost of $5,000-8,000/month (including benefits, training, turnover costs). However, the sector faces real constraints: kitchen retrofitting costs $20-50K, integration with existing POS/KDS systems is complex, and food safety certification adds 6-12 months to deployment. The 2023 QCEW data shows food truck/mobile food (722330) growing 14.4% in establishments — the lowest-capex format — while full-service restaurants grow only 1.8%, suggesting capital constraints are real for traditional formats.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $6.8B (food robotics by 2030, Grand View Research). Food service robotics specifically: ~$2.5B by 2030. RaaS model serviceable: $1.5B based on 25,000 QSR/fast-casual deployments at $5K/month.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Capital intensive — a startup can realistically deploy to 500-2,000 locations in 5 years. At $4,000/month RaaS per unit: $24-96M ARR. Requires $50-100M+ in venture funding for hardware development and fleet deployment. This is a Series B+ play, not seed-stage.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Hardware COGS of $30-60K per unit amortized over 36-month RaaS contract at $3,500-5,000/month = $126-180K lifetime revenue per unit. 55-65% gross margins at scale (including maintenance, remote monitoring). Payback on hardware: 8-14 months. Customer payback: 4-8 months (labor savings).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Slow deployment (3-6 months per site for kitchen integration) but highly sticky once installed (expected 85%+ renewal rate). Chain deployments create bulk orders (50-500 units per chain decision). Sales cycle: 6-12 months for chain pilots, 18-24 months for national rollout commitment.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Hardware IP + proprietary training data from thousands of kitchen environments. Food safety certification creates 12-18 month regulatory moat per category. Kitchen integration partnerships with POS/KDS vendors (Toast, Oracle MICROS) create distribution advantages. Each deployment generates data that improves reliability, creating a flywheel that new entrants cannot replicate without equivalent scale.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=robotics_automation, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $6810M

models.name: Hospitality Workforce Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-driven scheduling, labor compliance, and retention platform purpose-built for hospitality's unique shift/tip/seasonal workforce, targeting the $3.1B restaurant scheduling software market by 2035
models.macro_source: 360iResearch restaurant scheduling software forecast ($3.12B by 2035, 7.9% CAGR); QCEW NAICS 72 (14M workers, 781K establishments); NRA workforce surveys; BLS JOLTS hospitality quit rates

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (6): 7shifts (raised $100M+ total), Homebase, and When I Work have traction but none has achieved dominant share in a 781K-establishment market. Deputy was acquired by Gusto for $100M — validating the category but showing how workforce management is being absorbed into broader HR platforms. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): scheduling data creates switching costs, but the core product (shift scheduling) risks commoditization — differentiation comes from AI demand prediction, tip pooling compliance, and retention analytics. Value Density is moderate (5): $50-200/month per location ARPU for scheduling alone — must bundle labor compliance, tip management, and hiring to reach $300+/month. Demand Visibility is proven (9): hospitality has the highest quit rate of any sector (5.7% monthly in food services per BLS JOLTS) — workforce management is a survival requirement, not a nice-to-have.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 72 employs 13.97M private-sector workers across 781K establishments at $551/week ($28,667 annual). The Baumol score of 0.396 (wages 60% below economy average) means workers are among the poorest in the economy — and the most mobile. BLS JOLTS data shows food services consistently has the highest quit rate: approximately 5.7% monthly, meaning a restaurant turns over its entire staff approximately every 17 months. The scheduling software market was valued at $1.46B in 2025 (360iResearch) growing at 7.9% CAGR. But the real opportunity is workforce intelligence — not just scheduling but predictive demand-based staffing (AI analyzes weather, events, holidays, historical patterns to predict covers and staff accordingly), automated compliance (tip credit tracking, predictive scheduling laws in NYC/SF/Chicago/Seattle, break compliance, overtime management), and retention analytics (identifying which employees are at risk of quitting based on schedule satisfaction, hours stability, and peer patterns). The regulatory tailwind is significant: predictive scheduling laws now cover 10M+ workers and are expanding. NAICS 722310 (food service contractors) growing at 11.6% creates a concentrated enterprise buyer segment. The total workforce management value opportunity for hospitality: scheduling ($1.5B), compliance ($800M), hiring/retention ($600M), tip management ($400M) = $3.3B addressable by 2028.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.1B (restaurant scheduling by 2035). Broader hospitality workforce intelligence (scheduling + compliance + retention + tip management): $3.3B by 2028.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture 15,000-40,000 locations in 5 years. At $150/month per location: $27-72M ARR. 7shifts has ~40,000 locations after 10 years — the market supports multiple winners given 781K establishments.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Pure SaaS: 80-85% gross margins. $100-200/month ARPU for scheduling, $250-400/month bundled (scheduling + compliance + hiring). LTV: $3,600 (24-month retention at $150/mo). CAC: $400-800 (PLG + channel partnerships with POS platforms). LTV:CAC of 4.5-9x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fastest adoption cycle in hospitality tech: scheduling is a weekly pain point with immediate relief. Free trial to paid conversion in 14-30 days. Multi-location chains can deploy in 1-2 weeks. Predictive scheduling law compliance creates urgency-driven sales in regulated cities.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Historical scheduling data creates AI prediction accuracy advantage. Compliance rule engine (different laws in 20+ jurisdictions) is complex to build and maintain. Employee app network effects: if workers use the platform across multiple employers (common in hospitality), the platform becomes the worker's career tool. Integration with payroll and POS creates data dependency.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=workflow_automation, buyer=smb_mid, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $3300M

models.name: Subcontractor Prequalification & Risk Management Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform that aggregates financial health, safety records, project history, and insurance data to score and prequalify subcontractors for GCs -- serving 540K specialty trade firms and 225K GCs in a market where sub failure causes $15B+ in annual project disruptions
models.macro_source: F1: AI can aggregate and analyze subcontractor risk signals from financial data, OSHA records, litigation, insurance, and project references. F4: Subcontractor failure (bankruptcy, abandonment, defective work) costs GCs $15B+ annually in project delays and rework. F5: Trust deficit between GCs and subs is the primary friction in construction supply chains.

cla.rationale: Existing prequalification is manual: GCs require subs to fill out paper/PDF prequalification questionnaires (20-50 pages each) for every project bid. Current digital solutions: ISNetworld (safety-focused, $200M+ revenue, dominant in industrial), Avetta (supply chain risk, broader than construction), TradeTapp (construction-specific prequal, acquired by Procore competitor Command Alkon). Procore has basic prequal features but not AI-driven risk scoring. The AI opportunity: automatically pull OSHA records, financial filings, insurance certificates, litigation history, project performance data, and generate a real-time risk score for any subcontractor. The compounding data moat is strong: each prequal assessment adds to the database, and GCs who use the platform want ALL their subs on it, creating network effects. Market openness is high because ISNetworld is industrial-focused and no one dominates construction-specific prequal.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The GC-subcontractor relationship is the central axis of US construction: a typical $50M commercial project involves 1 GC and 20-30 specialty subcontractors. Subcontractor selection is the single highest-risk decision a GC makes. Subcontractor failure (bankruptcy mid-project, abandonment, defective work requiring rework) causes an estimated $15B+ in annual project disruptions (based on construction defect litigation data, surety bond claims, and project delay costs). Current prequal process: manual, paper-based, requiring 5-20 hours per sub per project. GCs typically prequalify 100-500 subs per year. Data sources available for AI aggregation: (1) OSHA inspection records (public), (2) State contractor license status (public), (3) Financial health indicators (D&B, Experian commercial), (4) Insurance certificate verification (API-accessible), (5) Litigation history (court records), (6) Project performance references (proprietary). ISNetworld dominates industrial prequal ($200M+ revenue) but is weak in commercial/residential construction. A construction-specific prequal platform with AI risk scoring could charge $5-15K/year per GC and $500-1,500/year per sub (sub pays to maintain verified profile). Network effects: GCs want all subs on platform, subs want to be findable by all GCs.
falsification_criteria: Open-source or foundation model alternatives eliminate proprietary data moat advantages
Data privacy regulations (state-level CCPA variants) restrict data aggregation business model
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.8B (subcontractor prequalification, risk management, and performance analytics -- 225K GCs + 540K subs)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Two-sided market: GCs pay for risk intelligence, subs pay for verified profiles. Path to $80M ARR by serving 5,000 GCs at $8K ACV + 50,000 subs at $800 ACV. Network effects create winner-take-most dynamics. ISNetworld's $200M+ in industrial prequal validates the category economics.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: GC side: $5-15K/year ACV. Sub side: $500-1,500/year ACV. Gross margins 85%+. CAC: $1-3K per GC (direct sales), $100-300 per sub (pulled by GC requirement). CLTV/CAC: 5x+ on GC side, 3x+ on sub side.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: GC procurement cycle for prequal tools: 3-6 months. Once GC adopts, 50-200 subs are pulled onto platform. Annual subscription renewal. New project starts trigger sub onboarding.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Subcontractor database with verified credentials, safety records, financial health, and project performance. Network effects (GCs attract subs, subs attract GCs). Data compounding: each project outcome improves the risk model. Switching costs once embedded in GC procurement workflow.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $15000M

models.name: Intermodal Optimization & Visibility Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered intermodal freight optimization platform balancing truck-rail-ship modal selection for shippers in the $27.5-54B US intermodal market growing at 11.7-13.5% CAGR to $78.9-93.5B by 2030
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: intermodal freight $27.5B (2025) to $82.6B (2030) at 13.5% CAGR. 360iResearch: $45.4B (2025) to $78.9B (2030) at 11.7% CAGR. Grand View Research: $93.5B (2030) at 12.1% CAGR. Rail intermodal is 3.5x more fuel efficient than truck. Sustainability mandates (EPA Scope 3 reporting) driving modal shift. Truck driver shortage makes rail-truck intermodal structural necessity.

cla.rationale: Intermodal optimization sits between two oligopolies: Class I railroads (7 companies, 94% of freight rail revenue) and large trucking carriers. J.B. Hunt is the dominant intermodal player ($6.5B intermodal revenue, 100K+ containers). Traditional intermodal brokers/IMCs (Hub Group, STG Logistics, XPO) handle modal selection manually. The AI opportunity is DYNAMIC modal optimization: for any given shipment, should it move truck-only, rail-truck, or rail-truck-rail based on real-time pricing, capacity, transit time, carbon emissions, and weather? Current technology: most shippers use static routing rules, not dynamic optimization. The platform that can ingest live rail capacity (from all 7 Class I railroads) and truck capacity (from 500K+ carriers) and optimize in real-time wins. MO is 6 because J.B. Hunt and Hub Group have strong intermodal positions but lack AI optimization depth.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US intermodal volumes: 14.8M containers/trailers moved in 2024. Rail intermodal is 3.5x more fuel efficient than over-the-road trucking. EPA Scope 3 emissions reporting requirements are driving corporate shippers to track and reduce transportation emissions -- rail intermodal is the easiest way to show 40-60% CO2 reduction per shipment. Driver shortage makes intermodal structural: one train replaces 280 trucks. Class I railroad on-time performance improved to 75-85% (up from 60-70% during 2021-2022 service crisis), making intermodal viable for time-sensitive freight again. Key pain point: intermodal transit time variability. AI can predict actual transit time (not published schedule) based on rail congestion, weather, terminal dwell time -- reducing variability from +/- 2 days to +/- 0.5 days. This predictability unlocks $50B+ of freight currently moving by truck because shippers cannot accept intermodal variability.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.0-3.5B by 2030 (intermodal optimization software capturing 2-4% of $79-94B intermodal market as technology enablement layer)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible targeting large shippers ($100M+ freight spend) who have enough volume for intermodal to matter but lack internal optimization capabilities. Must partner with (not compete against) railroads and IMCs. Data access to railroad systems is the critical unlock -- and the critical barrier.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS platform fee ($10-50K/month) + per-shipment optimization fee ($5-25/container). Large shipper moving 5,000 containers/month = $25-125K/month. Gross margins 80%+. Value creation: 5-15% transportation cost reduction + 40-60% CO2 reduction per converted shipment.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-12 months for enterprise shippers. Pilot with one lane (e.g., LA to Chicago), prove transit time predictability, then expand lane coverage. Fastest adoption among consumer goods companies with Scope 3 reporting pressure. Bid season (annual freight contracts in Q4-Q1) is the natural decision point.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Railroad data integration (access to real-time rail network data from all 7 Class I railroads is a multi-year achievement). Shipment data compounding: transit time prediction models improve with each container tracked. Shipper switching costs: once routing is optimized and integrated into ERP/TMS, changing providers is disruptive. Carbon accounting integration creates ESG reporting lock-in.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=supply_chain_optimization, buyer=enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $50000M

models.name: Drone Delivery Infrastructure & Airspace Management
models.sector_name: Couriers and Express Delivery Services — Drone
models.one_liner: Unmanned traffic management (UTM) and drone delivery operations platform enabling commercial BVLOS drone delivery in the $0.97B drone package delivery market growing to $4.78B by 2030 at 37.6% CAGR
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: drone package delivery $0.97B (2025) to $4.78B (2030) at 37.6% CAGR. MarketsandMarkets: $0.99B (2025) to $4.67B (2030) at 37.4% CAGR. BVLOS approvals expanding to 4+ states. Zipline: 1M+ commercial deliveries. Wing (Alphabet): 350K+ deliveries in 2024. Amazon Prime Air expanding to multiple metros. FAA Part 135 waivers increasing.

cla.rationale: Drone delivery is pre-market in terms of scale: only ~2M commercial deliveries in 2025 globally. The hardware layer is contested (Zipline, Wing, Amazon, Matternet, Flytrex). The SOFTWARE/INFRASTRUCTURE layer -- airspace management (UTM), vertiport management, multi-operator deconfliction, and regulatory compliance automation -- is the more capital-efficient startup opportunity. The FAA's UTM framework requires certified traffic management systems, creating a regulatory moat for approved providers. MO is 5 because the market is small and Wing/Amazon have deep pockets. But neither is building a NEUTRAL airspace management platform -- both want proprietary systems. The opportunity mirrors cell towers: neutral infrastructure serving multiple operators. DV is 5 because consumer demand is proven for speed but willingness to receive drone delivery specifically (vs any fast delivery) is uncertain.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Drone delivery deployments: Zipline 1M+ deliveries (primarily medical supply in Rwanda/US), Wing (Alphabet) 350K+ deliveries in 2024 across Australia, US, Finland. Amazon Prime Air: expanded to 3+ US metros. FAA BVLOS approvals: 4 states with expanded authorization. Medical drone delivery (hospital-to-hospital blood/specimens) is the proven use case. Consumer package delivery is the larger TAM but earlier stage. UTM (Unmanned Traffic Management) market: FAA mandating certified UTM for commercial drone operations. Only 3-5 companies have FAA-approved UTM systems. Key constraint: public acceptance is 45-55% for drone delivery (noise, safety, privacy concerns). Drone delivery cost approaching $2-3/delivery for lightweight packages (<5 lbs) vs $8-12 for van delivery -- economics are compelling IF regulatory and acceptance barriers are overcome. Medical delivery drone market is $400M+ and growing 40%+ CAGR with clearer regulatory path and higher social acceptance.
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Warehouse automation ROI fails to justify capital expenditure for mid-size operators
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.2-2.5B by 2030 (UTM + drone operations infrastructure capturing 25-50% of $4.8B drone delivery market as enabling layer)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible but TIMING RISK is high. The market grows 37%+ CAGR but from a tiny base ($970M). Realistic revenue potential by 2028 is $10-50M for a leading UTM provider. Best strategy: start with medical drone delivery infrastructure (proven demand, regulatory clarity, premium pricing) and expand to commercial delivery as BVLOS approvals broaden. FAA certification creates a regulatory moat that takes 2-3 years to achieve.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: UTM SaaS per-operation fee: $0.10-0.50/flight. At 100K flights/month = $10-50K/month. Platform fee per drone operator: $5-25K/month. Gross margins 80%+ for software. Hardware (vertiport infrastructure) is lower margin but creates physical switching costs. Medical delivery operations: $15-50/delivery for premium hospital-to-hospital service.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Regulatory-gated: each FAA BVLOS approval unlocks a new geography. Medical drone delivery is fastest to adopt (12-month sales cycle). Consumer delivery operators move faster once BVLOS is approved in their geography. Technology adoption follows airspace approval, not market demand -- regulatory is the gating factor.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: FAA UTM certification (2-3 year process, difficult to replicate). Airspace data: real-time drone traffic data from managed operations creates predictive models for airspace deconfliction. Vertiport network: physical landing infrastructure (like cell towers) creates geographic monopolies. Operator relationships: multi-year contracts with drone delivery operators for airspace management. Safety record: FAA relies on UTM providers' safety data for BVLOS expansion decisions.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $4780M

models.name: Automated Tax Fraud Detection & Revenue Optimization Platform
models.one_liner: Machine learning platform for tax fraud detection, audit targeting, and revenue optimization — addressing the $688B annual federal tax gap plus $100B+ state tax gap across 50 state revenue agencies and the IRS
models.macro_source: F1: IRS tax gap: $688B gross, $625B net (IRS 2024 report on TY2021). State/local tax gaps estimated $100-150B. AI/ML fraud detection market: $12.1B (2025) to $28.4B (2030) at 18.6% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). F4: IRS received $80B in IRA funding for modernization (2022), partially clawed back but $60B+ remains. F3: Bipartisan political consensus on closing tax gap — DOGE and progressive Democrats both support (for different reasons).
models.deep_dive_evidence: The IRS tax gap is $688B gross (TY2021, published 2024) — this is the difference between taxes owed and taxes collected. Breakdown: underreporting $542B (78%), non-filing $77B (11%), underpayment $68B (10%). IRS audit rate has fallen from 1.1% (2010) to 0.4% (2023) due to funding cuts. IRA provided $80B over 10 years for modernization; $45.6B for enforcement. The IRS estimates every $1 invested in enforcement returns $5-12. At the state level: 50 state revenue agencies collected $1.1T in state taxes (2024). State audit efficiency varies dramatically — some states achieve 15:1 ROI on audits, others 3:1. AI/ML can improve audit targeting by identifying non-obvious patterns (industry benchmarking, third-party data matching, behavioral analytics) that rule-based systems miss. Palantir has IRS contracts but focused on investigative case management, not broad audit targeting. Accenture Federal provides tax modernization services but uses traditional analytics. The startup opportunity is an AI platform specifically trained on tax compliance patterns: return-level risk scoring, refund fraud detection, identity verification, and audit case prioritization. At state level, Gentax (Fast Enterprises, dominant state tax platform) handles processing but lacks AI analytics. Revenue Solutions Inc. and Pondera Solutions serve some states but market is fragmented.

cla.rationale: Federal IRS contracts are FORTIFIED: dominated by Booz Allen, SAIC, Accenture Federal, and Palantir. The IRS spends $2.8B annually on IT and has deep incumbent relationships. MO is 3 at federal level. However, STATE tax agencies are dramatically more accessible: 50 state revenue departments, most using decade-old rule-based audit selection systems. States lost an estimated $100-150B in tax revenue during COVID (unemployment fraud alone was $191B). The AI fraud detection opportunity at the state level is genuinely open — few states have deployed ML-based audit targeting. MA is 9 because tax fraud models trained on historical audit outcomes create compounding accuracy (each completed audit improves the model). VD is 10: the value density is unmatched — every $1 spent on tax enforcement returns $5-12 (IRS ROI data). This is the rare government market where ROI is directly measurable in recovered revenue.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.5B by 2030 (AI-specific tax compliance and fraud detection within $28.4B total AI fraud detection market — government tax segment)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Federal IRS: requires FedRAMP High, cleared personnel, and 3-5 year relationship building. FORTIFIED — only viable for well-funded companies with existing federal presence. State revenue agencies: $100K-$2M ACV per state, procurement cycles 6-18 months. Start with 3-5 early adopter states, prove ROI (recovered revenue > platform cost), then scale. Revenue-sharing models (percentage of incremental revenue recovered) align incentives and reduce procurement friction.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: State agency: $50K-$200K/month ($600K-$2.4M ACV). Revenue sharing alternative: 5-15% of incremental tax revenue recovered (can reach $10M+ per state for large states). Gross margins 80%+. Zero marginal cost per additional audit recommendation. The economic case is self-funding: platform cost is 5-10% of recovered revenue.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 6-18 months for state agencies. Revenue-sharing model accelerates adoption (reduces procurement risk for agency). Budget cycle timing critical: state legislatures approve technology spending annually. NASACT (National Association of State Auditors) and FTA (Federation of Tax Administrators) are key distribution channels. Every fiscal crisis increases demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Tax compliance ML models trained on millions of returns with known outcomes create compounding accuracy. Multi-state training data creates cross-state pattern detection (fraud schemes migrate across jurisdictions). Integration with state tax processing systems (Fast Enterprises Gentax, SAP, Oracle) creates switching costs. Domain expertise in tax law is a hiring moat — few ML engineers understand tax code.

models.falsification_criteria: If IRS builds comprehensive AI audit targeting internally using IRA funding (eliminating need for external platforms). If Palantir expands from case management to broad tax compliance AI at federal and state levels. If political environment shifts against tax enforcement (reducing funding for audit technology). If taxpayer privacy concerns lead to restrictions on AI-based audit targeting (algorithmic due process challenges).

models.name: Commercial Earth Observation Analytics
models.one_liner: AI-powered geospatial analytics platform transforming satellite imagery into actionable intelligence for agriculture, insurance, commodity trading, and infrastructure monitoring — serving a $9.4B earth observation data market growing at 14% CAGR
models.macro_source: Planet Labs ($PL) financial reports; Euroconsult earth observation market report 2025; Maxar (acquired by Advent International for $6.4B); Orbital Insight and Descartes Labs funding; USDA crop monitoring programs; global crop insurance market $46B (2024)
models.deep_dive_evidence: The earth observation data and services market reached $6.1B in 2024 and is projected to hit $9.4B by 2028 (Euroconsult, 14% CAGR). Critically, the commercial segment now exceeds the defense/intelligence segment for the first time — agriculture, insurance, energy, finance, and infrastructure monitoring collectively represent 60%+ of demand. Planet Labs ($PL, ~$180M annual revenue) provides daily global 3m imagery from 200+ satellites but generates only basic analytics. The value gap: raw satellite imagery is abundant and commoditizing; AI-derived insights are scarce and high-value. Specific verticals demonstrate this: crop yield prediction (Descartes Labs, Gro Intelligence) commands $5-50/acre from commodity traders and insurers; infrastructure monitoring (Orbital Insight, HawkEye 360) charges $50-500K/year for pipeline and power line surveillance; deforestation monitoring commands $100K+ per engagement from ESG-mandated corporations. The analytics layer has better unit economics than the satellite layer — Planet Labs has -10% operating margins despite $180M revenue, while analytics providers operate at 60-80% gross margins with no space hardware risk. The data compounding advantage: AI models trained on multi-year, multi-spectral satellite archives with ground-truth validation (actual crop yields, confirmed insurance claims, verified deforestation) improve continuously. SAR (synthetic aperture radar) data from Capella Space and ICEYE adds all-weather, day-night capability. The CHIPS Act and ITAR reform are enabling US commercial earth observation exports that were previously restricted. Maxar's $6.4B acquisition by Advent International (2023) validates category value at the asset level.

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

models.name: RegTech Orchestration Layer for Alternative Investment Compliance

models.macro_source: v35_model_cards

models.name: Farm Succession & Land Transaction Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: Data-driven farmland valuation, succession planning, and transaction matching platform for the $3.2T US farmland market where 40% of acreage will change hands by 2035 as 700K+ operators over age 65 exit -- the largest intergenerational wealth transfer in American agricultural history
models.macro_source: F2: 34% of farm operators over 65 (USDA Census 2022). 40% of US farmland expected to change hands by 2035 (American Farmland Trust). F4: Farmland values $5,460/acre average cropland (2024), up 60% since 2019 -- creating $3.2T asset class. Institutional farmland investment: $15-20B AUM (TIAA-CREF/Nuveen, Gladstone Land, Farmland Partners REIT). F5: 70% of retiring farmers have NO written succession plan (Purdue Center for Commercial Agriculture, 2023).
models.deep_dive_evidence: US farmland: 896M acres, total value $3.2T (USDA NASS 2024). Average cropland value: $5,460/acre, up 60% from $3,420 in 2019. Annual farmland transactions: ~$50B (estimated from county-level deed transfer data). The demographic timebomb: 34% of farm operators are over 65. Only 9% are under 35. USDA ERS projects 370K farm operators will exit farming by 2030, controlling 300M+ acres. 70% of these retiring operators have NO written succession plan (Purdue 2023 survey). When a farmer without a succession plan dies or becomes incapacitated, the land typically: (1) goes to non-farming heirs who sell (40-50% of cases), (2) is rented to a neighbor (30-40%), or (3) is sold to institutional investors (10-20%). This is creating a MASSIVE and PREDICTABLE wave of land transactions. Current market infrastructure: farmland brokerages are local and fragmented (60,000+ licensed farm real estate agents). AcreTrader ($100M+ raised) and FarmFundr are crowdfunding platforms. Farmers National Company and Hertz Real Estate are traditional ag brokerages. AcreValue (acquired by Granular/Corteva) provides public farmland data but no transaction matching. NO PLATFORM combines: (1) AI-powered farmland valuation (integrating soil productivity, water rights, crop history, proximity, comparable sales), (2) succession planning tools (tax optimization for 1031 exchanges, installment sales, family LLC structuring), (3) buyer-seller matching (connecting retiring farmers with beginning farmers, institutional investors, and conservation organizations). The information asymmetry in farmland transactions is extreme: sellers rarely know the true productivity-adjusted value of their land, and buyers (especially institutional) overpay by 5-15% due to lack of field-level data.

cla.rationale: Market openness is HIGH: no tech platform serves the farmland succession/transaction lifecycle. AcreTrader is crowdfunding, AcreValue is data-only, local brokers are fragmented and non-digital. The demographic forcing function (700K+ operators over 65) is not a forecast -- it is a measured reality. Moat advantage is moderate: farmland valuation models improve with transaction data, and relationships with farm families create trust-based lock-in. Value density is HIGH: at 2.5-3% brokerage commission on $50B annual transactions, the take is $1.25-$1.5B/year. Demand visibility is strong and GROWING: the demographic wave is accelerating, not receding.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.5-3.0B (farmland transaction technology: valuation + succession planning + brokerage, on $50B annual farmland transactions)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented traditional, emerging digital
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Transaction-based: 1.5-3.0% of land sale value (split with listing agent). Average transaction: 320 acres at $5,460/acre = $1.75M, yielding $26K-$52K per transaction. Subscription tier for succession planning tools: $2,000-$5,000/year to farm families. Institutional data/analytics: $50K-$200K/year to farmland investment firms. Gross margins 65-75%.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Two-pronged: (1) Succession planning SaaS to farm families through ag lenders and estate attorneys ($3K ACV, 500 families = $1.5M). (2) Farmland transaction matching yielding $35K average commission on 100 transactions/year = $3.5M. Total $5M ARR in year 2-3. Focus on Corn Belt initially (Iowa, Illinois, Indiana) where land values are highest and succession urgency is greatest.

falsification_criteria: If farmland values correct sharply (>20% decline), reducing transaction urgency and institutional buyer interest
If retiring farmers prove willing to let heirs handle transactions through traditional local brokers rather than adopting a tech platform
If AcreTrader or another existing platform successfully expands from crowdfunding to full-service farmland transaction management

models.name: Wide-Bandgap Semiconductor Fabless Design
models.one_liner: Fabless design house specializing in SiC and GaN power semiconductor chips for EV inverters, data center power supplies, and renewable energy converters — riding the $18.4B wide-bandgap market by 2030 with design IP and OSAT partnerships
models.macro_source: Wolfspeed SiC foundry expansion (Mohawk Valley $5B fab); Yole Développement SiC/GaN power semiconductor market forecast; CHIPS Act Section 48D manufacturing credits; Tesla vertical integration of SiC inverters; Infineon, STMicro, and ON Semi SiC roadmaps
models.deep_dive_evidence: Silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) power semiconductors are replacing silicon IGBTs in high-power applications due to 50% lower switching losses, 10x higher switching frequency, and higher temperature operation. The SiC power device market reached $4.1B in 2024 and is projected to hit $12.6B by 2030 (Yole, 21% CAGR). GaN power adds another $5.8B by 2030 (primarily in <900V applications: data center power supplies, phone chargers, solar microinverters). The combined wide-bandgap market of $18.4B by 2030 is being driven by three converging demands: EVs (each EV uses $300-500 of SiC in the main inverter — Tesla's Model 3/Y use STMicro SiC MOSFETs), data center power (AI GPU racks draw 40-120kW requiring high-efficiency power conversion), and renewable energy (solar inverters and wind turbine converters). The market is supply-constrained: Wolfspeed's $5B Mohawk Valley fab expansion has faced repeated delays and the company's stock has declined 80%+ since 2023. Established players (Infineon, STMicro, ON Semi, ROHM) are vertically integrated, but the fabless opportunity exists because SiC/GaN foundry capacity (from X-FAB, Tower Semiconductor, and emerging Chinese fabs) is becoming available — enabling design houses to compete without $1-5B fab investments. CHIPS Act Section 48D provides 25% investment tax credits for semiconductor manufacturing, and Department of Commerce grants target SiC/GaN specifically. The design challenge: SiC/GaN devices require fundamentally different circuit topologies, gate drivers, and thermal management — creating space for specialized design IP. Navitas Semiconductor ($NVTS, GaN focus, $120M revenue run-rate) and EPC (acquired by Renesas) validate the fabless WBG model.

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=33, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

models.name: Energy Code & Sustainability Compliance Platform for Construction
models.one_liner: AI platform automating energy code compliance, LEED/WELL certification documentation, and embodied carbon tracking for new construction -- targeting the $17.5B building code compliance market by 2032 where 70% of firms already use software for green certification and energy codes are tightening 15-25% per cycle
models.macro_source: F6: IECC 2024 requires 15-25% energy improvement. 9 states mandate heat pumps. Building sector = 40% of US energy consumption. F1: AI automates energy modeling and code checking. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032), 8.8% CAGR (Coherent Market Insights). Green construction market growing at 11.2% CAGR.

cla.rationale: Energy code compliance is increasingly mandatory and increasingly complex. Current tools: (1) EnergyPlus (DOE, free, complex), (2) REScheck/COMcheck (DOE, basic compliance), (3) IES VE, eQUEST (commercial energy modeling, $10K+/year), (4) Autodesk Insight (integrated with Revit but limited), (5) cove.tool ($30M raised, performance-based building design). No single platform connects energy code compliance to permit submission to sustainability certification to embodied carbon tracking. The fragmentation of energy codes across jurisdictions (some states on IECC 2021, others on 2024, California on Title 24) creates complexity that AI can simplify. 70% of firms in developed regions already use software for green building compliance -- the question is whether a new platform can consolidate the workflow. Demand visibility is high: every new building must comply with energy codes, and codes are tightening every 3 years.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Building sector consumes 40% of US energy. Building codes are the primary policy lever for reducing building energy consumption. IECC 2024 (adopted by 12 states as of Feb 2026) requires 15-25% energy improvement over 2021 baseline, including: mandatory blower door testing, continuous insulation, high-efficiency HVAC, and for commercial buildings, automated lighting controls and energy recovery ventilation. California Title 24 (2025 cycle) mandates all-electric new construction in many zones. NYC LL97 imposes carbon penalties on existing buildings >25,000 SF starting 2024 (up to $268/ton CO2). 9 states mandate heat pumps in new residential. Embodied carbon: Portland, Vancouver, and LEED v5 now require lifecycle carbon assessment of construction materials. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR. Green building certification market growing at 11.2% CAGR. cove.tool ($30M raised) has proven the 'performance-based design' category. The integration opportunity: a single platform that (1) identifies applicable energy codes by jurisdiction, (2) runs automated energy modeling on building designs, (3) checks compliance and generates required documentation, (4) tracks embodied carbon in material selections, (5) generates LEED/WELL/ENERGY STAR documentation. For residential builders (1.1M workers, 225K firms), energy code compliance is the FASTEST-GROWING source of project complexity and delay.
falsification_criteria: Regulatory environment simplifies, reducing demand for automated compliance
Large consulting firms (Big 4) build competitive compliance automation platforms
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Grid capacity expands ahead of data center demand, eliminating energy constraint premiums

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.2B (energy code compliance + green certification + embodied carbon software within the $17.5B broader code compliance market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Target: 200K+ residential builders + 50K commercial builders needing energy code compliance. Path to $100M ARR by serving 15K builder firms at $6.5K ACV. Regulatory mandate creates non-optional demand. Code tightening every 3 years creates recurring upgrade cycles.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $3K-$15K per builder depending on volume. Per-project pricing also possible ($200-$1K per energy model). Gross margins 80%+. CAC moderate: code officials and building departments are referral channels. Energy raters and HERS providers are channel partners.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: New code adoption cycles create demand spikes. California Title 24 and NYC LL97 are early indicators of national trend. Builder association partnerships provide channel. Every new project is a potential sale.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Jurisdiction-specific code database (energy codes vary by state, county, and city). AI energy modeling trained on thousands of building types and climate zones. Integration with BIM tools and permit submission systems. Green certification workflow automation.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $17520M

models.name: Live Event Ticketing Alternative Infrastructure
models.one_liner: Primary ticketing infrastructure challenging Live Nation/Ticketmaster's 70%+ monopoly — targeting independent venues, festivals, and mid-tier promoters in the DOJ-antitrust-pressured $88B ticketing market
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence online event ticketing ($88.4B by 2026); DOJ v. Live Nation antitrust suit (2024-ongoing); QCEW NAICS 7113 (164K workers, 10.8K establishments); SeatGeek primary ticketing deal announcements; Eventbrite ~$300M revenue
models.sector_name: Promoters of Performing Arts, Sports, and Similar Events
models.deep_dive_evidence: Live Nation/Ticketmaster facilitated 637M tickets globally in 2024, controlling an estimated 70%+ of US primary ticketing for major venues. The DOJ filed an antitrust lawsuit in 2024 alleging monopolistic practices — if successful, this could force structural remedies (divestiture of Ticketmaster, venue contract releases, fee transparency mandates) that would create the largest market opening in live entertainment history. Even without DOJ action, the competitive landscape is shifting: SeatGeek has signed primary ticketing deals with the Dallas Cowboys, Brooklyn Nets, and NFL's New Orleans Saints. DICE focuses on no-fee mobile ticketing. Eventbrite serves 800K+ event creators at ~$300M revenue. The opportunity for alternative ticketing infrastructure is two-fold: (1) Structural: if DOJ remedies release venues from exclusive Ticketmaster contracts, thousands of venues will need alternative primary ticketing. (2) Technology: current ticketing platforms are optimized for revenue extraction (fees), not for venue/promoter value (audience data, CRM, dynamic pricing, fraud prevention). QCEW 711310 shows 4,615 venue establishments with 14.3% employment growth — the venue base is growing. The challenge is brutal: Ticketmaster's exclusive venue contracts are typically 5-10 years. Even without the contracts, Ticketmaster's consumer brand recognition and distribution (200M+ registered accounts) create massive demand-side network effects. This is a FORTIFIED market that becomes ACCESSIBLE only if DOJ action succeeds or venues organically choose alternatives.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is weak (3): this is the most monopolized market in NAICS 71. Ticketmaster's exclusive venue contracts, consumer brand, and Live Nation's vertical integration (promotion + venue ownership + ticketing) create a triple moat. SeatGeek, DICE, and others have made inroads but remain subscale. The DOJ case is the ONLY catalyst that could structurally open this market. Moat Advantage is moderate (5): ticketing platforms have moderate switching costs (venue integration, box office training, consumer migration) but the core technology is not deeply defensible — the moat is distribution, not technology. Value Density is strong (7): ticketing fees are 15-25% of face value on average — at $88B global ticketing, the fee pool exceeds $13B. Any platform capturing meaningful share accesses enormous revenue. Demand Visibility is strong (7): every venue operator, artist, and fan complains about Ticketmaster fees — demand for alternatives is universal but action is constrained by structural lock-in.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $88.4B (global online event ticketing 2026). US primary ticketing fee pool: estimated $8-13B. Non-Ticketmaster addressable (current): ~$2-3B. Post-DOJ remedy (speculative): $6-10B.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Ticketmaster (70%+ US primary, 637M tickets globally). SeatGeek (primary + secondary, Dallas Cowboys, Brooklyn Nets, $300M+ valuation). AXS (AEG-owned, major venues). DICE (mobile-first, no-fee model). Eventbrite (self-service events, 800K creators). StubHub (secondary market, $6B+ GMV).
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Transaction-based: 5-15% of ticket face value in fees, split with venues. On $50 average ticket price, platform captures $3-7.50 per ticket. Gross margins: 55-70% (after payment processing and infrastructure). Volume economics: 1M tickets = $3-7.5M revenue. LTV per venue: $200K-2M/year depending on venue size. CAC per venue: $50-200K (enterprise sales + venue integration). LTV:CAC of 4-10x at scale.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 50-100 mid-size venues selling 50-200K tickets/year each. At $5 average platform fee: 1M tickets = $5M. Requires winning exclusive or semi-exclusive primary ticketing deals with independent venues. Timeline: 24-36 months (long venue contract cycles). DOJ outcome could dramatically accelerate or eliminate this path.

falsification_criteria: DOJ antitrust case against Live Nation fails or results in minimal behavioral remedies rather than structural divestiture — Ticketmaster retains monopoly position
Live Nation preemptively reduces fees and improves venue terms, eliminating the value proposition of alternatives
Consumer network effects prove insurmountable — fans refuse to download alternative ticketing apps when Ticketmaster has 200M+ accounts
