models.name: Food Safety & Compliance Automation
models.one_liner: IoT sensor-based food safety monitoring and automated compliance documentation for restaurants and food service operations, targeting the $19.8B food safety compliance technology market by 2030
models.macro_source: Fact.MR food safety compliance technologies forecast ($19.8B by 2030); FDA FSMA regulations; QCEW NAICS 722 (12.1M workers, 703K establishments)

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): ComplianceMate (acquired by Emerson), Testo, and Therma (Google-backed) serve portions of the market but no dominant player exists for the full-service compliance stack (temperature monitoring + HACCP documentation + health inspection prep + employee training tracking). 703K food service establishments with only ~15% using automated monitoring = massive greenfield. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): IoT sensor hardware is increasingly commoditized, but the compliance rule engine (different regulations in 50 states + 3,000+ county health departments) and automated documentation create stickiness. Value Density is moderate (5): $100-300/month per location — low ARPU but mandatory spend once regulators enforce. Demand Visibility is proven (8): FDA FSMA enforcement tightening, health department inspection technology modernization, and brand liability concerns (a single foodborne illness outbreak can cost $75K-2M+ per incident) create non-discretionary demand.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Food safety compliance technologies market projected from $12.2B (2025) to $19.8B by 2030 (Fact.MR, 10.4% CAGR). Blockchain and traceability technologies expected to lead with 35% share. The regulatory tailwind is powerful: FDA FSMA (Food Safety Modernization Act) requires preventive controls and supply chain documentation for food service operations. The CDC estimates 48M foodborne illnesses annually in the US, resulting in 128,000 hospitalizations and 3,000 deaths — creating persistent regulatory pressure. For restaurants specifically: HACCP (Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points) compliance requires temperature logging, food handling documentation, and cleaning verification — traditionally done on paper clipboards. IoT sensors can automate temperature monitoring 24/7 (walk-in coolers, freezers, prep stations, serving lines), alerting managers before food spoilage occurs. ComplianceMate (acquired by Emerson for undisclosed) monitors 250,000+ sensors in food service. Therma (backed by Google's Area 120) raised $12.5M for refrigeration monitoring. The per-location economics: a single spoilage incident costs $2,000-10,000 in wasted food; a health department violation costs $500-5,000 in fines plus potential closure. Automated monitoring at $150-300/month prevents both. QCEW data shows food service contractors (722310, $37,468 avg pay) growing 11.6% — these institutional food operations (hospitals, schools, corporate) have the strictest compliance requirements and are the most receptive enterprise buyers.

Market openness is moderate-low due to OEM bundling, but the multi-fleet management gap is real. Value density is high: a single piece of heavy equipment costs $200K-$2M, and 10% better utilization saves $20K-$200K per unit per year.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction equipment fleet costs represent 15-25% of heavy/civil project budgets. The global construction equipment market: $186.62B by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets). Construction machinery telematics market: $3.18B (2025) to $6.62B (2030) at 15.83% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). Average equipment utilization on construction sites: 40-60% (meaning 40-60% idle time). Unplanned downtime costs: $1,000-$5,000 per hour for heavy equipment. AI predictive maintenance can reduce unplanned downtime 25-40% (Caterpillar data, Uptake deployments). Fuel costs: 15-30% of equipment operating costs, with 10-15% optimization potential through AI-driven idling reduction and route optimization. Autonomous equipment: Caterpillar has 500+ autonomous haul trucks in mining, with construction applications imminent (autonomous grading, excavation). The fleet intelligence platform opportunity: aggregate data across mixed fleets, optimize utilization (scheduling equipment across jobsites), predict maintenance needs, manage fuel consumption, and prepare for autonomous operations. Tenna ($100M+ raised) is the leading construction-specific fleet platform but focused on equipment tracking rather than AI optimization.

models.name: Wholesale Credit & Receivables Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI credit scoring and AR management for wholesale distributors — predicting customer payment behavior, automating collections, and reducing DSO from 48 to 35 days across $1.2T in wholesale receivables
models.macro_source: F1: AI credit scoring models outperforming traditional methods by 25-40% in B2B default prediction (McKinsey B2B Payments 2025). F4: $1.2T+ in wholesale trade receivables outstanding at any given time — working capital optimization is the single largest financial lever in distribution. Distributor DSO averages 45-50 days; reducing to 35 days frees $200B+ in working capital.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Wholesale distribution is a credit-intensive business: distributors extend net-30/60/90 payment terms to customers as a core value-add. At any given time, US wholesale trade has $1.2T+ in accounts receivable outstanding (Census Bureau, Quarterly Financial Report for wholesale trade). Average DSO: 45-50 days. Bad debt expense: 0.5-1.5% of revenue (higher in construction materials and food service where customer failure rates are elevated). For a $50M distributor operating at 4% EBITDA ($2M), bad debt of 1% ($500K) is 25% of profit. Reducing bad debt by half is equivalent to a 12% revenue increase on the bottom line. AI credit intelligence opportunity: (1) Real-time credit scoring using payment history (the distributor's own AR data), public financial signals (liens, judgments, UCC filings), business credit bureaus (D&B, Experian Business), and behavioral signals (order pattern changes that precede payment issues). (2) Automated collections — AI-powered dunning sequences that optimize timing, channel (email/text/call), and escalation based on customer payment behavior patterns. (3) Portfolio risk monitoring — real-time alerts when customer creditworthiness deteriorates (e.g., a construction contractor who just lost a major project). (4) Dynamic credit terms — adjusting net terms based on real-time risk assessment (offering net-60 to low-risk customers to win share, tightening to COD for high-risk). Incumbent: Dun & Bradstreet ($2.3B revenue) and Experian Business provide credit reports but are static, not real-time. Billtrust ($250M revenue, acquired by EQT for $1.7B in 2022) proved B2B AR automation has value but focused on invoice-to-cash, not credit intelligence.

cla.rationale: Market is open — Billtrust (invoice-to-cash) and D&B (static credit reports) leave a gap in real-time AI credit intelligence for distributors. Moat advantage is strong: cross-distributor payment data creates network-effect credit models (more distributors sharing data = more accurate predictions for all participants). Value chain depth spans credit scoring, AR management, collections automation, and dynamic terms — 4 monetizable layers. Demand visibility is high — every distributor CFO tracks DSO obsessively and can quantify the ROI of 1-day improvement.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.5B (B2B credit intelligence and AR automation for wholesale trade, growing 14% CAGR)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented — Billtrust ($250M revenue, invoice-to-cash), D&B ($2.3B, static credit), Experian Business (credit reports), Creditsafe (business credit). None offer real-time AI credit intelligence for wholesale distributors specifically.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $20K-$80K per distributor. Credit intelligence: $1K-3K/month. Collections automation: $500-2K/month. Portfolio monitoring: $500-1K/month. Gross margins 80%+. ROI is immediate: 1-day DSO improvement on $50M revenue = $137K in freed working capital. Performance-based pricing option: share of DSO improvement value (10-20% of working capital freed).
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Target 100 industrial/building materials distributors (highest DSO, most credit-intensive) at $50K ACV = $5M ARR. Wedge: AI credit scoring that demonstrably outperforms D&B Paydex by 25%+ in default prediction. NAW Credit Group provides industry access.

models.name: Automated Route Optimization & Dynamic Dispatch
models.one_liner: AI-powered route optimization and real-time dispatch platform reducing fuel costs 15-25% and improving fleet utilization for commercial carriers in the $8.0B route optimization market growing to $15.9B by 2030
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: route optimization software $8.0B (2025) to $15.9B (2030) at 14.7% CAGR. Diesel costs $3.50-5.50/gallon since 2022. Fuel accounts for 24-30% of trucking operating costs. Empty miles (deadhead) average 28% of total miles driven -- $100B+ in wasted capacity annually. AI optimization reduces empty miles 15-25% and fuel consumption 8-15%.

cla.rationale: Route optimization is a mature category with strong incumbents: Descartes (acquired PC*Miler), Trimble (ALK Technologies), ORTEC, Omnitracs, Locus (last-mile optimization). However, AI-native dynamic optimization (real-time re-routing based on traffic, weather, road closures, loading dock availability) is still nascent -- most existing tools do STATIC route planning, not DYNAMIC dispatch. The AI opportunity: ingest real-time signals (traffic, weather, customer receiving hours, driver HOS remaining, fuel prices by station) and continuously re-optimize routes throughout the day. The biggest value creation is in reducing EMPTY MILES: 28% of US truck miles are driven empty (deadhead). AI matching of backhaul loads and continuous route optimization can reduce deadhead to 15-20%, saving $25-50B annually across the industry.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US commercial trucking: 15.5M registered vehicles. Average truck drives 100K-120K miles/year. Fuel cost at $4/gallon on 6 MPG = $67-80K/year per truck. 28% empty miles = $100B+ in wasted fuel and capacity. Current route optimization adoption: 45% of large carriers (500+ trucks) use some form, but only 12% use AI-native dynamic optimization. Small carriers (<20 trucks): <5% use route optimization software. Diesel prices volatile: $3.50-5.50/gallon range since 2022. EV trucks introduce new optimization parameters (charging station location, battery range degradation, time-of-use electricity pricing). The dual-fleet transition (ICE + EV) creates complexity that AI is uniquely positioned to manage: which truck gets which route based on range requirements, charging infrastructure, and delivery deadlines. Route optimization for EV commercial fleets is essentially a new category with no incumbents.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in mid-market carriers (20-500 trucks) and specialized fleets (temperature-controlled, construction, waste management) where generic tools underperform. EV fleet optimization is a greenfield subcategory with zero incumbents. Must demonstrate fuel savings within 30 days or lose the customer.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing $50-200/truck/month. 100-truck fleet = $60-240K ARR. Gross margins 85%+ (pure software, cloud-based). Value creation: 8-15% fuel savings = $5-12K per truck per year. Software cost is 10-20% of savings delivered -- clear ROI.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-90 days for mid-market fleets (fuel savings are measurable immediately). Self-serve trial with 10-20 trucks, measure savings, then expand. Fuel price spikes create urgency: every $0.50/gallon increase drives fleet operators to seek optimization. EV fleet deployments create greenfield adoption windows.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Route data compounding: more routes driven = better traffic/weather/dock availability prediction models. Fleet-specific optimization: learning each fleet's customer receiving windows, driver preferences, and equipment constraints creates personalized optimization that generic tools cannot match. EV charging network data: integrating real-time charger availability across networks (ChargePoint, Tesla, Electrify America) creates data advantage for EV route optimization.

models.name: Ag Labor Management & H-2A Compliance Platform
models.one_liner: End-to-end seasonal farm labor platform: H-2A visa petition filing, DOL wage compliance, worker housing management, payroll with piece-rate/hourly blending, and crew scheduling -- serving 17,000+ H-2A employer agents filing 378K worker petitions annually in the most complex labor compliance environment in US agriculture
models.macro_source: F3: H-2A certified positions grew from 200K (FY2017) to 378K (FY2023), 89% increase, reflecting domestic labor unavailability. Immigration enforcement simultaneously tightens supply of undocumented workers, pushing MORE employers into H-2A. F2: Average hired farmworker age 41 (NAWS 2023), domestic farm labor force shrinking 2-3% annually. F5: H-2A compliance failures carry severe penalties: debarment (3-year ban) and back-pay liability of $50K-$500K per violation.
models.deep_dive_evidence: H-2A Temporary Agricultural Worker Program: 378K certified positions (FY2023), 17,600+ employer applications (DOL OFLC data). Growth rate: 12-15% annually for past 7 years, accelerating as undocumented labor supply tightens. H-2A compliance is EXTREMELY COMPLEX: (1) Adverse Effect Wage Rate (AEWR): set by DOL per state, $14.12-$19.75/hr (2024), must pay higher of AEWR, prevailing wage, or federal/state minimum. (2) Housing: employer must provide free housing meeting OSHA standards to all H-2A workers. (3) Transportation: employer pays inbound/outbound transportation from home country. (4) Three-quarter guarantee: must offer work for at least 75% of contract period. (5) Corresponding workers: domestic applicants get same terms as H-2A workers. Filing cost per worker: $2,000-$4,000 (attorney fees, filing fees, recruitment advertising). Total H-2A compliance cost: $3B-$5B/year industry-wide. Current solutions: immigration attorneys ($300-$500/hr), farm labor contractors (FLCs, who handle compliance for a fee but often poorly), and paper-based record-keeping. NO dominant software platform serves the H-2A lifecycle. AgriLegal is niche. Seso ($50M raised, YC W20) is the emerging leader, handling H-2A filing + payroll + housing management for 2,000+ farms. Farmworker Compliance Solutions (small). The market is structurally growing 12-15%/year because H-2A is the ONLY legal path for seasonal farm labor, and enforcement of I-9/E-Verify is pushing farms from undocumented to H-2A.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high: Seso is the only funded startup in this space, serving 2,000 of 17,600+ H-2A employers (11%). 89% of the market is unserved by any software platform. Moat advantage is strong because H-2A regulatory complexity creates deep domain expertise barriers (DOL, USCIS, OSHA housing standards, state-specific wage rules). Once a farm runs payroll and compliance through the platform, switching costs are extremely high (mid-season switch = compliance risk). Value density is high: $5-15K/year per farm employer is a fraction of the $50K-$500K penalty risk for non-compliance. Demand visibility is exceptional: H-2A is growing 12-15% annually by DOL data, creating a growing market with compounding urgency.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $500M-$1.2B (H-2A compliance software + ag labor management, growing at 12-15% annually with program growth)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: wide open
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Per-employer ACV: $5-15K/year for filing + payroll + housing. Per-worker transaction fee: $200-$500 for H-2A petition processing. At 378K workers and 17,600 employers: $88M-$264M from employer subscriptions, $75M-$189M from per-worker fees. Gross margins 75-85%. Low CAC: compliance deadline-driven sales, farm bureau and ag lender referrals.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Sign 500-700 H-2A employers at $8K average ACV. Focus on top H-2A states: Florida (48K positions), Georgia (32K), California (28K), Washington (25K), North Carolina (24K). First $5M ARR in year 2. Expand to full farm labor management (non-H-2A seasonal, year-round) for same customer base. Seso has first-mover advantage but the market is growing fast enough (12-15%/year) for a second entrant.

falsification_criteria: If comprehensive immigration reform creates a new agricultural visa category that is simpler than H-2A, reducing the compliance complexity that drives software demand
If H-2A program growth stalls or reverses due to political restrictions on legal immigration
If Seso achieves dominant market position (>30% of H-2A filings), closing the window for new entrants

models.name: Critical Minerals Exploration & Resource Estimation Platform
models.one_liner: Machine learning platform integrating geological, geophysical, geochemical, and satellite data to predict critical mineral deposits and optimize resource estimation — targeting $4.3B mining AI market by 2030 in a sector where US import dependency on 17 minerals is 100% and exploration success rates remain below 1%
models.macro_source: USGS 2024 Mineral Commodity Summaries: US 100% import-dependent for 17 minerals, >50% for 29 others. IRA provides $7B+ in mining incentives including 10% critical minerals production tax credit. Mining AI market $1.8B (2024) to $4.3B (2030) at 15.6% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). Historical exploration success rate: 0.1-1% of prospects become mines. KoBold Metals (Gates/Bezos-backed) raised $491M for AI mineral exploration. DOD critical minerals investment $439M (2022-2024). Lithium demand +500% by 2030. Copper demand +50% by 2035.
models.deep_dive_evidence: The global mineral exploration budget was $13.1B in 2024 (S&P Global), recovering from a 2020 low of $8.7B. Critical minerals (lithium, copper, cobalt, nickel, rare earths) now account for 45%+ of exploration spending, up from 25% in 2018. Despite $200B+ spent on exploration globally over the past decade, the rate of Tier 1 discoveries has declined 80% since 1990 (MinEx Consulting). The ore bodies being found are deeper, lower grade, and harder to extract — the 'easy' deposits were found decades ago. AI exploration addresses this by integrating heterogeneous datasets that human geologists cannot process simultaneously: satellite spectral imagery (Sentinel-2, Landsat), airborne geophysical surveys (magnetics, radiometrics, gravity, electromagnetics), soil/stream geochemistry, drilling records, and geological mapping. KoBold Metals claims its AI platform has identified targets across 4 continents, with its Mingomba copper-cobalt discovery in Zambia being the most significant new find in the Congo-Zambia copper belt in decades. Goldspot Discoveries (TSX: SPOT) has completed 100+ AI exploration projects across 16 countries. Earth AI (Australia) uses AI to identify targets for battery metals, claiming a 300% improvement in drill-to-discovery rates. The US Department of Energy's ARPA-E funded $30M in AI mineral exploration R&D (2023-2024). The USGS Earth Mapping Resources Initiative (Earth MRI) is creating the baseline geoscience data that these AI systems consume — $320M appropriated through 2030. Key constraint: geological data is sparse, heterogeneous, and often proprietary. A platform that aggregates and standardizes geological data from government surveys, historical mining records, and modern sensor networks has a massive data moat.

cla.rationale: KoBold Metals ($491M raised, backed by Breakthrough Energy) is the highest-profile AI exploration company, but its model is vertically integrated (AI exploration → acquire mineral rights → develop mines) rather than SaaS. Other players: Minerva Intelligence (geological AI, public, small-cap), Goldspot Discoveries, Earth AI. MO is 5 because KoBold's vertical integration means they are a competitor AND a validation signal. MA is 8 because proprietary geological datasets compound — each exploration campaign adds training data that improves the model. More holes drilled = better predictions. VD is 7 because a single Tier 1 mineral discovery is worth $1-10B+ in NPV, making the per-exploration-dollar ROI potentially enormous. DV is 6 — demand for critical minerals exploration is proven (federal funding, IRA incentives, OEM supply anxiety) but exploration budgets are cyclical with commodity prices.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.3B mining AI market by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets). Exploration-specific AI: $800M-1.5B by 2030 (estimated 20-35% of mining AI directed at exploration/resource estimation). Broader addressable: $13.1B annual global exploration budget, of which 15-25% could shift to AI-guided targeting = $2-3.3B.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible because mining majors are data-rich but AI-poor — they have decades of drilling records, assay results, and geological surveys but lack the ML engineering to exploit them. The SaaS exploration analytics model (vs KoBold's vertical integration) may be more capital-efficient: sell the picks and shovels, don't dig the mine. Key risk: mining companies are notoriously slow to adopt external software (7-10 year procurement cycles). Entry strategy: government-funded exploration programs (USGS Earth MRI, DOD critical minerals) as initial customers, then expand to juniors and mid-tier miners.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $200K-1M/year per mining company for AI-guided target generation and resource estimation. Project-based: $50-200K per exploration program analysis. Gross margins 70-80% (compute-intensive but high-value output). Success-based pricing option: 1-2% royalty on discoveries made using platform targets. Enterprise ACV target: $500K for mid-tier miners, $2-5M for majors.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: IRA tax credits create urgency for domestic exploration. DOD contracts provide non-dilutive funding ($439M allocated). Lithium exploration surge: 200+ lithium projects announced in the US since 2022. Copper exploration budgets at 10-year highs. USGS Earth MRI creating the public data foundation. Junior miners (exploration-stage companies) are most receptive — 2,000+ listed on TSX alone.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding is the primary moat: every exploration campaign the platform participates in adds labeled training data (drill results confirming or denying predictions). This is extremely difficult to replicate — you need thousands of real-world drilling outcomes to train effective models. Geological domain expertise embedded in feature engineering creates a second moat: knowing which geophysical signatures correlate with porphyry copper vs volcanogenic massive sulfide deposits is specialized knowledge. Government data partnerships (USGS, state geological surveys) provide preferential access.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) AI-generated exploration targets demonstrate no statistically significant improvement over expert geologist picks by 2029, undermining the core value proposition; (2) Critical mineral prices collapse (lithium below $8K/tonne sustained) eliminating exploration budgets; (3) Geological data remains siloed in proprietary databases, preventing the data aggregation that creates the platform's advantage; (4) Major mining companies build equivalent AI exploration capabilities in-house (BHP, Rio Tinto, and Newmont all have internal data science teams); (5) Permitting timelines remain at 7-10 years, making new US discoveries uneconomic regardless of exploration efficiency.

models.name: Mine Site Environmental Monitoring & Remediation Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered environmental compliance platform for mine water management, tailings monitoring, air quality tracking, and closure/remediation planning — targeting $4.8B mine environmental services market where ESG compliance costs major miners $2-5B/year and 500,000+ legacy abandoned mine sites in the US require $50B+ in remediation
models.macro_source: EPA: 500,000+ abandoned mine sites in US, $50B+ estimated remediation cost. IIJA: $11.3B for abandoned mine land reclamation. Major miner ESG spending: BHP $3.5B/year, Rio Tinto $2.8B/year, Freeport-McMoRan $1.2B/year on environmental compliance. Tailings dam failures: 2019 Brumadinho (270 deaths), 2014 Mount Polley — triggered global regulatory response (Global Industry Standard on Tailings Management, GISTM). Mine environmental services market $4.8B by 2028 (Allied Market Research). ESG reporting requirements expanding: EU CSRD, SEC climate disclosure, ISSB standards all require mine-level environmental data.
models.sector_name: Support Activities for Mining — Environmental Services
models.deep_dive_evidence: Mining is the most environmentally regulated industrial activity in the US, governed by overlapping federal (EPA, BLM, Army Corps, MSHA), state (DEQ equivalents), and increasingly international (GISTM) frameworks. Key environmental challenges: (1) WATER MANAGEMENT — mines alter hydrology (dewatering, process water, acid mine drainage). Acid mine drainage (AMD) is the single largest environmental legacy of mining — when sulfide minerals in waste rock are exposed to air and water, they generate sulfuric acid that mobilizes heavy metals. AMD treatment at legacy sites costs $1-10M/year indefinitely. Active mines must manage water balances across pits, tailings, process circuits, and discharge points. (2) TAILINGS — the fine-grained waste from mineral processing stored in engineered dams. There are ~1,800 active tailings storage facilities (TSFs) in the US and 18,000+ globally (UNEP). The 2019 Brumadinho dam failure in Brazil (270 deaths) triggered the Global Industry Standard on Tailings Management (GISTM), requiring real-time stability monitoring, independent reviews, and public disclosure. GISTM compliance costs $5-50M per TSF. (3) AIR QUALITY — particulate matter (PM10, PM2.5) from blasting, crushing, hauling, and wind erosion. Silica exposure regulations tightened in 2024 (MSHA new permissible exposure limit 50 μg/m3, down from 100 μg/m3). (4) CLOSURE/REMEDIATION — every operating mine in the US must post a financial assurance (bond) for closure costs. The $50B+ estimate for abandoned mine land remediation (EPA) represents liability without a responsible party. The IIJA allocated $11.3B for abandoned mine reclamation. Active mine closure bonds average $10-100M per site. The platform opportunity integrates: real-time sensor data from water quality stations, piezometers (tailings stability), dust monitors, and weather stations into a unified environmental dashboard. AI predictive models forecast AMD generation, tailings stability (using pore pressure trends), and dust exceedances. Automated regulatory reporting (EPA DMR, state discharge permits, MSHA respirable dust) reduces compliance labor 40-60%. Closure cost modeling uses LiDAR terrain data, geochemical predictions, and revegetation monitoring to optimize reclamation plans.

cla.rationale: MO is 7 because mine environmental monitoring is fragmented across specialized consultancies (SRK Consulting, Golder/WSP, Wood PLC, Stantec) and generic environmental platforms (Enviro.io, Locus Technologies, Cority). No dominant mine-specific environmental compliance platform exists. MA is 8 because mine-specific environmental models compound with site data — water balance models, geochemical predictions, and closure cost estimates improve with years of site-specific monitoring data. VD is 7 because environmental non-compliance can cost $50K-10M per violation (EPA penalties) and mine closure/remediation obligations represent $100M-1B+ per mine in liabilities. DV is 8 — regulatory compliance demand is non-cyclical and INCREASING (ESG requirements, GISTM, SEC climate disclosure).

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=regulatory_moat_builder, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.8B mine environmental services market by 2028 (Allied Market Research). Software/analytics layer: $800M-1.5B (estimated 15-30% of environmental services market shifting from consulting hours to software). Abandoned mine remediation: $11.3B IIJA allocation creates immediate federal project pipeline. Direct addressable: 12,000+ active mines x $50-200K/year environmental compliance software = $600M-2.4B.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture highly feasible — mine environmental compliance is currently managed through a combination of spreadsheets, paper logs, and consulting reports. No dominant platform exists. Entry strategy: target mines with active GISTM compliance requirements (largest tailings facilities), then expand to water management and air quality. The regulatory moat is real: understanding the interplay between EPA NPDES permits, state discharge permits, MSHA dust regulations, and GISTM requirements is deep domain knowledge that generic environmental platforms lack.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $10-25K/month per mine site for full environmental compliance platform. 150-mine deployment = $18-45M ARR. Gross margins 75-80% (sensor integration + analytics + regulatory reporting). Customer payback: avoiding 1 EPA penalty ($50K-10M) or reducing environmental consulting spend 20-30% ($100-500K/year per mine) provides clear ROI. Implementation: $50-200K per site for sensor integration and calibration.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: GISTM compliance deadline driving tailings monitoring upgrades globally. MSHA silica rule (2024) creating new air quality compliance burden. IIJA abandoned mine reclamation funding creating $11.3B federal project pipeline. SEC climate disclosure rule requires mine-level environmental data for publicly listed miners. Insurance carriers pricing tailings dam risk into mining insurance premiums — digital monitoring reduces premiums 10-20%. ESG-linked financing (green bonds, sustainability-linked loans) requires verifiable environmental data.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Regulatory depth moat: understanding EPA, MSHA, BLM, Army Corps, state DEQ, and GISTM requirements in combination is specialized knowledge. Site-specific environmental models compound (water balance, geochemical prediction, tailings stability) with years of monitoring data. Sensor integration across multiple vendors (Campbell Scientific, Geokon, RST Instruments, Ott HydroMet) creates platform switching costs. Regulatory reporting automation (EPA DMR, state permits) creates workflow lock-in.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) Major environmental consultancies (WSP, Stantec, SRK) build equivalent digital platforms, eliminating the technology gap between consulting services and software; (2) Mining companies keep environmental data internal due to legal liability concerns (environmental data can be used against operators in enforcement actions); (3) ESG reporting fatigue causes regulatory rollback (Trump administration rolled back some EPA mining regulations in 2017-2020; similar deregulation could reduce compliance urgency); (4) Tailings monitoring hardware remains non-standardized (each sensor vendor has proprietary data formats), making data integration impractical.

models.name: EU Act Compliance Automation Engine
models.one_liner: Automated compliance platform that continuously monitors AI systems against EU AI Act's risk-based requirements -- going beyond V3-GEO-004's advisory model to embed compliance-as-code into AI deployment pipelines for the 450M-person EU market
models.macro_source: EU AI Act entered force February 2025 with phased enforcement through 2027. Every AI system deployed in the EU must be classified by risk tier and documented accordingly. High-risk systems (employment, credit, healthcare, law enforcement) require conformity assessments, human oversight plans, and continuous monitoring. V3-GEO-004 exists as a service platform for advisory, but the real opportunity is compliance-as-code: embedded software that automatically classifies AI models, generates required documentation, monitors for drift, and flags non-compliance. This parallels how SOC 2 compliance tools (Vanta, Drata) automated what was previously consulting work. The EU market (450M people, $18T GDP) is non-optional for any global AI company.
models.sector_name: Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance
models.deep_dive_evidence: EU AI Act: entered force Feb 2025, prohibited AI practices banned immediately, high-risk system requirements phased in through 2027. Fines up to 7% of global revenue for non-compliance (vs GDPR's 4%). Every company deploying AI in EU needs: (1) risk classification per system, (2) conformity assessment for high-risk, (3) transparency documentation, (4) human oversight protocols, (5) continuous monitoring for performance drift and bias. Current compliance is manual (legal teams + consultants at $500-1000/hour). Automated compliance-as-code could reduce cost 80-90%. TAM: every company deploying AI in EU = potentially 100K+ organizations in first 3 years. SOC 2 compliance automation precedent: Vanta reached $2.5B valuation automating a much simpler compliance requirement. EU AI Act compliance is 10x more complex than SOC 2. Revenue model: SaaS per AI system monitored ($500-5000/month per system, depending on risk tier).

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=compliance_automation, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance successfully deploy equivalent AI internally

models.name: Private Credit Underwriting Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered underwriting and portfolio monitoring for private credit funds -- the dominant distress liquidity source as PE refinancing wall ($1.5-1.8T 2026-2028) forces credit restructuring at unprecedented scale.

structural_drivers: PE refinancing wall: $930B CRE + $1.5-1.8T total maturities 2026-2028 creates unprecedented distressed credit volume
Private credit has displaced banks as dominant non-bank lending source -- $1.7T+ AUM and growing
NAICS 52391 Miscellaneous Intermediation: extreme fragmentation (9,725 establishments, 0.284 fragmentation proxy)
Traditional credit underwriting requires 2-4 weeks per deal; AI compresses to 2-4 days for standard structures
Distressed asset evaluation requires rapid due diligence -- speed premium during refinancing wall

F1_technology.mechanism: AI parses financial statements, covenant packages, collateral documentation, and market comparables at 10x speed of human underwriters. NLP extracts risk signals from unstructured deal documents.

F4_capital.mechanism: PE refinancing wall creates $1.5-1.8T of maturity events requiring credit assessment. Private credit funds deploying $200B+/year need faster, more accurate underwriting to capture distressed opportunities.

F3_geopolitics.mechanism: Higher-for-longer rates (3.50-3.75% FFR) sustain private credit advantage over bank lending. Cross-border credit flows create multi-jurisdiction underwriting complexity.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $100-500K/yr per credit fund client (tiered by AUM and deal volume)
unit_economics.cost_advantage: 3-5x vs traditional underwriting team ($200K/yr platform vs $600K-$1M underwriting staff for equivalent throughput)
unit_economics.break_even: 30-50 private credit fund subscriptions at $200K avg ARR

fear_friction.note: Credit professionals are quantitative but cautious -- bad underwriting = bad loans. Resolution: AI as screening layer (processes 10x more deals) with human credit committee final approval. Position as deal flow expansion not judgment replacement.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Banks have internal credit models. FinTech lenders (Upstart, etc.) serve consumer credit. Enterprise private credit underwriting AI: <5 entrants. Distressed credit evaluation is the least-served niche.
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: Private credit AUM $1.7T+ with 3-5% management fees = $50-85B revenue pool. Underwriting tools at 1-2% of revenue = $500M-$1.7B addressable. Growing 15-20% annually.
deep_dive_evidence.note: Counter-cyclical: recessions increase distressed credit volume, which increases underwriting demand. PE refinancing wall is a time-specific catalyst (2026-2028) that elevates timing grade.

models.name: PE Healthcare Distress Turnaround Operating System
models.one_liner: Acquire fragmented healthcare businesses at 3-5x EBITDA, modernize operations with AI, and scale through roll-up consolidation

deep_dive_evidence.pe_healthcare_data: 30% of US hospitals PE-backed (~1,800 facilities). Major PE healthcare platforms: KKR (Envision), Cerberus (Steward Health Care — already in bankruptcy), Apollo (LifePoint), Leonard Green (Surgery Partners). Steward Health Care's 2024 bankruptcy is the canary for the sector.
deep_dive_evidence.refinancing_wall: $930B PE refinancing wall maturing 2026-2027. Healthcare-specific PE debt estimated at $80-120B of this total. Interest rate spread widening for PE healthcare: 200-400bps premium over 2021 levels. Lenders requiring demonstrated operational improvement for refinancing approval.

models.macro_source: 30% of US hospitals are PE-backed. $930B PE refinancing wall maturing 2026-2027. PE healthcare deals were underwritten at 6-8x EBITDA with assumptions about margin expansion that have not materialized. COVID staffing costs, travel nurse premiums (80-150%), and supply chain inflation eroded margins. These systems need immediate operational improvement to survive refinancing. AI operational tools (RCM, staffing, supply chain, clinical workflow optimization) deployed as an integrated operating system = the turnaround playbook. This is not a single-point solution — it is the complete AI toolkit that a distressed healthcare operator needs.

models.name: Construction Lending & Draw Management Fintech
models.one_liner: Digital platform automating construction loan draw management, progress verification, and lien tracking for the $480B annual US construction lending market -- reducing 74-day draw cycles to under 10 days and eliminating the $40B slow-payment economic drag
models.macro_source: F4: $480B annual US construction loans with manual draw processes averaging 74 days. $40B slow-payment economic impact (Rabbet/Levelset data). Built Technologies ($135B financed, unicorn valuation) validates category. Billd raised $7.3M (Nov 2025) for subcontractor financing.

cla.rationale: Built Technologies is the clear category leader ($135B financed, 200K+ projects, unicorn valuation, ~300 lending institution partners). This limits market openness for a direct competitor on the lender side. However, Built serves LENDERS (bank-side platform). The BORROWER/CONTRACTOR side remains underserved. Additionally, the subcontractor payment layer (Billd, Levelset/Procore, Material Financials) is fragmented. The opportunity is either: (1) contractor-side draw management that integrates with Built/lenders, or (2) the full subcontractor payment acceleration stack (combining lending, lien management, payment acceleration). Value density is very high: construction financing is $480B annual, and even small efficiency improvements generate significant revenue.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US construction lending: ~$480B annually. Average draw request processing: 74 days (Rabbet data), creating massive cash flow problems for contractors and subcontractors. Slow payments cost the construction industry $40B/year (Levelset research). Lien law complexity: 50 different state lien statutes, creating compliance nightmares. Built Technologies: unicorn valuation, ~300 lending institution partners, $135B in construction value financed since 2015. The platform automates inspection scheduling, draw approval, budget tracking, and disbursement for banks. Billd ($7.3M raised Nov 2025): focuses on giving subcontractors 120-day payment terms for materials, addressing the sub-tier cash flow crisis. Rabbet: construction loan monitoring for lenders. The contractor/sub side remains largely manual: 60%+ of subcontractors report cash flow as their #1 business challenge. Construction-specific financial products (progress-based lending, retainage financing, performance bond alternatives) represent a $5-10B fintech opportunity beyond Built's lender-side platform.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Interest rate cuts to sub-3% re-liquefy capital markets, eliminating distressed asset opportunities

Path to $150M ARR via payment acceleration fees (1-3% of accelerated payments) + SaaS ($500-$2K/month). Billd proves sub-tier financing demand.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Payment acceleration: 1-3% fee on accelerated payments (average sub payment $25-75K). SaaS: $6K-$24K ACV. models.name: Smart Port & Terminal Operations Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered digital twin platform for port and terminal operations -- vessel scheduling, yard management, crane optimization, and gate automation in the $2.5-4.5B smart port market growing to $7.9-16.9B by 2030 at 19.8-25.8% CAGR
models.macro_source: MarketsandMarkets: smart port market $2.5B (2025) to $7.95B (2030) at 25.8% CAGR. Mordor Intelligence: $4.5B (2025) to $11.1B (2030) at 19.8% CAGR. Grand View Research: $3.2B (2024) to $14.6B (2030) at 29.8% CAGR. US handles 25.8M TEUs annually across 360 ports. Port congestion costs estimated $25B+ annually in supply chain delays.

cla.rationale: Port operations technology is dominated by legacy TOS (Terminal Operating System) vendors: Navis (Cargotec, ~60% global market share for container terminals), Tideworks (SSA Marine subsidiary), Cosmos (HHLA). Digital twin and AI optimization represent a technology paradigm shift from these transaction-processing systems. Key players in smart port: Siemens (port logistics), ABB (automation), Kalmar (terminal automation equipment). The AI/digital twin layer that OPTIMIZES operations on top of existing TOS is the startup opportunity. MO is 5 because port authorities are conservative buyers with long procurement cycles. MA is 7 because port digital twin models require 12-18 months of operational data to calibrate -- deep switching costs once deployed.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US port system: 360 ports handling 25.8M TEUs (2024). Port congestion costs: $25B+ annually in supply chain delays and demurrage charges. Average container dwell time in US ports: 4.2 days (2x pre-COVID). Automated terminals (Long Beach, Virginia) show 30-40% throughput improvement vs manual operations. Digital twin applications: vessel berth scheduling (reduce wait time 20-35%), yard container positioning (reduce truck turn time 25-40%), crane sequencing (improve moves/hour 15-25%), gate appointment systems (reduce gate congestion 40-60%). Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act: $17B for port infrastructure including technology modernization. Only 12 of 360 US ports have significant automation -- 95%+ of terminals still primarily manual operations. Shanghai, Singapore, and Rotterdam are 5-10 years ahead of US ports in digital twin adoption. The catch-up opportunity is massive but requires patient capital (port procurement cycles are 2-5 years).
falsification_criteria: Hardware component costs fail to decline on expected trajectory
Software-only solutions prove sufficient, eliminating need for specialized hardware
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.0-6B by 2030 (smart port AI + digital twin software on $8-17B total smart port market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture challenging due to long procurement cycles (2-5 years) and conservative port authority buyers. Best entry strategy: start with private terminal operators (who move faster than public port authorities) or international ports (Singapore, UAE more tech-forward). Then bring proven technology to US ports. Alternatively, target inland port/rail intermodal terminals which have shorter procurement cycles.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Enterprise SaaS: $500K-5M/year per terminal depending on size and scope. Implementation services $200K-1M. Gross margins 70-80%. But sales cycle is extremely long (2-5 years from first contact to contract) and implementation is 12-18 months. Requires patient capital.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 2-5 years for port authorities, 12-18 months for private terminal operators. IIJA funding creates accelerated procurement windows (use-it-or-lose-it federal grants). International ports (especially Middle East and Southeast Asia) move 2-3x faster than US ports. Container volume growth creates urgency as existing manual processes hit capacity ceilings.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Digital twin calibration data: 12-18 months of operational data per terminal creates models that competitors cannot replicate without similar deployment time. Port-specific customization (each terminal has unique layout, equipment, labor rules) creates switching costs. Reference installations: winning 3-5 marquee ports creates credibility that is nearly impossible to replicate. Integration with vessel tracking (AIS), weather, and customs systems creates data moat.

models.one_liner: AI-powered food procurement, inventory optimization, and waste reduction platform for multi-unit restaurants, addressing the $162B annual food waste problem in a $9.2B inventory software market by 2030
models.macro_source: GlobeNewsWire restaurant inventory management software forecast ($9.17B by 2030, 15% CAGR); USDA food waste data ($162B annual restaurant food waste); QCEW NAICS 722 sector economics

Moat Advantage is strong (7): price data compounding across thousands of restaurant purchase histories creates unique pricing intelligence that individual operators cannot access. Integration with distributor APIs, POS waste tracking, and menu engineering creates deep embedding. Value Density is moderate (6): $300-800/month ARPU from multi-unit operators; value proposition is 5-15% food cost reduction on 28-35% of restaurant revenue going to COGS. Demand Visibility is proven (8): food cost inflation (+5-8% in 2024-2025) and labor shortages driving urgent need for waste reduction and procurement efficiency.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Restaurant inventory management software market projected to reach $9.17B by 2030 from $3.95B in 2024 (GlobeNewsWire, 15% CAGR). USDA estimates US restaurants waste 30-40% of food purchased, totaling $162B in annual losses. For a restaurant with $1M in revenue and 30% food cost ($300K), reducing waste by 10% saves $30K/year — often the difference between profit and loss at 3-9% net margins. QCEW data: NAICS 722 has $322.7B in total annual wages across 703K establishments, with food costs adding another $300-400B. The supply chain is uniquely fragmented: 1,000+ food distributors, 150,000+ food manufacturers, wildly variable pricing. Sysco ($76B revenue) and US Foods ($37B) together control ~35% but use pricing opacity as a profit tool. AI-powered procurement can aggregate purchasing data across thousands of independent restaurants to identify price discrepancies, predict demand (reducing over-ordering), and optimize menus for food cost (menu engineering). The regulatory tailwind is real: California SB 1383 requires 75% reduction in organic waste by 2025, creating compliance pressure. Food service contractors (722310, growing 11.6% YoY) represent a concentrated buyer segment — Compass Group, Aramark, and Sodexo collectively operate 50,000+ kitchens.

vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Multi-unit operators (10+ locations) are the beachhead: ~50,000 establishments controlled by buyers who can make centralized procurement decisions. vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Measurable ROI within 60 days (first month of food cost data reveals savings opportunities). Multi-unit chains can deploy across 10-50 locations in 30 days once the pilot succeeds. Seasonal food cost spikes (summer produce, holiday proteins) create natural urgency windows for sales.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Pricing data network effect: each restaurant's purchasing data improves price benchmarking for all users. Once procurement workflows route through the platform, switching costs are high (vendor relationships, historical data, menu engineering tied to the system). Regulatory compliance features (waste tracking, FSMA documentation) add non-discretionary stickiness.

models.name: Building Permit & Code Compliance Automation
models.one_liner: AI platform that automates building permit applications, plan reviews, and code compliance checks across 19,000+ US jurisdictions -- targeting the $8.2B building code compliance market growing to $17.5B by 2032 at 8.8% CAGR
models.macro_source: F1: NLP/AI can parse building codes and check plan compliance automatically. F6: Energy code compliance becoming more complex (IECC 2024 requires 15-25% improvement). Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR (Coherent Market Insights). PermitFlow and GovBuilt validating the category.

cla.rationale: The permit/code compliance space is early and fragmented. PermitFlow (YC W22, $31M+ raised) leads the contractor-side permit filing category. GovBuilt and Accela serve the government side (plan review, permit issuance). Salesforce Government has entered permitting. The two-sided nature (government and contractor) creates complexity. Market openness is high for AI-powered automated plan review: currently plan reviews take 4-16 weeks and are done manually by under-staffed building departments. AI that pre-checks plans against building codes before submission (reducing rejection rate from 30%+ to <5%) creates enormous value for both sides. Energy code compliance is the fastest-growing complexity driver (IECC 2024, Title 24, LL97). Value density is moderate per permit but high in aggregate: 1.5M building permits issued annually in the US.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR (Coherent Market Insights). 19,000+ building jurisdictions in the US, each with potentially different code amendments. Average permit review time: 4-16 weeks. First-time plan rejection rate: 30-50% (plans fail code check, must be revised and resubmitted). 1.5M+ building permits issued annually. PermitFlow ($31M+ raised) automates permit applications (filing, tracking, expediting) for contractors -- claims 75% time reduction. But the BIGGER opportunity is automated plan review: using AI to check architectural/engineering plans against building codes BEFORE submission. This is the 10x value creation because it eliminates the 4-16 week review cycle and 30-50% rejection rate. Energy code complexity is exploding: IECC 2024 requires energy modeling, blower door tests, and thermal bridging calculations that most small builders cannot perform without software assistance. 70% of firms in developed regions already rely on software for LEED compliance. Accela dominates the government permitting platform market but has not built AI plan review. The integration play: AI pre-check on contractor side + digital submission to government + automated review on government side = end-to-end digitization.
falsification_criteria: Regulatory environment simplifies, reducing demand for automated compliance
Large consulting firms (Big 4) build competitive compliance automation platforms
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

(2) Municipalities: 19K+ jurisdictions willing to pay $10-100K/year for digital permitting and AI plan review. Path to $100M ARR serving 5K contractor firms + 2K municipalities.

Government partnerships create long-term contracts (3-5 year terms). Network effects: contractors prefer jurisdictions with faster permitting, creating demand pull.

models.name: Livestock Health Monitoring & Feed Optimization System
models.one_liner: Ear-tag sensor and computer vision platform that detects bovine respiratory disease 48hrs before clinical signs, optimizes individual-animal feed rations in feedlots, and tracks weight gain per livestock unit day -- targeting the 92M US cattle herd across 882K operations
models.macro_source: F1: Livestock health monitoring market $2.4B (2025) to $5.1B (2030) at 16.3% CAGR (Grand View Research). BRD costs $900M-$1B/year in US feedlots (USDA ERS). F2: Average cattle rancher age 58.2 years -- oldest sub-sector in agriculture. F6: EPA methane supplemental rule (2024) targeting 30% reduction in livestock methane by 2030, creating regulatory push for feed optimization (methane inhibitor additives like 3-NOP require precise per-animal dosing).
models.deep_dive_evidence: US cattle inventory: 87.2M head (Jan 2025, USDA), down from 98.8M in 2019 -- lowest since 1951 due to drought-driven herd liquidation. Feedlot sector: ~26,000 feedlots, but 2,100 large feedlots (1,000+ head capacity) finish 80%+ of beef. Average feedlot cost of gain: $1.10-$1.40/lb, of which feed is 65-75%. Bovine respiratory disease (BRD): #1 cause of feedlot death, costs $900M-$1B/year in treatment, mortality, and reduced performance (Kansas State University, 2023). Current BRD detection is visual: pen riders on horseback identifying sick animals by behavior -- 50-60% sensitivity. AI systems (ear tags with temperature, accelerometer + computer vision) detect BRD 48-72 hours earlier with 85-90% sensitivity (validated by Merck Animal Health Smart Tag trials, 2023-2024). Early detection reduces treatment cost from $35-50/head to $15-25/head and cuts mortality 40-60%. Feed optimization: precision feeding (adjusting ration by individual pen or individual animal based on intake, weight gain, and market weight targets) saves $15-30/head over a 150-day feeding period. At $3-5/head/feeding period for the monitoring system, ROI is 3-8x. Key players: Merck Animal Health (MSD), Allflex/MSD (ear tags), CattleEye (computer vision, UK), Vytelle (genetics + monitoring, raised $80M), HerdDogg (IoT ear tags). Market is fragmented with no dominant AI platform integrating health + feed + performance.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate: Allflex dominates ear tags (hardware) but the AI analytics layer is nascent and fragmented. No one integrates health monitoring, feed optimization, and performance analytics into a single platform. Moat builds through animal-level outcome data (correlating sensor data with health events, feed conversion, carcass grade). Value density is moderate per head ($3-5/head/period) but large feedlots (10K-100K head) generate $30K-$500K/year ACV. Demand visibility is high: BRD losses are quantifiable and every feedlot manager knows their death loss percentage.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=physical_production_ai, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.2-2.5B (livestock health monitoring + feed optimization for US cattle, subset of $5.1B global livestock monitoring market)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: $3-5/head/feeding period (150 days). Large feedlot (50K head capacity, 2.3 turns/year): $345K-$575K ACV. Mid-size feedlot (5K head): $34K-$58K ACV. Hardware cost: $8-15/ear tag (reusable across 3-5 turns). Gross margins 55-65% (hardware drag on margins). Camera systems: $2-5K per pen, 50-100 pens per large feedlot.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Win 15-20 large feedlots (20K+ head capacity) at $250K-$400K ACV. Requires 12-18 month pilot proving BRD detection improvement and feed savings. Feedlot managers are pragmatic -- show me the death loss reduction and I will pay. First $5M ARR in year 3 with 20 large feedlot customers. Expand to dairy (9.4M cows, similar monitoring needs) for second growth vector.

falsification_criteria: If Merck/Allflex vertically integrates health monitoring AI into their ear tag platform and bundles it with pharmaceutical sales, locking out independent analytics
If US cattle herd continues declining below 80M head, reducing the addressable market below critical mass for technology ROI
If feedlot consolidation accelerates to the point where top 50 feedlots control 60%+ of capacity, enabling them to build proprietary systems rather than buy

models.name: Recreation & Outdoor Activity Booking Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered marketplace connecting consumers with recreation activities — golf, skiing, bowling, fitness, outdoor experiences — across 87K fragmented establishments averaging $27.6K pay
models.macro_source: QCEW NAICS 7139 (1.42M workers, 87.4K establishments, $27.6K avg pay, 7.3% emp growth); recreation sub-segments: golf (413K), skiing (43K), bowling (68K), fitness (621K), all other (238K); ClassPass/Mindbody aggregation model; experience economy research
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7139 (Other Amusement and Recreation Industries) is the LARGEST sub-sector in NAICS 71 by a massive margin: 87,381 establishments employing 1,423,906 workers at $530/week ($27,553 annual). This is 57% of all NAICS 71 employment across 48% of establishments. The sub-segments reveal extraordinary diversity: golf courses (713910: 11K establishments, 413K workers, $34.4K avg pay), skiing facilities (713920: 417 establishments, 43K workers, $33.6K avg pay), marinas (713930: 4K establishments, 40.5K workers, $45.4K avg pay), fitness centers (713940: 44K establishments, 621K workers, $21.5K avg pay), bowling centers (713950: 3.4K establishments, 68.2K workers, $25.1K avg pay), and all other recreation (713990: 24.3K establishments, 238K workers, $28K avg pay). The marketplace opportunity: consumers want to discover, book, and pay for recreation activities across modalities — a Tuesday golf round, Thursday bowling league, Saturday ski trip, and Sunday fitness class. ClassPass (acquired by Mindbody) proved the aggregation model for fitness. But no platform extends this across the full recreation spectrum. The 87.4K establishments at $27.6K avg pay are small businesses with minimal technology — most take bookings by phone or walk-in. AI enables: dynamic pricing (off-peak discounts, weather-based pricing for outdoor activities), personalized recommendation (suggesting activities based on preferences, location, weather), and yield management (helping establishments fill unused capacity). The experience economy thesis is validated: Live events, fitness, and recreation are all growing faster than goods-based sectors.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): no cross-recreation marketplace exists. GolfNow (NBC Sports) dominates golf tee times. Ikon/Epic Pass dominate ski. ClassPass dominates boutique fitness aggregation. But these are vertical silos — no platform aggregates across recreation modalities. Moat Advantage is moderate (5): marketplace network effects (more consumers attract more establishments and vice versa) create defensibility at scale, but each recreation vertical has entrenched incumbents who control supply. Value Density is moderate (5): per-transaction revenue of $3-15 per booking on $20-100 average activity price. Volume economics: 87K establishments with thousands of daily booking slots represent massive transaction volume. Demand Visibility is strong (8): consumer demand for experience discovery and booking is proven — ClassPass, OpenTable, and Airbnb Experiences all validated the model. The 87K-establishment universe is the largest untapped booking marketplace in the US economy.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace_network, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: Recreation industry revenue: estimated $150-200B (US). Booking platform commission opportunity (10-15% of booked GMV): estimated $3-5B. Current digital booking penetration: <20% for most non-fitness recreation activities.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: GolfNow (NBC Sports, dominant in golf tee times). Ikon/Epic Pass (ski season passes). ClassPass/Mindbody (fitness aggregation). FareHarbor/Peek/Bookeo (tours and activities). Groupon (discount discovery, declining). No cross-recreation unified marketplace.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Marketplace commission: 10-20% of booking value. Average booking value $40-80. Commission per transaction $4-16. Gross margin on marketplace: 60-70%. Monthly ARPU per establishment: $200-800 (based on 20-50 bookings driven per month). LTV per establishment: $3,600 (18-month retention at $200/mo). CAC per establishment: $300-600 (digital onboarding, local sales). LTV:CAC of 6-12x. Consumer CAC: $5-15 (digital marketing, referral programs).
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 500-700 recreation establishments driving 15,000-25,000 bookings/month at $10 average commission. Start with one metro area (e.g., Denver — ski + golf + fitness + outdoor) and expand market by market. PLG via consumer app with free discovery. Timeline: 18-24 months.

falsification_criteria: ClassPass/Mindbody captures the multi-activity marketplace by expanding beyond fitness into general recreation
Recreation activities prove too heterogeneous for a single platform — golf, skiing, and bowling have fundamentally different booking, pricing, and experience models that resist aggregation
Recreation establishment owners resist marketplace commission models (10-20% per booking) in the same way restaurants resisted DoorDash — opting for direct booking instead

models.name: Public Education Operations & School District Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform for school district operations — transportation routing, substitute teacher management, facility maintenance, budget forecasting, and special education compliance — serving 13,000+ US school districts employing 7.4M workers as the single largest local government function
models.macro_source: F1: K-12 education technology market: $32.4B (2025) to $56.2B (2030) at 11.6% CAGR. School bus routing optimization alone is a $2.3B market. F2: Teacher shortage: 300K+ unfilled positions nationally (NEA 2024). Substitute teacher fill rate: 60-70% (down from 90%+ pre-COVID). F5: Parent/community resistance to AI in education is moderate but vocal — AI grading, student surveillance, and data privacy are hot-button issues. District operations (back-office) face less resistance than classroom AI.
models.deep_dive_evidence: 13,187 school districts in the US (NCES 2024) employing 7.4M workers (3.7M teachers, 3.7M support staff). Total K-12 spending: $860B (FY2024). School districts are the single largest category of local government, representing 35% of local government employment. Key operational pain points: (1) TRANSPORTATION: 480K school buses, $30B annual spending, 10B student-miles/year. Average district spends 8-12% of budget on transportation. AI routing (Transfinder, Routefinder Pro) can reduce bus counts 10-20% and cut ride times 15-25%. Only 30% of districts use optimization software. (2) SUBSTITUTE TEACHERS: 270K+ needed daily, fill rate dropped to 60-70% post-COVID. Frontline Education (Absence Management) is the dominant absence/sub placement system, but uses rule-based matching, not AI prediction. AI can predict teacher absences 3-5 days ahead (based on patterns, time of year, health trends) and pre-assign subs. (3) FACILITY MAINTENANCE: 130K+ school buildings, average age 44 years. Deferred maintenance backlog: $85B nationally (ASCE). Predictive maintenance for HVAC, roofing, plumbing could reduce emergency repairs 30-40%. (4) SPECIAL EDUCATION COMPLIANCE: 7.5M students with IEPs. Each IEP requires 10-20 hours of documentation annually. SpedTrack, Goalbook, and IEP-specific tools exist but are not AI-native.

cla.rationale: School district operations technology is fragmented across point solutions: PowerSchool (SIS, $800M+ revenue), Tyler Technologies (Munis for school finance), Frontline Education (HR/absence management, $300M+ revenue), Transfinder/Versatrans (bus routing), SchoolDude/Brightly (facility maintenance). No integrated AI platform spans all operations. MO is 6 because each point solution has installed-base inertia but none offers AI-native operations management. The AI opportunity is CROSS-FUNCTIONAL: substitute teacher prediction (ML model predicts absence patterns, pre-assigns subs), transportation routing optimization (AI optimizes 480K school bus routes daily, saving 15-25% on fuel and time), facility maintenance prediction (50K+ school buildings aging faster than repair budgets allow), and special education compliance (IDEA/IEP paperwork consumes 5-8 hours per student per year — 7.5M students in special ed). DV is 8 because school boards face persistent budget pressure and operational inefficiency is visible to parents/taxpayers.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B by 2030 (AI-specific school district operations within $56.2B total K-12 edtech — transportation, HR, facilities, compliance)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: 13K school districts are accessible buyers: many have IT directors who make technology decisions independently. Cooperative purchasing (NASPO, E-Rate, state cooperative contracts) enables scalable distribution. Start with transportation optimization (most measurable ROI — reduced bus costs are immediately visible) then expand to HR, facilities, and compliance. Average district: $30-80K ACV for comprehensive operations platform.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Transportation module: $10-30K/year per district. Substitute management: $5-15K/year. Facilities: $5-20K/year. Full operations platform: $30-80K/year per district. Gross margins 80%+. E-Rate eligibility for connectivity-related components. ESSER replacement funding (Title I/II, state technology grants) available.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 3-6 months for operations technology (faster than instructional). School board approval cycle: quarterly meetings. Budget cycle: annual (July-June for most districts). Trigger events: transportation audit finding, substitute shortage crisis, facility emergency. AASA (American Association of School Administrators) and CoSN conferences are primary distribution.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Student data (enrollment projections, attendance patterns, transportation needs, special ed caseloads) creates compounding operational intelligence. District-specific configuration (bell schedules, boundary maps, union rules, board policies) creates switching costs. Multi-module platform economics (single vendor for transport + HR + facilities) creates cross-sell lock-in.

models.falsification_criteria: If PowerSchool or Tyler Technologies builds a comprehensive AI operations layer across their installed bases, preventing challengers. If school district budgets contract sharply (ESSER cliff in 2024-2025 already reducing technology spending). If teacher unions negotiate AI restrictions that prevent operational AI deployment (extending classroom AI resistance to back-office). If school choice/voucher expansion fragments the public school system, reducing district-level economies of scale.

models.name: Automated Clinical Decision Support Platform (Post-FDA Deregulation)
models.one_liner: Compliance-first platform for healthcare that turns regulatory complexity into competitive advantage through automated monitoring and reporting

deep_dive_evidence.fda_action: Jan 6, 2026: FDA issued final guidance deregulating AI/ML-based clinical decision support software that meets four criteria: (1) not intended to replace clinical judgment, (2) intended for healthcare professionals, (3) provides information basis for recommendation, (4) user can independently review. This removes 510(k) pathway requirements for qualifying CDS tools.
deep_dive_evidence.physician_adoption: 66% of physicians report using AI tools in clinical practice (AMA 2025 survey). Usage is primarily for: clinical documentation (40%), differential diagnosis (28%), treatment recommendations (18%), literature review (14%). Most use is informal — personal ChatGPT/Claude queries, not integrated EHR tools.
deep_dive_evidence.invisible_pathway: Physicians are adopting AI without institutional knowledge or patient consent. This 'invisible pathway' means adoption rate understates actual AI influence on clinical decisions. Trust barrier is circumvented (physicians trust their own judgment, AI is a tool they consult) not overcome (patients still do not know or consent).
deep_dive_evidence.diagnostic_accuracy: Meta-analysis of 82 studies: AI diagnostic accuracy matches or exceeds human specialists in: radiology (AUC 0.94 vs 0.91 human), dermatology (AUC 0.91 vs 0.88), pathology (AUC 0.96 vs 0.93). Performance gap widens for rare conditions where AI training data exceeds individual physician experience.

models.macro_source: FDA deregulated AI clinical decision support (Jan 6, 2026) — removing the single largest regulatory barrier to physician-facing AI. 66% of physicians already using AI tools (invisible pathway: adoption happening without explicit trust transfer). But fear friction gap = 4 — patients do not trust AI diagnosis. The opportunity is in the physician-tool layer (high adoption, regulatory tailwind) NOT the patient-facing layer (trust barrier intact). Baumol destination sector dynamics (T4) mean physician time is the most expensive input in healthcare — AI that augments physician judgment has massive cost leverage.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=regulatory_moat_builder, buyer=enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=sector $350000M→$3500M addressable

falsification_criteria: Regulatory framework simplifies or deregulates, eliminating compliance complexity advantage
Incumbent compliance vendors add AI features faster than startups can build regulatory expertise
FDA reverses AI device approval pathway or adds significant new regulatory barriers
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.name: Behind-the-Meter Power for Data Centers
models.one_liner: Develop and operate behind-the-meter gas/solar/battery power plants co-located with data centers, bypassing the 5-year grid queue.
models.key_v3_context: AI compute demand (F1) requires electricity that the grid cannot deliver (F6 bottleneck). The solution is to bring power generation TO the data center rather than connecting data centers to the grid. This is a capital-intensive but structurally necessary infrastructure play. F4 capital rotation means project finance is available. Microsoft/Amazon/Google are already doing this at scale — the opportunity is serving the hundreds of smaller data center operators who need the same solution.
models.macro_source: F6 Grid Bottleneck + F1 AI Compute Demand

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=project_development, buyer=enterprise, frag=3, tam_source=sector $500000M→$5000M addressable

This is the meta-opportunity created by geopolitical fragmentation (F3). v2 had no cross-border regulatory model because NAICS scanning is sector-specific, not regime-comparative.
