models.name: Direct Restaurant Ordering & Delivery Infrastructure
models.one_liner: White-label ordering, delivery logistics, and customer retention platform enabling restaurants to bypass 15-30% delivery platform commissions, targeting the $505B online food delivery market by 2030
models.macro_source: Grand View Research online food delivery market ($505.5B by 2030, 9.4% CAGR); DoorDash/Uber Eats commission structure analysis; QCEW NAICS 722511 and 722513 combined 10M workers

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): Olo ($225M revenue) provides ordering infrastructure to major chains (Wingstop, Shake Shack, Five Guys) but focuses on enterprise. ChowNow, BentoBox (acquired by Fiserv), and Owner.com serve smaller restaurants. DoorDash/Uber Eats have massive consumer demand aggregation that is hard to displace. Moat Advantage is moderate (5): white-label ordering platforms face commoditization risk — Shopify-for-restaurants is a crowded positioning. Differentiation comes from delivery logistics (pooling drivers across restaurants in a geography) and customer data ownership. Value Density is moderate (6): $200-500/month SaaS plus 3-5% transaction fee on orders — lower than DoorDash's 15-30% but meaningful at scale. Demand Visibility is proven (8): restaurants actively hate paying 15-30% commissions — every restaurant owner knows this problem and wants alternatives.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Grand View Research projects the global online food delivery market at $505.5B by 2030 (9.4% CAGR from $288.84B in 2024). In the US, the market is ~$100B and growing at 9.6% CAGR. DoorDash holds ~60% US delivery share, Uber Eats ~25%. Their commission structure: 15-30% per order for marketplace listings, 6-15% for delivery-only. On a $30 average order, DoorDash captures $4.50-9.00 in commission — often exceeding the restaurant's profit margin. QCEW data: 262,155 full-service restaurants and 263,503 limited-service restaurants. An estimated 35-45% participate in third-party delivery, meaning 180,000-235,000 establishments are paying delivery platform commissions. If average commission is $500-1,500/month per restaurant, the total commission pool is $1.1-4.2B annually — this is the value that direct ordering platforms can redistribute. Olo processes $26B+ in annual orders for 700+ brands, proving the infrastructure play works at scale. The direct ordering thesis: restaurants capture customer data (email, order history, preferences) that DoorDash currently owns, enabling retention marketing that platforms explicitly prevent. A restaurant saving 10-20% in commission costs on 30% of its delivery orders saves $6,000-24,000/year — enough to justify $200-500/month in software fees.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $505B global online food delivery by 2030. US market: ~$100B. Direct ordering infrastructure TAM: $4-6B (SaaS + transaction fees on redirected delivery volume).
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can sign 5,000-15,000 restaurants in 5 years. At $300/month SaaS + 3% transaction fee on $5,000/month order volume = $450/month effective ARPU. Total: $27-81M ARR. Owner.com reportedly reaching $50M+ ARR, validating the trajectory.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Blended model: SaaS (80% margin) + transaction fees (50-60% margin after payment processing) + delivery logistics (15-25% margin if operating own driver network). Blended gross margin: 55-70%. LTV: $7,200 (16-month retention at $450/mo — higher churn than enterprise but lower than scheduling tools). CAC: $1,000-2,500 (digital marketing + restaurant industry events). LTV:CAC of 2.9-7.2x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Immediate measurable value: restaurant sees first direct order within 48 hours of setup. Commission savings are visible on first monthly statement. Multi-location chains can deploy in 1-2 weeks. Seasonal peaks (holidays, game days) demonstrate delivery volume capture.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Customer data ownership: once restaurant has 5,000+ customer records with order history, switching back to DoorDash means losing that asset. Delivery driver network in a geography creates logistics moat (expensive to build, hard to replicate). Integration with POS, kitchen, and loyalty systems creates operational dependency.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform, buyer=multi, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $505500M

models.name: Government Constituent Services AI Agent Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered constituent services platform replacing IVR phone trees and in-person queues with conversational AI agents that handle 60-80% of routine government inquiries for 311 services, benefits questions, and agency interactions — serving 90K+ government units
models.macro_source: F1: Government contact center market: $4.2B (2025) to $7.8B (2030) at 13.2% CAGR. US government handles 2B+ citizen contacts annually (phone, in-person, web). Conversational AI market: $13.2B (2025) to $49.9B (2030) at 30.5% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). F2: Government call center staffing vacancy rates 25-35%. Average hold time for IRS: 28 minutes (2024). F5: Citizens tolerate AI for informational queries but strongly resist AI for consequential decisions.
models.sector_name: Executive, Legislative, and Other General Government Support
models.deep_dive_evidence: US government entities handle an estimated 2B+ citizen contacts annually across all channels (NASCIO 2024). Federal: IRS received 290M calls in FY2023, answered 36%. SSA received 72M calls, answered 52%. VA received 98M calls. State: DMVs, tax agencies, benefits offices handle 500M+ contacts. Local: 311 systems in 400+ cities process 100M+ requests. The citizen service experience is broadly awful: average IRS hold time 28 minutes, SSA 33 minutes, state DMV 45+ minutes in-person. Government contact center staffing is 25-35% below authorized levels due to low pay ($30-38K for GS-5 level) and competition from private sector. AI can address this: (1) conversational AI handles 60-80% of informational queries (hours, locations, status checks, how-to guides) without human intervention, (2) AI triage routes complex cases to the right specialist (reducing transfers, which account for 35% of call handle time), (3) multilingual AI serves 67M US residents who speak a language other than English at home. The federal contact center market is dominated by Maximus ($5.2B, operates 60+ government contact centers with 35K agents), but Maximus is a LABOR company — its model depends on hiring thousands of low-wage call center workers. AI agents directly threaten this model. At the local level, companies like Citibot (311 AI chatbots), PublicInput (civic engagement), and Polco are early movers but tiny ($5-20M revenue).

cla.rationale: Government constituent services is split between federal (FORTIFIED — dominated by Maximus $5.2B, GDIT, Alorica) and local (ACCESSIBLE — 90K units, minimal vendor lock-in). At the federal level, Maximus operates the CMS Medicare helpline, SSA contact center, and IRS overflow — replacing these contracts requires cleared facilities, FISMA compliance, and multi-year procurement. MO is 6 weighted across tiers. At the local level, most 311 systems are rudimentary (often just a phone number routed to a dispatcher). AI chatbots and voice agents can serve as the first-ever scalable constituent service layer for small municipalities. Salesforce Public Sector and ServiceNow are expanding into government constituent services but targeting large agencies. The mid-market (cities 10K-250K population, counties, school districts) is underserved. DV is 9 because every citizen who waits 30+ minutes on hold with a government agency experiences the demand for this product.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=ai_copilot, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.8B by 2030 (AI-specific government constituent services within $7.8B total government contact center market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Local/municipal: most accessible tier. 90K+ government units, most with no AI capability. Low ACV ($5-50K/year) but massive volume. State agencies: $100-500K ACV, 50 state opportunities plus territories. Federal: FORTIFIED by Maximus, GDIT, and Alorica — only viable via subcontract or after-hours AI overflow. Startup path: win 500+ municipalities at $15K ACV = $7.5M ARR base, then expand to state and county agencies.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Municipal: $500-$5K/month per entity. State agency: $10K-$50K/month. Per-interaction pricing alternative: $0.50-$2.00 per AI-handled contact (vs $8-15 per human-handled contact). Gross margins 80%+. Implementation: 30-60 days for basic chatbot, 6-12 months for voice agent with full knowledge base.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 30-60 days for municipal (often purchased from discretionary IT budget below formal procurement threshold). 6-12 months for state agencies. Trigger events: budget crunch (hiring freeze makes AI attractive), constituent complaints, election cycle (new mayors/city managers want quick wins). ICMA, NLC, and GFOA conferences are primary distribution.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Government-specific knowledge base (regulations, procedures, form requirements, eligibility rules) unique to each jurisdiction creates per-customer configuration depth. Conversation logs train models on actual citizen queries (what questions do people actually ask?). Integration with permitting, payments, and case management systems creates workflow lock-in. Multilingual capability (government mandate) raises bar for competitors.

models.falsification_criteria: If Maximus successfully pivots from labor-based to AI-based contact center operations (protecting their contracts and switching to hybrid human-AI delivery). If citizens reject government AI chatbots due to accuracy concerns (AI gives wrong benefits information, creates liability). If government employee unions successfully block AI deployment in constituent services (arguing it eliminates jobs). If the multilingual challenge proves harder than expected (government AI must serve 350+ languages to match current interpreter services).

models.name: Perez Crash Defense Portfolio Platform
models.one_liner: Investment platform assembling crash-resilient portfolios of businesses that maintain value regardless of whether AI succeeds or fails -- cash-flow-positive, low-leverage, essential-service companies that survive the Installation-to-Deployment transition
models.macro_source: COUNTER-TREND MODEL: Perez cycle theory (T5) predicts a crash at the Installation-to-Deployment transition. Every major technology revolution (canals, railroads, telegraph, automobiles, internet) experienced a financial crash before the technology deployed broadly. The current AI installation phase (2022-2026) has invested $1T+ in infrastructure. If/when the crash comes, which businesses survive? This model builds a 'crash-proof' portfolio using the engine's own scoring: high CE (capital efficiency), high SN (structural necessity), low leverage. The meta-insight: the Perez crash doesn't mean AI fails -- it means financial excess gets purged while the technology continues deploying.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Perez cycle historical parallels: Railway Mania (1840s), Roaring Twenties (1929), Dot-com (2000). Each saw 40-80% market declines followed by the technology transforming the economy anyway. Current AI markers matching 'late Installation phase': massive infrastructure investment ($100B+ annually by hyperscalers), speculative valuations (NVIDIA 30x+ revenue), financial engineering around AI narratives. $1.2T PE debt maturing 2027-2029 (engine's F4 tracking) adds refinancing wall pressure. The crash-defense portfolio: companies scoring CE>=8 AND SN>=8 in the engine's existing data. 34 models meet this threshold. Revenue model: AUM-based or model-portfolio licensing to RIAs and family offices. Data compounding moat: the engine's own 508-model dataset provides unique crash-resilience scoring unavailable elsewhere.

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=data_compounding, NAICS=52, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

Cybersecurity talent shortage of 3.5M unfilled positions globally makes AI alternative not just cheaper but necessary. MSP M&A market active — PE buying customer bases, not workforces. Headcount per managed environment projected to drop 60-80% by 2030. Acquire-and-modernize model provides day-1 revenue and 12-36mo contract stickiness. models.name: Smart Building Facilities Management OS
models.one_liner: IoT-integrated AI platform unifying HVAC, lighting, security, cleaning, and maintenance into a single facilities operating system — targeting $30.6B US facility management market by 2030
models.macro_source: MarketsandMarkets: US facility management market $14.9B in 2025, $30.6B by 2030 (15.5% CAGR). Mordor Intelligence: integrated FM market $191.8B globally in 2025, $269.7B by 2030 (7.1% CAGR). Smart building market $141.8B in 2025, $309.6B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence). Building IoT market $64.1B in 2024, $101.0B by 2030 (7.9% CAGR, Memoori). CMBS office delinquency at 12.34% record creates cost-cutting urgency.

cla.rationale: Market openness moderate — Siemens (Smart Infrastructure), Johnson Controls (OpenBlue), Honeywell (Forge), and Schneider Electric (EcoStruxure) are massive incumbents. However, these legacy BMS vendors sell hardware-centric solutions with software as an afterthought. The opportunity is a software-first FM platform that integrates across multiple BMS vendors (Siemens + Honeywell + third-party IoT sensors) rather than being locked to one hardware ecosystem. Moat advantage high: building operational data compounds over years (energy usage patterns, maintenance histories, occupancy trends). Value density very high: commercial buildings spend $5-25/sqft annually on facilities management — a 500K sqft office = $2.5-12.5M annual FM spend. Demand visibility strong: CMBS delinquency creates cost-cutting urgency, ESG mandates require energy monitoring, hybrid work requires space optimization.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The US facility management market is projected to grow from $14.9B in 2025 to $30.6B by 2030 at 15.5% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). The global smart building market reached $141.8B in 2025 (Mordor Intelligence) and the Building IoT market is $64.1B in 2024 growing to $101.0B by 2030 (Memoori). NAICS 5612 (Facilities Support Services) employs approximately 150K US workers. But the real opportunity extends across all buildings served by NAICS 5611-5619 — there are 5.9M commercial buildings in the US, of which only 15-20% have any smart building technology. The economic drivers are powerful: (1) CMBS office delinquency reached 12.34% all-time record — building owners must cut costs to avoid default, and FM technology reduces operating costs 15-30%. (2) ESG mandates require energy monitoring and carbon reporting — smart building platforms provide this data. (3) Hybrid work creates occupancy volatility — AI-driven space optimization reduces wasted energy and FM resources. (4) Energy costs: commercial buildings account for 35% of US electricity consumption ($150B+/year). AI-driven HVAC optimization delivers 15-30% energy savings ($22-45B annual savings potential). Key competition: Siemens Smart Infrastructure ($19B segment), Johnson Controls OpenBlue, Honeywell Forge, and Schneider Electric EcoStruxure are multi-billion dollar incumbents. But they sell proprietary hardware-locked ecosystems. The market gap is a vendor-agnostic FM OS that integrates across BMS vendors, IoT sensor types, and building management workflows. 32% of CRE leaders plan further footprint reduction, creating demand for technology-enabled FM to manage remaining portfolio more efficiently.
falsification_criteria: Hardware component costs fail to decline on expected trajectory
Software-only solutions prove sufficient, eliminating need for specialized hardware
Gig economy regulation (AB5-like laws) disrupts staffing platform economics
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $30.6B US facility management market by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets). Software/platform sub-segment: $5-8B by 2030 (platform fees, analytics, optimization services). Energy savings addressable: $22-45B annual savings potential across US commercial buildings.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible as vendor-agnostic integration layer — this is a classic 'Switzerland' platform play. Property management firms (CBRE, JLL, Cushman & Wakefield) are potential channel partners and acquirers. REITs are anchor customers (manage hundreds of buildings, need portfolio-wide optimization). Capital requirements $10-20M for platform development and initial building deployments.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing: $0.25-1.00/sqft/year for FM platform. A 500K sqft building = $125K-500K ACV. Enterprise portfolio (10M+ sqft) = $2.5-10M annually. Gross margins 75-85% on software. Customer ROI: 15-30% energy savings + 20-40% maintenance cost reduction = $1-5M annual savings for a single large building. Break-even at 20-30 large building deployments or 2-3 REIT portfolio deals.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: CMBS delinquency at record levels creates cost-cutting urgency. ESG reporting mandates (SEC climate disclosure rule) require building-level energy data. Hybrid work occupancy variability requires AI-driven space optimization. Rising energy costs (commercial electricity up 15-20% since 2020) improve automation ROI. 15.5% market CAGR indicates strong underlying demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Building operational data compounds (3-5 years of HVAC, energy, occupancy data enables predictive optimization impossible for new entrants). Multi-vendor integration creates complexity moat (connecting Siemens BMS + Honeywell sensors + third-party IoT + elevator systems requires deep domain expertise). Portfolio-level benchmarking creates network effects (insights from building A improve optimization at building B). Long-term building management contracts (3-5 year) create revenue predictability and switching costs.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=iot_platform, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $150000M

models.name: Last-Mile Delivery Orchestration Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform orchestrating multi-modal last-mile delivery (vans, bikes, drones, lockers, robots) for retailers and e-commerce brands in the $62.4B US last-mile market growing at 7.5% CAGR to 2030
models.macro_source: Grand View Research: US last-mile delivery market projected $62.4B by 2030 at 7.5% CAGR. Global last-mile market $177-197B (2025) growing to $259-374B by 2030-2033. Last mile accounts for 53% of total shipping cost. Amazon delivers 60%+ of own packages. Same-day delivery expectation now standard for 65% of US consumers.

cla.rationale: Last-mile is Amazon's territory -- they deliver 60%+ of their own packages and DSP (Delivery Service Partner) program controls 3,000+ independent delivery companies. For non-Amazon retailers, the pain is acute: FedEx/UPS costs rising 5-7% annually, gig delivery (DoorDash, Instacart) unreliable for planned delivery, and building your own fleet is capital-intensive. The orchestration opportunity is for a platform that MANAGES multi-modal last-mile (mix of own fleet, gig drivers, parcel lockers, drones, micro-fulfillment) and optimizes across modes in real-time. MO is 5 because Amazon, FedEx, and UPS are massive incumbents. But 40% of e-commerce volume flows OUTSIDE Amazon and those retailers desperately need better last-mile solutions.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Last mile = 53% of total shipping cost, averaging $10.10 per last-mile delivery in the US. Amazon's DSP program: 3,000+ independent delivery companies, 275K+ drivers. FedEx/UPS parcel rates rising 5-7% annually compounding. Failed deliveries cost US retailers $17.2B annually. Consumer expectation shift: 65% expect same-day or next-day delivery (up from 36% in 2020). Micro-fulfillment centers growing 25%+ CAGR -- DoorDash DashMart, Gopuff, Getir model proving urban dark store economics. Drone delivery approved BVLOS in 4 states, with Zipline, Wing (Alphabet), and Amazon Prime Air expanding commercial operations. Autonomous delivery robots (Nuro, Serve Robotics, Starship) now in 25+ US cities. The orchestration layer -- deciding WHICH mode to use for WHICH delivery based on real-time cost/speed tradeoffs -- is the untapped software opportunity.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Warehouse automation ROI fails to justify capital expenditure for mid-size operators
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.2-5B by 2030 (last-mile orchestration software layer capturing 5-8% of $62.4B US last-mile market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible targeting mid-market e-commerce ($10-500M GMV) and specialty retailers (grocery, pharmacy, furniture) with complex delivery requirements. Must integrate with 5+ delivery modes from day one. Win rate depends on demonstrating 15-25% cost reduction vs single-mode delivery.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS platform fee ($5-25K/month) + per-delivery transaction fee ($0.10-0.50). For a retailer doing 50K deliveries/month, that's $10-30K/month. Gross margins 75%+. Capital-light (software only, no fleet ownership).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 3-6 months for mid-market retailers. Pilot with one geography/store cluster, then expand. Fastest adoption in dense urban markets where multi-modal options exist. Peak season (Nov-Dec) is the natural pressure test and decision point.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Delivery data compounding: real-time performance data across modes enables increasingly accurate mode selection. Carrier/partner network integration (each new delivery partner integrated is 3-6 months of engineering -- switching cost for retailers). Geographic density: platform performs better in areas with more active delivery partners and modes.

models.name: Trucking Compliance & ELD Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered compliance platform automating HOS management, FMCSA audit preparation, drug/alcohol testing coordination, and CSA score optimization for 500K+ motor carriers in the $16.9B ELD market growing to $32.7B by 2033
models.macro_source: Business Research Insights: ELD market $16.9B (2025) to $32.7B (2033) at 8.6% CAGR. FMCSA ELD mandate: 97% compliance for regulated commercial motor vehicles. 500K+ registered motor carriers in the US. FMCSA Drug & Alcohol Clearinghouse: 215K+ positive results. HOS violations are #1 reason for out-of-service orders. CSA scores directly impact insurance costs (5-25% premium variation).

cla.rationale: ELD hardware is commoditized (900+ registered devices on FMCSA list). The opportunity is NOT in another ELD box but in the INTELLIGENCE layer: AI that optimizes HOS utilization (drivers lose 5-15% of available driving time to suboptimal planning), predicts FMCSA audit risk, automatically manages drug/alcohol clearinghouse compliance, and optimizes CSA scores to reduce insurance costs. KeepTruckin/Motive and Samsara provide basic compliance but their AI analytics are shallow. Specialized compliance AI targets the 500K motor carriers for whom regulatory violations are existential (one critical violation can shut down a carrier). MO is 6 because Motive/Samsara are in-market but MO gap exists in deep compliance intelligence.

models.deep_dive_evidence: 500K+ motor carriers registered with FMCSA. 91% have fewer than 6 trucks -- extreme fragmentation. FMCSA conducts 5-7K compliance reviews annually but algorithm-based targeting means small carriers face random audits. Drug & Alcohol Clearinghouse: 215K+ positive results since 2020, 130K+ currently prohibited from driving. HOS violations: #1 out-of-service reason (35% of all OOS orders). CSA methodology uses 7 BASICs (Behavior Analysis and Safety Improvement Categories) -- carriers above threshold face interventions. Insurance impact: CSA scores directly affect premiums, with 5-25% variation. Small carriers spend 15-25 hours/month on compliance paperwork manually. An AI platform that automates FMCSA audit prep (auto-generates DQ files, manages driver qualification), optimizes HOS to maximize legal driving time, and proactively manages CSA scores saves $5-15K/year per carrier while reducing violation risk.
falsification_criteria: Regulatory environment simplifies, reducing demand for automated compliance
Large consulting firms (Big 4) build competitive compliance automation platforms
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.8-4.5B by 2030 (compliance intelligence software for 500K+ carriers at $5-9K average annual spend)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture highly feasible in small/mid carriers (6-100 trucks) where compliance is handled by the owner or one safety manager, not a department. These carriers cannot afford dedicated compliance staff but face same regulatory requirements as large carriers. Pricing at $100-500/truck/month is affordable vs compliance staff ($60-80K/year salary).
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing $100-500/truck/month. 20-truck carrier = $24-120K ARR. Target 1,000 carriers at $50K average ARR = $50M ARR at scale. Gross margins 85%+ (pure software). Low CAC via freight industry channels (trucking associations, trade shows, referrals).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-60 days for small carriers (pain is immediate -- recent violation or audit drives purchase). Self-serve onboarding for <20 trucks. Seasonal patterns: DOT blitz inspection weeks (3x/year) create urgency spikes. Insurance renewal cycles (annual) create CSA optimization demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Compliance data accumulation: years of HOS data, violation patterns, and audit outcomes create predictive models that improve with each carrier onboarded. Regulatory expertise: FMCSA rule changes require platform updates that smaller competitors cannot keep pace with. Integration with ELD hardware providers creates ecosystem stickiness. Carrier referral networks: safety directors share compliance tools within industry groups.

models.name: Drone-Based Crop Scouting & Aerial Application Service
models.one_liner: Drone-as-a-service platform for crop scouting (multispectral NDVI, stand counts, weed mapping) and precision aerial application (spot-spray fungicide/insecticide) -- replacing $2.4B manned aerial application market while enabling sub-acre resolution scouting on 400M+ US crop acres
models.macro_source: F1: Agricultural drone market $5.5B (2025) to $14.7B (2030) at 21.7% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). DJI Agras T40 sprays 50 acres/hour at $25K unit cost vs $250K+ manned ag aircraft. F2: Crop scout/agronomist workforce aging (avg age 52) with insufficient replacement. F4: Ag drone VC investment >$600M in 2024 (Hylio, Rantizo, Guardian Agriculture all raised $20M+ rounds).
models.deep_dive_evidence: US aerial application market: $2.4B (2024), 1,560 manned ag aircraft operators (NAAA), applying crop protection on 127M acres/year. Manned application: $8-15/acre for fungicide/insecticide application. Drone application: $4-8/acre and dropping as payload capacity increases (DJI T40: 40L payload, 50 acres/hour; Hylio AG-272: 72L payload). FAA Part 137 agricultural drone exemptions granted to 450+ operators (Jan 2026), up from 180 in 2024 -- regulatory path clearing rapidly. Crop scouting: traditional foot scouting covers 2-4 fields/day at $5-8/acre. Drone multispectral scouting covers 300-500 acres/hour at $1-3/acre with sub-meter resolution. Stand count accuracy: 95%+ (vs visual estimation at 80%). Weed pressure mapping enables spot-spray herbicide applications that reduce chemical use 60-80% (Rantizo pilot data, 2024 Iowa trials). Key drone-as-a-service players: Rantizo (Iowa, raised $20M, 500K+ acres treated), Hylio (Texas, raised $24M), Guardian Agriculture (VTOL crop sprayer, $65M raised), Pyka (autonomous fixed-wing sprayer, $48M raised). Market structure is fragmenting into (1) hardware OEMs (DJI, Hylio, Guardian), (2) DaaS operators (Rantizo, local operators), and (3) analytics platforms (processing drone imagery). The integration of scouting + application is the gap: fly the field, detect the problem, apply the treatment -- all in one platform.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high because the DaaS model is nascent and no one dominates nationally. Rantizo leads in treated acres but only covers 500K acres -- <0.2% of addressable. Moat advantage is moderate: hardware commoditizing (DJI dominates globally, US alternatives emerging), so moat must be in data/analytics and operator network density. Value density per acre is moderate ($4-8/acre application, $1-3/acre scouting) but aggregates to $3-6B addressable. Demand visibility is strong: every farmer knows their scouting and application costs and can do the math.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=service_platform, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.0-6.0B (US agricultural drone services: scouting + application, growing from $2.4B manned aerial baseline as drones expand total addressable acres)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: DaaS revenue: $4-8/acre for application, $1-3/acre for scouting. Drone COGS: $25K per unit, 2-3 year useful life. Operator cost: $250-400/day. A single drone operator covers 300-500 acres/day scouting or 200-400 acres/day spraying. Revenue per operator-day: $800-$3,200. Gross margins 45-55% (equipment, labor, logistics). Network model (Uber-for-drones) has better margins at 65-70% by using independent operators.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Build DaaS network in 2-3 major ag regions (Corn Belt, Delta, Central Valley). 100 drone operators covering 500K+ acres at $10/acre blended (scout + apply). First $5M ARR in year 2-3. Key distribution: partner with crop input retailers (CHS, Nutrien) who already sell to every farmer and can upsell drone services.

falsification_criteria: If FAA restricts agricultural drone operations (BVLOS waivers revoked, weight limits tightened) rather than continuing to expand Part 137 exemptions
If DJI agricultural drones are banned from US use (NDAA restrictions on Chinese drones could extend to agricultural applications)
If manned aerial applicators successfully lobby for regulations requiring manned oversight of all drone spray operations, eliminating the cost advantage

models.name: Independent Agronomic Intelligence & Input Marketplace
models.one_liner: Farmer-owned agronomic data cooperative that pools field-level yield, soil, and input data from 50K+ members to generate unbiased seed/chemical recommendations and negotiate group purchasing -- the anti-Monsanto model disrupting the $60B US crop input distribution chain where dealers earn 15-25% margins on captive farmer relationships
models.macro_source: F5: Farmer distrust of input companies (Bayer/Monsanto, Corteva, Syngenta/ChemChina) is structural -- 72% of farmers concerned about data privacy (Farm Bureau 2023). Climate Corp acquisition by Monsanto ($930M, 2013) is the cautionary tale every farmer knows. F1: AI recommendation engines can replace human crop consultants who are often paid by input companies (conflict of interest). F4: FBN's $900M+ fundraising validates farmer willingness to pay for independent advice.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US crop input market: $60B+ annually (seed $23B, fertilizer $22B, crop protection $15B+). Distribution chain: manufacturer → distributor/retailer → farmer, with 15-25% dealer margins at each step. The distribution layer (CHS, Nutrien, Helena Chemical, Wilbur-Ellis, local co-ops) generates $10-15B in margin by bundling recommendations with product sales -- a structural conflict of interest. Farmer problem: 'My agronomist recommends the seed that gives him the highest commission, not the highest yield.' Farmers Business Network (FBN, founded 2014): the pioneer of the independent model. 60K+ farm members contributing agronomic data. FBN Direct: e-commerce for crop inputs at transparent pricing. Total funding: $900M+. Revenue ~$500M (2024 est). BUT FBN has struggled with unit economics -- input distribution is capital-intensive (inventory, logistics) and FBN's losses are significant. The PLATFORM play (not the distribution play): build the data cooperative and recommendation engine, partner with multiple distributors for fulfillment. Revenue from subscription ($10-20/acre) + marketplace transaction fees (3-5% of input purchases). Average large farm spends $200-400/acre on inputs: 3-5% = $6-20/acre in marketplace fees. Combined $16-40/acre revenue vs FBN's full-stack distribution attempt. AgExplorer, Bushel, and Conservis are adjacent. Co-op model (member-owned data) resolves the trust problem that killed Climate Corp's farmer adoption.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate: FBN occupies the 'independent ag data' position but has struggled financially. The cooperative model (farmer-owned, not VC-backed) is differentiated and may have better trust dynamics. Moat advantage builds through member data contributions -- more farms = better recommendations = more farms (network effect). Value density is moderate per acre but large at scale. Demand is proven by FBN's 60K members despite FBN's execution challenges.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace_network, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.0-4.0B (independent agronomic intelligence + crop input marketplace fees on $60B input market)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: concentrated incumbents, emerging independents
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Subscription: $10-20/acre/year. Marketplace fee: 3-5% of input purchases ($6-20/acre). Blended revenue: $16-40/acre. Average member farm: 2,000 acres = $32K-$80K ACV. Gross margins 70-80% for platform (no inventory). Compare to FBN's 15-20% gross margins on input distribution. The platform-only model is 4x better unit economics.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Recruit 200-300 large grain farms (2,000+ acres) as founding cooperative members. $20K average ACV from subscription + marketplace fees. First $5M ARR in year 2-3. Distribution: ag lenders (Farm Credit, Rabobank) who want their borrowers to reduce input costs. State Farm Bureaus for member recruitment. Corn Belt focus initially (Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio = 100M+ acres of row crops).

falsification_criteria: If FBN achieves profitability and dominant market position, closing the window for an alternative independent platform
If input manufacturers (Bayer, Corteva, Syngenta) successfully rebuild farmer trust through transparent data policies, reducing the 'anti-Monsanto' demand driver
If crop input prices decline enough that farmers stop caring about optimization (low commodity prices make input cost management less urgent)

models.name: Wholesale Distribution Warehouse Robotics-as-a-Service
models.one_liner: Deploy warehouse AMRs and pick-pack robotics in mid-market wholesale distribution centers — RaaS model targeting 250K+ warehouses where labor costs are 40-50% of operating expense
models.macro_source: F1: Warehouse automation market $23B (2025) to $51B (2030) at 17% CAGR (LogisticsIQ). F2: Warehouse labor shortage — 490K+ unfilled warehouse/logistics positions, turnover rate 49% annually (BLS). F4: RaaS model eliminates $1-5M upfront capital requirement that blocks mid-market adoption.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Wholesale distribution operates 250K+ warehouse and distribution center facilities in the US. Labor represents 40-50% of warehouse operating costs, and wholesale distributors face the same labor crisis as the broader logistics sector: 490K+ unfilled warehouse positions (BLS JOLTS, Dec 2025), 49% annual turnover rate, and average warehouse worker compensation rising 12% since 2022 to $38K/year. Warehouse automation market: $23B (2025) growing to $51B (2030) at 17.5% CAGR (LogisticsIQ). Key technologies: autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) for goods-to-person picking (Locus Robotics, 6 River Systems/Shopify, Berkshire Grey), robotic picking arms (RightHand Robotics, Dexterity), and automated sortation. BUT adoption is concentrated in mega-warehouses (Amazon, Walmart, FedEx). Mid-market distributors (5K-50K SF warehouses) are largely unautomated because: (1) upfront cost of $1-5M for a warehouse automation system exceeds their capital budget, (2) integration complexity with legacy WMS systems, (3) product diversity (wholesale distributors may carry 50K+ SKUs of varying size/weight/fragility). RaaS model: deploy AMRs at $2-5K/month per robot (vs $25-50K purchase), integrate with existing WMS, and demonstrate 30-50% pick productivity improvement. Locus Robotics ($300M+ raised, RaaS model) has validated the approach but focuses on e-commerce fulfillment, not wholesale distribution. The wholesale-specific opportunity requires handling: B2B order profiles (larger, fewer orders vs B2C), pallet-level and case-level picking, and integration with wholesale-specific ERP systems (Epicor, Infor, SAP B1).

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate — Locus Robotics, Berkshire Grey, and others are established in warehouse robotics but not focused on wholesale distribution. Competition is intensifying. Moat advantage is moderate: wholesale-specific workflow knowledge and WMS integrations create switching costs, but AMR hardware is commoditizing. Value chain depth is limited — primarily pick-pack-ship optimization without deep upstream/downstream integration. Demand visibility is excellent: labor shortage is acute and measurable.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=robotics_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $12B (mid-market warehouse automation by 2030, wholesale distribution segment ~$4B)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: moderately concentrated — Locus Robotics ($300M+ raised), Berkshire Grey (public, $BGRY), 6 River Systems (Shopify), GreyOrange, Fetch Robotics (Zebra). None are wholesale-distribution-specialized.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: RaaS revenue: $2-5K/month per AMR. Robot COGS: $25-50K per unit. Break-even per robot: 12-18 months. Gross margins 40-55% (hardware drag). Fleet of 10-20 robots per warehouse = $20-100K/month per customer. Integration services: $10-30K per deployment.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Deploy in 30-50 wholesale distribution centers at $10K/month average (5-10 robots each). Total fleet: 200-400 robots. $3.6-6M ARR. Focus on industrial MRO and electrical distributors where SKU density is highest and labor shortage most acute.

falsification_criteria: If Amazon Robotics or Shopify/6 River Systems enter mid-market distribution automation, leveraging their scale to offer RaaS at 50% lower cost
If warehouse labor market eases (immigration reform or wage stabilization), reducing the urgency for automation
If humanoid robots (Figure, Tesla Optimus) reach warehouse-viable capabilities at sub-$20K by 2028, disrupting task-specific AMR economics

models.name: Agentic Financial Advisory Operating System
models.one_liner: AI operating system for RIAs: autonomous client communication, portfolio monitoring, compliance, proactive financial planning. Advisor focuses on judgment and relationships while AI handles operations.

structural_drivers: Fee compression: 83% of advisors charging <1% for $5M+ clients -- margins demand AI augmentation
Agentic AI now production-ready (OpenAI Frontier Feb 2026, Claude agent teams)
Feb 10, 2026 sector sell-off confirms market pricing in AI transformation of advisory
Current advisor capacity 100-150 clients; AI OS enables 300-500 without quality degradation
RIA tech stacks fragmented across 5+ separate tools -- no unified AI orchestration layer

F1_technology.mechanism: Agentic AI autonomously monitors portfolios, drafts client communications, prepares compliance reports, generates financial plans, executes proactive outreach. Multi-agent orchestration is enabling breakthrough.

F4_capital.mechanism: Advisory firms earning 0.6-0.8% AUM (down from 1.0%) need 30-50% cost reduction to maintain margins. AI OS delivers this.

F5_psychology.mechanism: Feb 2026 sell-off creates urgency. Advisors complacent about AI now face existential pressure. Fear becomes adoption catalyst.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $10-40K/yr per RIA firm (tiered by AUM, client count, features)
unit_economics.break_even: 200-400 RIA firm subscriptions at $20K avg ARR

fear_friction.note: Advisors fear losing control of client relationships to autonomous agents. Resolution: human-in-the-loop for all client-facing communications, start with back-office, expand as trust builds.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Orion, Envestnet adding AI features. Altruist is AI-native but custody-focused. Dedicated agentic AI OS for RIAs: <3 entrants. 12-18 month competitive window before incumbents catch up.
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: 85K+ RIA firms x $20K avg ARR = $1.7B direct. Plus broker-dealers/hybrid advisors: $500M. Total: $2.2B.

cla.rationale: No dominant AI-native RIA platform. Legacy platforms (Orion, Tamarac) not AI-native. Client comm, portfolio management, rebalancing, compliance, reporting — rich layer stack. Advisor retirements + fee compression + AI enabling 1:5x client scaling.

The 532K/month new business formation (Coasean shrinkage) creates massive demand for ready-to-deploy AI agents. This is an infrastructure layer for the AI economy that has no NAICS code. v2 could not detect it because it was constructing individual AI-powered business models rather than the meta-layer where AI agents are bought and sold.

models.name: Automated Voice Ordering & Drive-Through Intelligence
models.one_liner: AI-powered voice ordering for drive-throughs, phone orders, and counter service — automating the $285B limited-service restaurant ordering workflow targeting a $3.2B addressable market by 2028
models.macro_source: Wendy's FreshAI deployment data; McDonald's Apprente acquisition and subsequent partnerships; QCEW NAICS 722513 (4.6M workers); restaurant technology solutions market forecast (360iResearch)

cla.rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): major chains are already deploying (Wendy's FreshAI at 100+ locations, Taco Bell testing, McDonald's previously with IBM/now pivoting) but most are built on third-party AI — creating room for best-of-breed platform providers. The 263,503 limited-service restaurant establishments represent massive volume. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): voice AI for ordering requires food-service-specific training data (menu variations, accent handling, upsell logic, dietary modifications) that creates specialization moat, but foundation model improvements could commoditize base capability. Value Density is high (8): per-location value of $1,000-3,000/month (replacing 0.5-1.0 FTE order-taker + upsell revenue lift of 5-15%). Demand Visibility is proven (9): Wendy's, Taco Bell, Checkers already deploying — this is not speculative, the adoption curve is active.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: 722513 (Limited-Service Restaurants) has 263,503 establishments employing 4.606M workers at $434/week ($22,553/year). Average of 17.5 workers per location. Drive-through generates 70-75% of QSR revenue (pre-COVID: 65%). Wendy's FreshAI (built on Google Cloud AI) has deployed to 100+ locations with reported 86% order accuracy and 22-second average order time. McDonald's abandoned its IBM partnership but continues testing AI ordering through other vendors. SoundHound's SYNQ3 processes 300M+ voice orders annually for restaurant chains. ConverseNow (raised $15M Series B) processes voice orders for Pizza Hut, Domino's franchisees. The unit economics are stark: a drive-through order-taker costs $15-18/hr ($31-37K/year with benefits), operates one lane, and has inconsistent upsell performance. AI voice ordering costs $1,500-3,000/month per lane, operates 24/7 with zero breaks, and consistently upsells (reported 5-15% ticket increase). At 263K limited-service locations, assuming 60% have drive-throughs (158K lanes), the addressable market for voice ordering alone is $1.9-4.7B annually. Adding phone ordering (the other 40%) expands to $3.2B. Restaurant analytics solutions growing at 17.8% CAGR (Grand View Research) confirms the trajectory.
falsification_criteria: Foundation model APIs commoditize the copilot layer, eliminating differentiation
User adoption stalls as professionals resist AI-augmented workflows in daily tasks
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.2B (voice ordering for limited-service restaurants including drive-through and phone). Broader restaurant voice AI including full-service: $4.5B by 2028.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture 3,000-8,000 locations in 5 years through chain partnerships (one national QSR chain = 5,000+ locations). At $2,000/month per location: $72-192M ARR. SoundHound's existing 300M+ order volume proves the scale is achievable.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Pure software/API model: 85-90% gross margins. $2,000/month per location ARPU. Implementation cost of $500-2,000 per site (minimal hardware — microphone + speaker + cloud connection). LTV of $48,000 (assuming 24-month retention). CAC of $3,000-8,000 per location (chain sales require enterprise BD team). LTV:CAC of 6-16x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fast once chain decision is made: 60-90 day deployment per location, 500+ locations per quarter possible for national chains. Phone/counter ordering can be deployed in days (no hardware). Upsell revenue lift creates measurable ROI within 30 days — the fastest payback of any restaurant technology.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Menu-specific voice training data (handling 'no pickles extra mayo light ice' across thousands of menu permutations). Integration partnerships with POS systems (Toast, Oracle MICROS, NCR) create distribution moat. Chain-level contracts with 2-3 year terms create revenue predictability. Each location deployment improves the model's accent/dialect handling.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=ai_copilot, buyer=consumer_smb, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $285000M

models.name: Automated Staffing Marketplace — Enterprise Direct Sourcing Platform
models.one_liner: AI-native talent matching platform enabling enterprise direct sourcing and bypassing traditional staffing agencies — targeting $200B+ US staffing market disruption with $12B direct sourcing TAM by 2028
models.macro_source: Staffing Industry Analysts: US staffing market $290B+ by 2030 (2.2% CAGR). Robert Half stock -53%, ManpowerGroup -44% signaling structural disruption (P-027 canary). Grand View Research: freelance platforms market $14.4B by 2030 (17.7% CAGR). 70% of tech leaders more likely to use staffing — but for AI specialists, not commodity workers. AI recruitment tools cut hiring costs 30% and time-to-fill 40% (DemandSage 2025).

cla.rationale: Market openness is high because traditional staffing firms (Robert Half, ManpowerGroup, Randstad) are structurally disadvantaged — their business model depends on the markup that AI eliminates. Existing digital platforms (Upwork $690M revenue, Fiverr, Toptal) focus on freelancers, not enterprise staffing replacement. The gap between 'freelance marketplace' and 'enterprise staffing replacement' is where the opportunity lives. Moat advantage is moderate — data on placement outcomes compounds over time (which placements succeed, which fail, why), but talent marketplaces face multi-homing problem (candidates list on multiple platforms). Value density high: enterprise staffing contracts are $50K-500K annual per account. Demand visibility is proven — $200B+ market with incumbents visibly declining.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The US staffing industry generates $290B+ annually (Staffing Industry Analysts, growing at 2.2% CAGR to 2030). The industry's structural economics are under assault: traditional staffing agencies charge 25-50% markups on hourly rates for candidate sourcing, screening, and employer-of-record services. AI-powered matching can perform sourcing and screening at near-zero marginal cost. Robert Half (RHI) stock declined 53% from peak and ManpowerGroup (MAN) declined 44% — these are the market pricing in structural disruption, not cyclical weakness. IT staffing aggregate revenue is down 9% with larger firms suffering most. The direct sourcing model allows enterprises to build their own curated talent pools, bypassing staffing agency intermediation. Beeline's acquisition of MBO Partners (June 2025) signals enterprise VMS platforms moving into direct sourcing. 65% of recruiters have already implemented AI tools (DemandSage), primarily for candidate sourcing (58% use case), time savings (44%), and cost reduction (30% per hire). The freelance platforms market is $5.6B in 2024 growing to $14.4B by 2030 (Grand View Research, 17.7% CAGR). But this understates the opportunity: the real TAM is the delta between the $200B+ staffing market and the 25-50% markup that AI eliminates — roughly $50-100B in intermediation value at risk. Even capturing 10-15% of this displacement represents a $5-15B market for AI-native staffing platforms.
falsification_criteria: Supply-side participants disintermediate the platform through direct relationships
Network effects fail to materialize due to low transaction frequency in the sector
Gig economy regulation (AB5-like laws) disrupts staffing platform economics
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $12B direct sourcing software/platform TAM by 2028 (conservative: 6% of $200B staffing market converting to platform economics). Broader disruption TAM: $50-100B in staffing intermediation value at risk of AI compression.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture is feasible because incumbents face innovator's dilemma — their revenue IS the markup that AI eliminates. New entrants can charge 5-10% platform fees vs 25-50% staffing markups, winning on price while delivering faster, better matching. Key risk: two-sided marketplace cold-start problem requires domain focus (start in healthcare staffing, light industrial, or tech).
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Platform model: 5-10% take rate on placement value. Enterprise ACV $100K-1M for large accounts. Gross margins 75-85% (software + AI matching, no employee carrying cost). Break-even at 200-500 enterprise accounts. Capital efficient: $5-15M to build platform and reach product-market fit.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Staffing agencies experiencing 9%+ revenue decline creates urgency for enterprise alternatives. Contract/project-based hiring preference (vs permanent) favors platform model. 70% of tech leaders already increasing staffing usage — the demand exists, it's seeking a better channel. Healthcare staffing crisis creates immediate wedge market ($42.8B healthcare staffing by 2035).
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: placement outcome data (who succeeded, who churned, why) improves matching over time. Curated talent benches create switching costs — enterprises invest in building their 'pre-vetted' talent pools on the platform. Employer-of-record compliance layer creates stickiness. Network effects: more talent = better matches = more employers = more talent.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $290000M

models.name: Automated Construction Project Management Copilot
models.one_liner: AI copilot for construction project managers that automates scheduling, RFI processing, submittal tracking, and daily reports -- targeting the $11.6B construction management software market growing to $19.1B by 2030 at 12.1% CAGR
models.macro_source: F1: AI-driven progress analytics expanding at 14.12% CAGR through 2031, outpacing traditional PM modules. F2: 650K unfilled positions mean PMs are overloaded, managing 2-3x project volume vs 2019. Mordor Intelligence Construction Management Software Market Report 2025.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate because Procore ($1.31B revenue, 16K+ customers), Autodesk Construction Cloud, and Oracle Aconex dominate the GC/owner segment. However, AI-native copilot features are nascent -- Procore just launched basic AI in 2025. The opportunity is to build an AI-first PM tool for the underserved mid-market (sub-$50M projects, 90%+ of market by volume) where Procore is too expensive ($10K-$50K/year) and Excel/paper still dominates. Moat builds through project data accumulation: each completed project trains the model on scheduling patterns, delay causes, cost escalation factors. Value density is high -- construction PM software yields $8K-$50K ACV per GC. Demand is proven: 70% of construction projects run over budget, 80% run over schedule.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The construction management software market reached $10.64B in 2025 and is projected to grow to $19.12B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence, 12.08% CAGR). Cloud solutions lead with 62.35% market share. AI-driven progress analytics is the fastest-growing segment at 14.12% CAGR. Currently, 70% of construction projects exceed budget and 80% exceed schedule. The average construction project overrun is 16% on cost and 20% on time (McKinsey Global Institute). Procore dominates large GCs but only serves ~16K customers out of 814K+ employer construction firms -- 98% of the market is unserved by modern PM software. Mid-market GCs and specialty contractors manage projects via spreadsheets, email, and paper. An AI copilot that automates RFI processing (avg 200+ RFIs per commercial project), submittal tracking, daily report generation, and schedule optimization could reduce PM labor by 30-40% per project while improving on-time/on-budget rates. At $500-$2,000/month per project (10-20x cheaper than Procore for small firms), the addressable mid-market is $3-5B.
falsification_criteria: Foundation model APIs commoditize the copilot layer, eliminating differentiation
User adoption stalls as professionals resist AI-augmented workflows in daily tasks
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B (AI-specific PM tools within $19.1B total construction software market by 2030)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture mid-market segment underserved by Procore/Autodesk. 800K+ firms with no modern PM software. Path to $100M ARR serving 10K firms at $10K ACV. Competing against spreadsheets and paper, not Procore.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $6K-$24K depending on firm size. Gross margins 80%+. CAC challenge is high (fragmented market, low digital engagement). Field sales required for larger GCs. Product-led growth possible for sub-10 employee firms.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-90 days for small firms, 6-12 months for mid-market GCs. Seasonal demand (construction is seasonal in northern US). Network effects: GCs pull subs onto platform for document sharing.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Project data compounding (scheduling patterns, cost databases, risk models trained on thousands of completed projects). Integration with BIM tools and accounting systems. Workflow lock-in once adopted mid-project.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=ai_copilot, buyer=consumer_smb, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $19120M

models.name: Dairy Herd Management & Methane Reduction Platform
models.one_liner: Integrated dairy management platform combining automated milking parlor data, individual-cow health/fertility monitoring, feed ration optimization, and methane emissions tracking for the 24,300 US dairy operations milking 9.4M cows -- where methane regulations and $28/cwt milk price volatility demand per-cow profitability optimization
models.macro_source: F1: Dairy management software market $2.8B (2025) to $5.3B (2030) at 13.6% CAGR. Robotic milking systems deployed on 10,000+ farms globally. F6: EPA methane supplemental rule (2024) targets 30% livestock methane reduction by 2030. Dairy methane: 25% of US agricultural methane emissions. California SB-1383: mandatory methane reduction for dairies >10K head. F2: US lost 28,000 dairy farms (2012-2022), consolidation accelerating: average herd size now 350 cows (up from 200 in 2012).
models.deep_dive_evidence: US dairy: 9.4M milk cows on 24,300 operations (USDA NASS 2024). Extreme consolidation: the largest 2,200 dairies (>1,000 cows) produce 67% of US milk. Average milk cow produces 24,000 lbs/year ($28.00/cwt Class III, 2024 average). Per-cow annual revenue: ~$6,720. Per-cow annual cost: $5,800-$6,400 (feed 55%, labor 15%, overhead 30%). Profit margin: $320-$920/cow/year -- razor-thin, so per-cow optimization is existential. Key management decisions: (1) Reproductive efficiency: 21-day pregnancy rate directly impacts milk production curve. AI-powered estrus detection (SCR/Allflex, Afimilk) achieves 90%+ accuracy vs 50% visual detection. Each additional day open (not pregnant) costs $3-5/day/cow. (2) Feed optimization: TMR (total mixed ration) adjusted by production group and milk component analysis. AI feed optimization saves $0.15-$0.30/cow/day. (3) Methane: dairy methane is 25% of US ag methane. Methane inhibitor (3-NOP/Bovaer, DSM) reduces enteric methane 30% but requires precise per-cow dosing ($0.20-$0.50/cow/day). California SB-1383 makes methane reduction mandatory for large dairies. (4) Mastitis detection: costs US dairy $2B/year in lost production and treatment. Inline conductivity + AI reduces detection time from 24-48hrs to <2hrs. Key players: DairyComp/Valley Ag Software (legacy herd management, 60% market share in US), Allflex/MSD (sensors), Lely/DeLaval (robotic milking), Connecterra ($35M raised, AI for dairy, Netherlands). The integration gap: sensor data (milking, activity, health) sits in separate silos. No platform integrates milking + health + feed + methane + financials into per-cow P&L.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate: DairyComp has legacy dominance (60% share) but is aging technology (DOS-era architecture, minimal AI). Allflex sensors are ubiquitous but analytics layer is weak. The integration opportunity -- combining milking parlor data, sensor data, feed management, methane tracking, and financial P&L per cow -- is unoccupied. Moat builds through per-cow performance data across thousands of herds. Value density is moderate ($2-5/cow/month = $8K-$20K ACV for 300-cow dairy) but the regulatory methane requirement creates non-discretionary demand. Demand is visible: every dairy manager knows their pregnancy rate, somatic cell count, and feed cost per cwt.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $1.0-2.5B (US dairy management software + methane compliance, subset of $5.3B global dairy software market)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: legacy incumbent + fragmented sensors
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: $2-5/cow/month subscription. 300-cow dairy: $7,200-$18,000 ACV. 3,000-cow mega-dairy: $72,000-$180,000 ACV. Gross margins 75-85% (software). Hardware integration costs offset by sensor OEM partnerships (Allflex, SCR). Methane module premium: $0.50-$1.00/cow/month additional.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Win 100-200 mid-to-large dairies (500-5,000 cows) at $25K-$50K ACV. Focus on California (1.7M dairy cows, strictest methane regulation), Wisconsin (1.2M cows), Idaho, Texas, New York. Methane compliance as entry wedge for dairies that MUST track emissions. First $5M ARR in year 2-3. Expand to dairy cooperatives (DFA, Land O'Lakes) as enterprise channel.

falsification_criteria: If Lely or DeLaval (robotic milking OEMs) build comprehensive management platforms bundled with their hardware, locking out independent software
If US dairy consolidation accelerates to the point where the top 500 operations (already producing 40%+ of milk) build proprietary systems
If methane regulation is rolled back or enforcement delayed, removing the regulatory push for emissions-integrated management

models.name: Theme Park Operations Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered operations platform for theme parks — crowd flow optimization, predictive ride maintenance, dynamic pricing, and labor scheduling for the $84B global amusement park market
models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence amusement parks ($84.2B by 2026); QCEW NAICS 713110 (224K workers, 1.1K establishments); Six Flags/Cedar Fair merger creating 42-park platform; Straits Research amusement parks ($141.2B by 2033, 5.8% CAGR)
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data shows NAICS 7131 (Amusement Parks and Arcades) has 3,885 establishments employing 256,638 workers — but the theme park sub-segment (713110) is highly concentrated: approximately 1,100 establishments (the largest averaging 200+ workers each) generating the vast majority of revenue. Employment grew an explosive 25.5% YoY as parks recovered to above pre-COVID attendance. The global amusement park market is projected at $84.2B by 2026 (Mordor Intelligence), growing to $141.2B by 2033 at 5.8% CAGR (Straits Research). The Six Flags/Cedar Fair merger created a 42-park North American platform — the most significant consolidation event in the industry, with a stated focus on operational efficiency, procurement synergies, and technology standardization. The AI operations opportunity has multiple vectors: (1) Crowd flow optimization using computer vision and mobile signal data to predict and redirect guest movement, reducing wait times 15-25%. (2) Predictive maintenance for rides — a single ride breakdown costs $50-200K in lost revenue per day; AI predictive maintenance using IoT sensors can reduce unplanned downtime 30-50%. (3) Dynamic pricing for admission and fast passes — Disney's Genie+ proved dynamic pricing works (but generated consumer backlash). (4) Labor scheduling optimization — parks employ 200-2,000 seasonal workers each and scheduling is complex (weather-dependent, attraction-dependent, compliance-heavy). Six Flags' partnership with Google Cloud deploys AI chatbots and real-time pricing. Disney's MagicBand+ is the most advanced IoT theme park wristband. Average theme park consumes 50-100 GWh annually — energy optimization is material.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is limited (4): the top operators (Disney, Universal, Six Flags/Cedar Fair, Merlin) control the majority of visitors and build proprietary technology. The addressable market for third-party platforms is mid-tier parks (water parks, regional attractions, FEC chains) — roughly 2,500+ establishments. Accesso (FTSE AIM listed) provides ticketing/queuing for parks but lacks AI operations intelligence. Moat Advantage is strong (7): operational data from ride sensors, crowd flow patterns, and weather/demand correlations compounds over seasons — a park using the system for 3+ seasons gets dramatically better predictions. Integration with ride control systems and POS creates deep technical moat. models.name: Carbon Credit Verification and Registry Platform
models.one_liner: Digital-native carbon credit registry with AI-powered MRV (measurement, reporting, verification) — rebuilding trust in voluntary carbon markets after the integrity crisis by providing satellite-verified, transparent credit issuance
models.macro_source: ICVCM Core Carbon Principles (March 2023); Article 6 of Paris Agreement operationalization (COP28); Bloomberg voluntary carbon market analysis ($2B in 2023); Verra/Gold Standard registry reform announcements; Pachama, Sylvera, and BeZero funding rounds
models.deep_dive_evidence: The voluntary carbon market experienced an integrity crisis in 2023-2024 when investigations (The Guardian, Bloomberg) found that major Verra-certified REDD+ forest carbon credits were largely worthless — up to 94% of offsets did not represent real emissions reductions. Market volume dropped from $2B (2023) to estimated $1.5B (2024) as corporate buyers paused purchases. This crisis creates a rebuild opportunity: the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) published Core Carbon Principles requiring enhanced additionality, permanence, and robust MRV. Article 6 of the Paris Agreement (operationalized at COP28/29) establishes a framework for international carbon trading that requires registry-level transparency. The technology to solve verification exists: satellite-based forest monitoring (Planet Labs provides 3m resolution daily global imagery), LiDAR-measured biomass estimation, and IoT-enabled soil carbon measurement can replace the site-visit-based verification that enabled fraud. Pachama (raised $79M) and Sylvera (raised $57M) provide AI-powered carbon credit rating and verification. BeZero ($50M raised) rates credit quality. But the registry layer itself — where credits are issued, tracked, and retired — remains controlled by legacy nonprofits (Verra, Gold Standard) using outdated systems. A digital-native registry with satellite-verified issuance, transparent methodology scoring, and real-time monitoring could capture 10-20% of a market projected to reach $50B by 2030 (TSVCM estimate, revised down from $100B). The CORSIA aviation offset mandate (2024+) creates guaranteed demand from airlines regardless of voluntary market sentiment.

models.name: Restaurant Financial Intelligence
models.one_liner: AI-powered financial management combining real-time P&L, cash flow prediction, and embedded lending for restaurants operating on 3-9% margins, targeting a $2.8B opportunity within the $14.7B restaurant management software market
models.macro_source: Grand View Research restaurant management software ($14.7B by 2030); QCEW NAICS 7225 ($285.9B total annual wages, 611K establishments); Federal Reserve small business lending data; NRA financial surveys

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): restaurant financial management is shockingly primitive — most independent restaurants use paper records or basic QuickBooks with no restaurant-specific intelligence. Toast Capital (merchant cash advances) and Square Loans provide embedded lending but not financial intelligence. xtraCHEF (acquired by Toast) focused on invoice management, not full P&L. The gap between what restaurants need (real-time margin tracking by menu item, cash flow forecasting, tax optimization) and what they have (a shoebox of receipts) is enormous. Moat Advantage is strong (7): once a platform has access to a restaurant's POS data, bank accounts, vendor invoices, and payroll, the switching cost is massive — the system becomes the restaurant's financial nervous system. Embedded lending creates additional revenue stream and lock-in. Value Density is moderate (6): $200-500/month for financial intelligence + lending revenue (2-5% of loan value). Demand Visibility is strong (7): 60% of restaurant failures cite poor financial management — this is a survival tool, not a nice-to-have.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7225 (Restaurants and Other Eating Places) has 610,970 establishments with $285.9B in total annual wages. Restaurant net margins of 3-9% mean the difference between profit and failure is often $20-50K/year — exactly the range that better financial intelligence can impact. The Federal Reserve's Small Business Credit Survey shows 64% of restaurants that applied for financing in 2024 received less than they requested. Toast Capital has originated $2B+ in merchant cash advances — proving embedded lending demand. The AI financial intelligence thesis: by connecting POS transaction data, bank account feeds, vendor invoices (via photo capture/OCR), and payroll systems, an AI can produce real-time daily P&L (most restaurants only see monthly financials from their accountant), predict cash flow 30-60 days forward (critical for a business with irregular revenue and weekly payroll), identify menu items with negative contribution margin, and pre-qualify for embedded lending based on actual financial performance rather than credit scores. Restaurant-specific financial challenges that general tools miss: tip reporting and tax obligations, COGS tracking against menu pricing, seasonal cash flow patterns (summer vs winter, holiday peaks), and multiple revenue channels (dine-in, takeout, delivery, catering) that need separate margin analysis. The 2023 QCEW data shows average restaurant pay of $26,097 ($502/week) with total sector wages of $285.9B — the payroll processing and compliance layer alone is a $1B+ market.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

LTV: $7,200 (18-month retention at $400/mo). CAC: $600-1,200 (PLG possible — free P&L tool as lead gen for premium features and lending). LTV:CAC of 6-12x.

Lending pre-qualification creates immediate monetization path for capital-constrained restaurants. Tax season (Q1, Q4) creates urgency spikes for financial management tools.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Financial data access is the ultimate switching cost — a restaurant cannot easily disconnect its bank feed, POS integration, and vendor invoice history. Credit underwriting model improves with data — more restaurant financial histories = better lending decisions = lower default rates = better loan terms = more restaurants attracted. Multi-location restaurant groups create enterprise accounts with even deeper data access.

models.macro_source: Mordor Intelligence: smart waste management market $3.5B in 2025, $7.2B by 2030 (15.1% CAGR). Mordor Intelligence: robotic waste sorting systems $2.8B in 2025, $6.7B by 2030 (18.6% CAGR). Market.us: AI in waste management $18.2B by 2033 (27% CAGR). China National Sword policy (2018) redirected global recycling, forcing US to build domestic sorting capacity. AI sorting increases recycling efficiency 60% (Columbia Climate School, June 2025).

cla.rationale: Market openness moderate — AMP Robotics (raised $190M+, deployed 400+ systems), ZenRobotics (TOMRA-owned), Machinex, and Bollegraaf compete in robotic sorting. But the software/analytics layer (contamination detection, stream optimization, commodity pricing) is less crowded. Moat advantage high because waste stream data is facility-specific and compounds — more data = better sorting accuracy = higher commodity recovery rates = higher recycling revenue. Value density moderate: average MRF processes $5-50M annually in recyclable commodities, and AI sorting can increase commodity recovery value 20-40%. Demand visibility strong: 9,800 MRFs in US, many still using manual sorting.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The US waste management market was $42.7B in 2023 and is projected to reach $63.3B by 2030 (Grand View Research, 4.7% CAGR). The smart waste management market stood at $3.5B in 2025 and is forecast to reach $7.2B by 2030 at 15.1% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). Robotic waste sorting systems are the fastest-growing segment: $2.8B in 2025 growing at 18.6% CAGR to $6.7B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence). AI vision-based sorting is growing at 20.1% CAGR (highest in the category). The US has approximately 9,800 Materials Recovery Facilities (MRFs), of which only 15-20% have AI-enabled sorting as of 2025. China's National Sword policy (2018) rejected contaminated recyclables from the US, forcing domestic processing infrastructure development. AI-enabled recycling systems demonstrate 60% efficiency increase (Columbia Climate School, June 2025) and can sort at rates of 80+ picks per minute versus 30-40 picks per minute for human sorters. AMP Robotics has raised $190M+ and deployed 400+ systems globally, processing 90B+ objects through its AI system. The economics are compelling: contamination reduces recyclable commodity value by 30-50%. AI contamination detection and sorting can recover $10-30M annually in otherwise-lost commodity value across a large MRF network. Waste Management Inc. ($20.4B revenue) and Republic Services ($16.7B) dominate the industry but are actively seeking technology partners — Republic Services specifically targets technology-enabled route optimization and facility automation in its strategy.

models.name: Space Debris Tracking and Collision Avoidance
models.one_liner: AI-powered space situational awareness platform providing real-time debris tracking, conjunction analysis, and collision avoidance maneuver planning for satellite operators managing 10,000+ active satellites amid 36,000+ tracked debris objects
models.macro_source: FCC 5-year deorbit rule (effective September 2024); ESA Space Debris Office statistics; SpaceX Starlink constellation (6,000+ satellites, 12,000 planned); 18th Space Defense Squadron conjunction data; LeoLabs and ExoAnalytic funding rounds
models.deep_dive_evidence: The orbital debris problem is reaching a critical threshold. The US Space Surveillance Network tracks 36,500+ objects larger than 10cm, but the estimated population includes 130M+ objects larger than 1mm — any of which can damage or destroy a satellite at orbital velocities (7-8 km/s in LEO). SpaceX alone has launched 6,000+ Starlink satellites with 12,000 planned; Amazon's Kuiper, OneWeb, and Chinese constellations add thousands more. The FCC's September 2024 rule requiring satellite deorbit within 5 years of mission end (reduced from 25 years) creates a regulatory mandate for active debris management. The 18th Space Defense Squadron issues 20,000+ conjunction warnings per day but cannot provide the granular, operator-specific collision avoidance analysis that constellation operators need. This gap is the commercial opportunity. LeoLabs (raised $82M) operates a ground-based radar network providing LEO tracking. ExoAnalytic Solutions uses optical telescopes. Neither provides the integrated conjunction analysis + automated maneuver planning that operators need at mega-constellation scale. The space situational awareness market is projected at $1.8B by 2028 (Allied Market Research). Each new satellite launch increases the tracking requirement exponentially (each new object creates conjunction possibilities with every existing object). Insurance is a driver: space insurance premiums ($600M+ annual market) increasingly require demonstrated collision avoidance capability. ESA's ClearSpace-1 active debris removal mission (2026 launch) validates the seriousness of the problem. The data moat: tracking history for 10,000+ objects over years creates a propagation model that improves conjunction prediction accuracy — new entrants cannot replicate historical observation data.

Customer payback: replaces $3,000-4,000/month equivalent human labor, 3-6 month payback. Fleet of 500 robots = $6-12M ARR. Break-even at ~200-300 deployed units.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Janitorial labor shortage accelerating (post-COVID hygiene standards + immigration enforcement reducing available workforce). Walmart, Kroger, Sam's Club already deploying at scale (30K+ Brain Corp robots). Hospital/healthcare facilities fastest-growing segment. RaaS model eliminates CapEx barrier for mid-market customers.

models.name: Controlled Environment Agriculture Operating System
models.one_liner: AI-powered greenhouse and indoor farm management platform controlling HVAC, irrigation, lighting, CO2 enrichment, and IPM (integrated pest management) to optimize yield per square foot and energy cost per gram -- serving the 35,000+ US greenhouse operations and surviving indoor farming companies after the 2022-2024 vertical farming shakeout
models.macro_source: F1: CEA (controlled environment agriculture) technology market $4.1B (2025) to $9.8B (2030) at 19.0% CAGR. AI climate control reduces energy costs 20-35% (Priva, Ridder, Argus data). F6: Greenhouse energy: 20-40% of operating costs. Natural gas price directly impacts profitability. LED efficiency improving 15% annually, reducing electricity cost per PAR photon. F4: Post-shakeout (AppHarvest bankrupt, AeroFarms bankrupt, Kalera bankrupt) the surviving CEA operators need COST OPTIMIZATION, not growth capital.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US greenhouse production: 35,000+ operations, 1.2B sq ft of covered production area (USDA Census 2022). Revenue: $18.6B (greenhouse, nursery, floriculture combined). The sector spans: traditional greenhouse tomatoes/peppers/cucumbers (Mastronardi/Sunset, NatureFresh, Village Farms), cannabis cultivation (legal in 38 states, $30B market), ornamental/nursery (largest segment by revenue), and indoor vertical farming (post-shakeout survivors: Bowery, Plenty/Walmart-backed, Little Leaf Farms, Gotham Greens). The 2022-2024 shakeout destroyed $5B+ in invested capital: AppHarvest (bankrupt, APPH stock to $0), AeroFarms (bankrupt, $238M raised lost), Kalera (bankrupt), Fifth Season (shut down). Survivors share one trait: COST CONTROL, not growth-at-all-costs. The software opportunity: Priva (Netherlands, $300M+ revenue) and Argus Controls (Conviron) dominate greenhouse climate control hardware but analytics are basic. No platform integrates: (1) AI-optimized climate recipes (temperature, humidity, CO2, light by crop stage), (2) energy cost optimization (time-of-use electricity pricing, natural gas vs electric heating), (3) IPM scouting with computer vision (thrips, aphids, powdery mildew detection at 95%+ accuracy), (4) yield prediction and harvest planning. Energy is 20-40% of CEA operating costs. AI climate optimization reduces energy 20-35% (validated at Wageningen University greenhouse trials). For a 10-acre greenhouse operation spending $2M/year on energy, that is $400K-$700K in annual savings. Software at $50K-$100K/year is 7-14x ROI.

cla.rationale: Market openness is high: Priva and Argus control the hardware layer but their software is basic (setpoint control, not AI optimization). The AI analytics layer on top of existing climate control systems is greenfield. Moat builds through crop-specific growth models trained on millions of sensor data points (a tomato climate recipe is useless for cannabis). Value density is high per operation ($50K-$200K ACV for large greenhouses). Demand visibility is strong: every greenhouse operator knows their energy cost per lb of production and wants it lower. Post-shakeout survivors are the ideal customers -- they are focused on unit economics, not hypergrowth.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
