models.name: Construction Materials Procurement & Supply Chain AI
models.one_liner: AI-powered materials procurement platform with real-time pricing, demand forecasting, and supply chain visibility for the $1.5B construction procurement software market growing to $2.6B by 2032 -- reducing material cost overruns that average 10-15% of project budgets
models.macro_source: F1: AI demand forecasting reducing procurement costs 5-15%. F3: Steel tariffs (25% Section 232) and lumber volatility (2-3x range) create urgent need for supply chain visibility. Construction procurement software market $1.5B (2025) to $2.6B (2032), 8.1% CAGR (GM Insights, ResearchAndMarkets).

cla.rationale: Existing players include HCSS (heavy civil focused), BIM 360 (Autodesk, design-integrated), Procore (PM-integrated procurement), and general procurement platforms (Coupa, SAP Ariba) that serve construction poorly. Construction-specific AI procurement startups include StructionSite, Kojo ($51M raised, materials procurement for electrical contractors), and Voyage Control. Kojo has validated the niche approach (starting with electrical materials). The market is moderately open because construction procurement is uniquely complex: project-based (not recurring), geographically variable, subject to long lead times, and requires integration with project schedules. Value density is moderate -- savings of 5-15% on materials (which are 40-60% of project cost) create clear ROI. Moat from pricing data accumulation across thousands of projects.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction materials represent 40-60% of project costs ($840B-$1.26T of $2.1T US construction spending). Material cost overruns average 10-15% per project (McKinsey). Lumber price volatility: 2021 peak $1,700/MBF, 2023 low $350/MBF, 2025 ranging $450-$650/MBF. Steel: 25% tariff adds $200-400/ton. Concrete: up 30% since 2020. Construction procurement software market: $1.5B (2025) to $2.6B (2032) at 8.1% CAGR (GM Insights). Kojo ($51M raised, Series B 2023) proved the vertical approach by focusing on electrical contractor materials procurement -- claims 10-15% cost savings, 90%+ procurement digitization for customers. The broader opportunity is an AI platform that: (1) aggregates pricing across suppliers for real-time comparison, (2) forecasts material price movements using commodity futures, tariff signals, and demand indicators, (3) optimizes order timing and quantities based on project schedules and storage constraints, (4) provides supply chain visibility (lead time tracking, alternative sourcing). At $2.1T in total construction spending and 40-60% materials share, even 1% efficiency improvement = $8-12B in value created.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.6B (construction procurement software by 2032, AI-specific layer ~$800M)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Kojo proved the vertical approach ($51M raised, electrical contractors). Replicable across plumbing, HVAC, concrete, steel. Path to $100M ARR serving 10K contractor firms at $10K ACV. Trade-specific knowledge creates defensible niches.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $5K-$30K per contractor depending on size and trade. Gross margins 75-80%. Transaction-based pricing also possible (% of procurement volume). CAC high in fragmented market but trade associations provide channel.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-90 days (cost savings are immediate and measurable). Price volatility events (tariff changes, supply shortages) create urgency spikes. Trade-specific go-to-market (start with one trade, expand).
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Pricing database across thousands of suppliers and projects. Material-specific demand forecasting models. Supplier relationship data. Integration with project schedules and accounting systems.

models.name: Algorithmic Oil & Gas Production Optimization Platform
models.one_liner: Cloud-based AI platform for real-time well monitoring, decline curve optimization, artificial lift management, and production forecasting — targeting $3.2B digital oilfield market growing to $8.7B by 2030 across 900,000+ active US wells operated by 9,000+ independent producers
models.macro_source: EIA: 900,000+ active US oil and gas wells. 9,000+ independent producers operate 83% of US wells but produce 62% of output. Digital oilfield market $3.2B (2024) to $8.7B (2030) at 18.2% CAGR (Grand View Research). Permian Basin: 6.1M bbl/day, 44% of US output. Average well decline rate: 70-80% in first year for unconventional wells. AI production optimization demonstrated 5-15% production uplift and 20-30% reduction in unplanned downtime in pilot deployments (McKinsey, 2024). Oil & gas digital spending: $28B+ globally in 2025.
models.deep_dive_evidence: The US has 900,000+ active oil and gas wells (EIA, 2024), operated by a fragmented landscape: ExxonMobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips dominate by production, but 9,000+ independent producers operate 83% of wells. The average independent operates 5-50 wells and lacks the IT infrastructure, data science teams, and procurement budgets to deploy enterprise digital oilfield platforms (SLB Delfi starts at $500K+ implementation). The technology opportunity is clear: unconventional wells (horizontal wells with hydraulic fracturing) decline 70-80% in their first year. Optimizing artificial lift (rod pump, ESP, gas lift) timing, completions design, and well spacing can recover 10-30% more EUR (estimated ultimate recovery). AI platforms like Ambyint, Kelvin, Validere, and Corva target this optimization layer. Ambyint reports 5-15% production improvement on wells using its AI-optimized rod pump control. Kelvin claims 12% production increase and 30% downtime reduction across its deployment base. The Permian Basin alone produces 6.1M bbl/day across ~180,000 horizontal wells — a 5% production improvement is worth $3.5B/year in incremental revenue at $65/bbl. SLB's Delfi platform has been deployed at 200+ operators with $2B+ digital revenue, but its target customer is the major/super-independent with 1,000+ wells. The gap between SLB Delfi (enterprise, $500K+ implementation) and independent producers (need $5-50K/year solutions, self-service, no IT staff) is where mid-market vertical SaaS captures value. The critical innovation is ingesting SCADA data from existing well controllers (without hardware replacement), applying ML to detect artificial lift inefficiencies, predict failures, and recommend optimizations — a software overlay on existing infrastructure.

cla.rationale: The digital oilfield space has major incumbents: SLB Delfi platform ($2B+ digital revenue), Halliburton DecisionSpace, Baker Hughes Leucipa, and Emerson (Paradigm). These platforms are enterprise-grade, integrated with the OFS majors' hardware and services. MO is 5 because incumbents are strong but focused on majors/super-independents — 9,000+ independents operating <100 wells each are underserved. MA is 6 because well-level production data compounds (predicting decline behavior, artificial lift optimization, completion design feedback), but data portability is moderate. VD is 8 because a 5-15% production uplift on a 500 bbl/day well is $50-150K/year additional revenue per well — massive per-unit value. DV is 7 — oil demand is structural (100M+ bbl/day global) but prices are cyclical.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8.7B digital oilfield market by 2030 (Grand View Research). Independent producer segment: $1.5-3B (estimated 20-35% of digital oilfield TAM serving operators with <500 wells). Broader addressable: 9,000+ independents x $50-200K/year = $450M-1.8B immediate TAM.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in the mid-market gap between enterprise OFS platforms and spreadsheet-managed independents. Critical success factor: deploy without requiring IT staff or hardware changes. Must integrate with SCADA systems already installed on wells (Allen-Bradley, Emerson ROC, ABB). Land-and-expand within basins: win 5-10 operators in the Permian, become the reference, then expand to Bakken, Eagle Ford, DJ Basin.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $50-200/well/month. 50-well operator = $30K-120K ACV. Gross margins 75-80% (cloud compute + ML inference costs). Customer payback: 5-15% production uplift on a $200K/year well = $10-30K/year value per well vs $600-2,400/year cost. 5-10x ROI. Low churn once integrated (production data becomes institutional knowledge).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Oil prices above $60/bbl sustain independent producer economics and technology budgets. Permian Basin exhaustion (fewer Tier 1 locations) forces operators to maximize EUR from existing wells, increasing optimization value. Production decline rates increasing as sweet spots deplete — making optimization MORE valuable over time. PE-backed E&P companies (acquisition-heavy) need standardized production analytics across acquired asset portfolios.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Well-level production data compounds: ML models trained on 10,000+ wells with completion data, geology, and production history outperform models trained on 100 wells. Basin-specific expertise (Permian geology differs from Bakken) creates geographic moats. Integration with SCADA systems creates switching costs — ripping out a production optimization platform requires retraining operators and losing historical analytics. Operator network effects: anonymized production benchmarking across an operator community creates value that single-operator tools cannot replicate.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) SLB, Halliburton, or Baker Hughes launch affordable mid-market versions of their digital platforms, closing the independent producer gap; (2) Oil prices decline below $40/bbl sustained, collapsing independent producer economics and eliminating technology spending; (3) Independent producers refuse to share well data with cloud platforms due to competitive concerns (many operators consider production data proprietary); (4) Well-level AI optimization demonstrates <3% production improvement in large-scale deployments, insufficient to justify subscription costs for small operators.

models.name: Quarry Operations Optimization & Aggregate Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-driven platform optimizing blast design, crush/screen circuits, fleet dispatching, and demand forecasting for the 6,800+ US quarry operations producing $75B+ in aggregates annually — where 80%+ of operations are managed through manual methods and tribal knowledge
models.macro_source: USGS: US produced 2.9B tonnes of crushed stone and sand/gravel in 2024 ($38B crushed stone, $22B sand/gravel). 6,800+ quarry establishments averaging 12 workers each (QCEW). Aggregates market projected $75B+ by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence). Vulcan Materials ($8.5B revenue), Martin Marietta ($6.8B), and Summit Materials ($3.5B) dominate but long tail of 5,000+ small operators. IIJA infrastructure spending driving aggregate demand +4-6% through 2028. Average quarry manager age: 52 (NSSGA survey). Blast-to-product optimization demonstrated 15-25% improvement in crusher throughput through AI-guided drill pattern design.
models.deep_dive_evidence: The US aggregates industry produces 2.9B tonnes annually across 6,800+ operations, making it the highest-volume mining sector by tonnage. The industry is structurally divided: the top 5 producers (Vulcan Materials, Martin Marietta, CRH, Heidelberg Materials, Summit Materials) control ~30% of production, while 5,000+ independent operators produce the remaining 70%. These independents typically operate 1-5 quarries each, employ 5-25 workers per site, and manage operations through decades of accumulated tribal knowledge. The technology stack at a typical independent quarry: a truck scale (for ticketing), a maintenance log (paper or spreadsheet), and a blast log (paper). No production optimization, no demand forecasting, no fleet dispatching software. The transformation opportunity spans the full quarry value chain: (1) DRILL & BLAST OPTIMIZATION — blast pattern design determines fragmentation, which determines crusher throughput and product yield. AI-guided blast design (using downhole drilling data, rock mass classification, and fragmentation imaging) has demonstrated 15-25% improvement in crusher throughput. Companies: Orica (BlastIQ), Austin Powder, Strayos (AI fragmentation analysis). (2) CRUSH/SCREEN CIRCUIT OPTIMIZATION — crushing and screening circuits consume 60-80% of quarry energy and determine product mix yield. AI-based circuit optimization adjusts CSS (closed-side settings), feed rates, and screen deck configurations to maximize high-value product yield. Metso (Metrics), FLSmidth (ECS/ProcessExpert), and Sandvik provide equipment-level optimization but lack cross-circuit intelligence. (3) FLEET DISPATCHING — haul truck allocation between faces, crushers, and stockpiles is typically managed by radio communication. GPS fleet management (Wenco, Modular Mining) exists for large mines but is overbuilt for 10-truck quarry fleets. (4) DEMAND FORECASTING — aggregates demand is hyper-local (25-50 mile transport radius) and seasonal (construction cycles). Correlating local building permits, DOT project schedules, and weather data to forecast demand enables production planning and inventory optimization. (5) QUALITY CONTROL — aggregate specifications (gradation, LA abrasion, soundness) must meet ASTM/AASHTO standards for DOT contracts. Automated quality testing and spec compliance tracking reduces rejection rates. The IIJA is creating unprecedented aggregate demand: $110B for roads and bridges alone will consume billions of tonnes of crushed stone over 2024-2030. Quarries in IIJA project corridors are running at capacity.

cla.rationale: MO is 7 because quarry operations software is an underserved market — most quarry managers use paper tickets, spreadsheets, and truck scale readings. Existing mine planning software (Hexagon, Maptek, Deswik) targets large mines, not quarries. CRH, Heidelberg Materials, and major aggregates producers are building internal digital capabilities but not selling them externally. MA is 6 because quarry-specific optimization data (fragmentation analysis → crush circuit → product spec yield) compounds but each quarry has unique geology and equipment. VD is 5 because individual quarry margins are thin ($2-5/tonne on a 500K-2M tonne/year operation = $1-10M gross profit). DV is 8 — aggregate demand is driven by construction and infrastructure, currently boosted by $1.2T IIJA spending.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=physical_production_ai, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: Quarry operations software market: $400-800M by 2030 (estimated from $75B aggregates market at 0.5-1% technology spend rate). Digital mine management for quarries specifically: limited market sizing exists because market researchers don't separately track quarry-specific software vs broader mining software. Direct addressable: 6,800+ quarries x $20-100K/year = $136M-680M.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture highly feasible because the market is greenfield — no dominant quarry operations platform exists. The major quarry companies (Vulcan, Martin Marietta) build internally; independents use nothing. Entry strategy: mobile-first platform requiring zero IT infrastructure (quarries don't have server rooms). GPS fleet tracking + truck ticketing (replacing paper tickets) as the wedge, then expand to blast optimization, crush circuit optimization, and demand forecasting. Quarry associations (NSSGA) and equipment dealers are distribution channels.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $2-8K/month per quarry operation. 500-quarry customer base = $12-48M ARR. Gross margins 75-80% (mobile SaaS + GPS hardware margins). Customer payback: 15% improvement in crusher throughput on a 1M tonne/year quarry producing $10/tonne = $1.5M/year incremental revenue vs $36-96K/year platform cost — 15-40x ROI. Low implementation cost: deploy in 1-2 days with GPS trackers on trucks and mobile app for operators. The key: quarry operators think in dollars-per-tonne, not SaaS metrics.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: IIJA demand surge creating capacity pressure — quarries at capacity NEED optimization, not expansion (permitting a new quarry takes 5-10 years). Quarry operator retirement wave (average age 52) means tribal knowledge is being lost — platform captures institutional knowledge. Equipment dealer channel ready: Komatsu, Cat, Volvo construction equipment dealers serve quarries and can bundle software with equipment packages. ESG reporting requirements reaching mid-tier operators for the first time.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Quarry-specific operational data compounds (blast → fragmentation → crusher → product yield feedback loops improve with each blast cycle). Hyper-local demand data (correlating building permits, DOT projects, and weather to quarry-level demand) is defensible because data collection across 6,800+ quarries creates geographic coverage. Truck ticketing and scale integration creates transactional lock-in. Equipment-agnostic integration (works with Cat, Komatsu, Volvo, Metso, Sandvik equipment) avoids OEM lock-out.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) Vulcan Materials, Martin Marietta, or CRH commercialize their internal digital quarry platforms and sell to independents, closing the technology gap; (2) Quarry operators refuse to adopt technology due to 'it's always worked this way' mindset and thin margins (aggregates is a low-margin commodity business where operators resist SaaS subscriptions); (3) Aggregate demand declines (construction downturn or IIJA funding delays), compressing quarry margins below the threshold where technology investment makes sense; (4) Equipment OEMs (Metso, Sandvik, Caterpillar) bundle operation-level optimization into equipment purchases, making standalone quarry software unnecessary.

models.name: Mining Commodity Intelligence & Supply Chain Traceability Platform
models.one_liner: Real-time commodity market intelligence platform combining satellite production monitoring, vessel tracking, supply chain traceability, and ESG scoring for critical minerals — targeting $5.2B commodity trading analytics market where OEMs (Tesla, Apple, BMW) require provenance tracking for $200B+ in annual mineral procurement
models.macro_source: EU Battery Regulation (2024): requires full supply chain due diligence and carbon footprint declaration for batteries sold in EU by 2027. SEC conflict minerals rule (Section 1502 Dodd-Frank) requires supply chain disclosure. EU Critical Raw Materials Act: mandatory recycling targets and supply chain audits. Tesla, Apple, BMW, and VW all have critical minerals sourcing policies requiring chain-of-custody documentation. Commodity trading analytics market $5.2B by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets). Critical mineral supply chain value: $200B+ annually. Satellite-based production monitoring companies: Orbital Insight, Planet Labs, Kayrros, SpaceKnow. Supply chain traceability: Circulor, Everledger, ReTrace.
models.sector_name: Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction — Cross-Sector Intelligence
models.deep_dive_evidence: The critical minerals supply chain is the most geopolitically contested industrial system in the world. China controls 70%+ of rare earth mining, 87% of rare earth processing, 70%+ of cobalt refining, 77% of lithium cell manufacturing, and 100% of natural graphite processing (IEA Critical Minerals Review 2024). This concentration creates national security vulnerability for the US, EU, Japan, and South Korea — recognized by the IRA ($7B+ mining incentives), EU Critical Raw Materials Act (2024), and Japan's Mineral Security Strategy (2023). The regulatory response is creating MANDATORY supply chain traceability: (1) EU Battery Regulation (effective 2024, fully enforced 2027): requires every EV battery sold in the EU to have a digital passport documenting the full supply chain (mine → refiner → cathode manufacturer → cell maker → battery pack), carbon footprint, and recycled content. Penalties for non-compliance: product ban from EU market. (2) SEC Section 1502 (Dodd-Frank): requires public companies to disclose use of conflict minerals (tin, tantalum, tungsten, gold) from DRC and adjoining countries. (3) EU Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD): requires supply chain human rights and environmental due diligence for companies operating in the EU. OEM response: Tesla's 2024 Impact Report commits to 100% traceable battery materials by 2026. Apple requires cobalt smelter audits covering 100% of supply. BMW's supply chain traceability platform tracks lithium from mine to vehicle. VW's Power Co commits to battery passport compliance for EU market. This creates a B2B platform opportunity: (1) SATELLITE MONITORING — track mine production volumes using multispectral satellite imagery (stockpile changes, pit expansion, tailings growth, truck activity). Validate supplier production claims against physical evidence. (2) COMMODITY FLOW TRACKING — map mineral flows from mine → concentrator → smelter/refinery → product using shipping data (AIS vessel tracking), trade statistics, and customs declarations. Detect transshipment (Chinese minerals re-exported through third countries). (3) ESG SCORING — quantify environmental and social performance at the mine level using satellite data (deforestation, water discharge, tailings stability), worker safety records, and community impact. (4) BATTERY PASSPORT — provide EU Battery Regulation-compliant digital passport infrastructure for battery supply chains.

cla.rationale: MO is 6 because several players address fragments of this opportunity: S&P Global Market Intelligence (commodity data, $4B+ revenue), Orbital Insight/Planet Labs (satellite production monitoring), Circulor/ReTrace (supply chain traceability), and RCS Global/Minespider (responsible sourcing). But no platform integrates real-time satellite monitoring + commodity analytics + supply chain traceability + ESG scoring into a unified critical minerals intelligence product. MA is 7 because the combination of satellite imagery archives, commodity flow data, supplier audit records, and ESG verification creates a data asset that compounds — more supply chains tracked = better anomaly detection and price prediction. VD is 7 because commodity trading decisions are high-value ($1M-1B per trade) and supply chain compliance failures are costly (EU penalties, reputational damage, procurement disruption). DV is 8 — regulatory mandates (EU Battery Regulation, SEC conflict minerals) create compulsory demand.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B commodity trading analytics market by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets). Critical minerals traceability/ESG compliance layer: $1-2.5B by 2030 (estimated from EU Battery Regulation compliance costs + OEM supply chain audit spending + commodity intelligence demand). Battery passport infrastructure: $500M-1B by 2028 (EU Battery Regulation driving 100M+ battery passports required annually by 2027).
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible because the market is MANDATE-DRIVEN — EU Battery Regulation compliance is not optional for any company selling batteries in Europe. The integration challenge (satellite + shipping + trade data + ESG audits) is complex enough that no single incumbent covers the full stack. Entry strategy: battery passport compliance for EU market as the wedge (immediate regulatory deadline), then expand to broader commodity intelligence and ESG scoring. OEM procurement teams (Tesla, BMW, Apple) are the buyers — they are mandated to perform due diligence and will pay for platforms that automate it.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $200K-2M/year per OEM customer for supply chain intelligence. Battery passport infrastructure: $1-5 per passport issued (100M+ annual volume by 2028 = $100-500M revenue opportunity at scale). Gross margins 70-80% (satellite data licensing + analytics platform). Customer payback: avoiding EU market access loss (batteries banned from sale = $100M-1B revenue impact for auto OEMs) provides unlimited ROI for compliance. Due diligence labor reduction: 60-80% of manual supply chain audit work automated.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: EU Battery Regulation deadlines creating urgency (carbon footprint declaration 2025, recycled content 2027, full battery passport 2027). US critical minerals policy accelerating (IRA, DOD investments). OEM supply chain diversification from China creating demand for alternative supplier validation. Cobalt, lithium, and nickel price volatility making real-time supply/demand intelligence more valuable. EU CSDDD expanding due diligence requirements beyond batteries to all raw materials.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Satellite imagery archive compounds (historical production monitoring enables anomaly detection and trend analysis). Supply chain mapping data is proprietary and difficult to replicate (requires years of trade flow analysis, customs data aggregation, and supplier relationship documentation). Multi-data-source integration (satellite + AIS shipping + trade statistics + ESG audits) creates a platform that is greater than the sum of its parts. Regulatory compliance certification relationships (third-party verified under EU Battery Regulation) create trust moat.

models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) EU Battery Regulation enforcement is delayed or weakened, removing the compliance mandate that drives adoption; (2) S&P Global Market Intelligence builds a comprehensive critical minerals traceability platform on top of its existing commodity data infrastructure; (3) Major OEMs (Tesla, BMW, VW) build internal supply chain monitoring capabilities, eliminating the need for third-party platforms; (4) China retaliates against supply chain traceability by restricting mineral exports through traceable channels, pushing procurement to untraceable grey market sources; (5) Blockchain-based traceability solutions (Circulor, Everledger, Minespider) achieve industry standard status, making a satellite-intelligence-driven approach less relevant.

models.name: Travel Nurse Optimization Network
models.one_liner: Two-sided marketplace connecting administrative and support services supply and demand with AI-driven matching, pricing, and quality assurance

deep_dive_evidence.market_size: Travel nursing market: $12B (2025). Did NOT deflate to pre-COVID $5B — structural demand confirmed. Expected to reach $15-18B by 2028.
deep_dive_evidence.agency_economics: Typical agency bill rate: $85-120/hr. Nurse pay: $45-65/hr. Agency gross margin: 30-45%. Overhead (recruiters, compliance, facilities): 15-20%. Net margin: 10-25%. AI marketplace model: bill rate $70-100/hr, nurse pay $55-75/hr, platform take: 15-25%. Both sides win.
deep_dive_evidence.p027_parallel: IT staffing intermediary decline (RHI -53%, MAN -44%) is the direct parallel. Healthcare staffing agencies face identical Coasean transaction cost collapse. The lag is 12-18 months because healthcare credentials are more complex to verify than IT skills.
deep_dive_evidence.funded_competitors: Trusted Health ($149M raised), Nomad Health ($197M raised), Incredible Health ($80M raised), ShiftMed ($200M raised). Total VC investment in nurse marketplace/staffing AI: $800M+. Market is well-funded but fragmented.

models.macro_source: Healthcare staffing crisis (P-039) created a $12B travel nursing market with 80-150% agency markups. Nurses earn $3,200-4,500/week on travel contracts but agencies capture 30-45% of the bill rate. The intermediary extraction is a T10 Coase transaction cost artifact: high information asymmetry (where are the shortages? which credentials match?) justifies agency fees. AI collapses the information asymmetry, enabling direct matching with transparent pricing. Both sides benefit: hospitals pay less, nurses earn more, agencies' margin is redistributed.

models.name: Automated Watermarking and Model Provenance Registry
models.one_liner: Universal AI output watermarking and model lineage tracking system, enabling regulatory compliance and content attribution at scale.
models.key_v3_context: EU AI Act Article 50 requires that AI-generated content be labeled. This is a regulatory mandate creating a new infrastructure layer. C2PA and other standards are emerging but no dominant platform exists. The model provenance problem (which model generated which output, with what training data) is increasingly important for liability and compliance. This is infrastructure for the fear economy — not a direct fear product, but the plumbing that governance, safety, and compliance products need.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + EU AI Act Mandate

cla.rationale: Heuristic scored 7/7/5/7=73.0 via fear_economy_capture. Reality: AI watermarking/provenance market is nascent but C2PA coalition (200+ members) led by Adobe, Microsoft, Google is setting standards. Google SynthID provides free watermarking. EU AI Act mandates visible disclosures after Aug 2026. No single dominant commercial platform but hyperscalers embedding capabilities natively. Market is between nascent (good for entrants) and being captured by big tech (bad for entrants). Keeping MO at 7 (nascent commercial market, but C2PA creates standard), keeping MA at 7 (no established moats yet but Google/Adobe positioning), raising VD from 5 to 6 (capture, embedding, detection, verification, registry, marketplace layers), keeping DV at 7 (regulatory mandates + deepfake escalation create forcing functions).

models.deep_dive_evidence: Predictive maintenance reduces unplanned downtime 20-40% (industry consensus). Manufacturing equipment average age 12-15 years for CNC machines in SMB shops. Unplanned downtime costs $10-50K+ per hour in lost production. Industrial IoT market $110B+ (2025). Vibration sensor costs below $100/unit. 40% of large manufacturers deployed PdM (2026 projection), but <10% of SMBs. 392K manufacturing establishments, 280K+ with <50 employees running legacy equipment. MachineMetrics raised $50M+ for machine monitoring. Augury raised $350M+.
models.macro_source: Predictive maintenance reduces unplanned downtime 20-40%. 392K manufacturing establishments with aging equipment (average CNC machine age 12-15 years). Retrofit approach serves the 280K+ shops that cannot afford new equipment.

cla.rationale: Predictive maintenance is proven technology with clear ROI (avoiding one unplanned downtime event at $10-50K/hr pays for months of monitoring). The market challenge is DISTRIBUTION, not technology: reaching 280K+ small manufacturers who run 12-15 year old CNC machines, presses, and processing equipment. Incumbents (Augury, Senseye) focus on enterprise deployments ($100K+ contracts). A retrofit solution at <$5K per machine with self-install wireless sensors could capture the SMB long tail. MO is 6 because incumbents exist, but the price point and distribution model for SMB is underserved.

models.sector_name: Grocery and Related Product Merchant Wholesalers
models.deep_dive_evidence: US food distribution is a $300B+ market dominated by Sysco ($76B revenue, 16% share), US Foods ($37B, 10%), and Performance Food Group ($58B, 7%). But the remaining ~67% of the market is served by 16,000+ independent and regional distributors averaging $10-50M in revenue. These mid-market distributors run on legacy systems (many still on AS/400 or paper-based routing), face rising costs (diesel, labor, refrigeration), and now confront FSMA 204 compliance — the FDA's food traceability rule requiring one-up/one-back traceability for high-risk foods effective January 2026. Non-compliance penalties: up to $10M+ per violation for repeated offenses. The technology gap is stark: Sysco spends $700M+/year on IT; a typical $20M independent distributor spends $50-100K. AI route optimization alone can reduce distribution costs 10-15% — on a 3-5% net margin business, this is transformative. Perishable dynamic pricing (adjusting prices based on remaining shelf life, demand patterns, competitor pricing) can improve gross margins 100-200bps. Cold chain IoT monitoring reduces spoilage (currently 10-12% for produce) by 30-40%. Choco ($300M raised, food ordering platform) and BlueCart (acquired by US Foods) validated the food distribution SaaS category but neither solved routing, compliance, or pricing.

cla.rationale: Market is open — 16K+ independent food distributors with inadequate technology. No dominant vertical SaaS player for food distribution (Choco is ordering-only, BlueCart was acquired). Moat builds through FSMA compliance data (audit trails are sticky) and route optimization models trained on delivery patterns. Value chain depth is strong: ordering, routing, compliance, pricing, inventory, cold chain monitoring = 6 monetizable modules. Demand visibility is high — FSMA 204 creates a regulatory forcing function for adoption.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.2B (food distribution technology including SaaS, IoT, and analytics — Mordor Intelligence, 14% CAGR through 2030)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented — no dominant vertical SaaS platform. Choco ($300M raised, ordering only). Silo (food ERP, early stage). Legacy: Yellow Dog, CrunchTime (restaurant-focused). Sysco LABS and US Foods technology are internal-only.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $12K-$60K depending on distributor size and modules. Base platform (ordering + routing): $1K-2K/month. Add-ons: FSMA compliance ($500/month), cold chain IoT ($200/device/year), dynamic pricing ($1K-3K/month). Gross margins 75-80%. CAC challenge: reaching fragmented distributors requires food industry trade shows, distributor association partnerships (IFDA, FMI).
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Target FSMA 204 compliance as wedge — urgent, deadline-driven. Sign 200 distributors at $2K/month base = $4.8M ARR. Upsell routing and pricing modules to reach $5M+ by Month 18.

falsification_criteria: If Sysco or US Foods extend their technology platforms to independent distributors as a service (Sysco LABS already exploring this)
If FSMA 204 enforcement is delayed or weakened under deregulatory administration, reducing compliance urgency
If food distributor consolidation accelerates (Sysco/US Foods acquiring independents), shrinking the addressable mid-market

models.name: Government Benefits Eligibility & Case Management Platform
models.one_liner: AI copilot for government social services case workers, automating benefits eligibility determination, document verification, and case management across Medicaid (80M enrollees), SNAP (42M recipients), and TANF programs — serving 3,100+ county/state social services agencies
models.macro_source: F1: Government benefits administration market: $8.4B (2025) to $14.2B (2030) at 11.1% CAGR. Medicaid: 80M enrollees, $800B+ annual spending. SNAP: 42M recipients, $113B (FY2024). F2: Social services case worker vacancy rates: 30-40% nationally (APHSA 2024). Average case worker manages 120+ cases (vs recommended 60). F5: Algorithmic bias in benefits determination is the MOST politically toxic government AI application — Michigan's unemployment fraud algorithm (MiDAS) wrongly accused 40,000+ citizens and generated $640M in false fraud claims.
models.sector_name: Administration of Human Resource Programs (Social Services)
models.deep_dive_evidence: Federal benefits programs distribute $1T+ annually to 100M+ Americans. Processing this volume requires 500K+ benefits case workers across 3,100+ county and state social services agencies. The case worker crisis is acute: APHSA (American Public Human Services Agency) reports 30-40% vacancy rates nationally. Average case worker manages 120-180 cases when the recommended caseload is 60. Burnout and turnover rates exceed 30% annually. Each benefits determination requires: (1) document collection (pay stubs, bank statements, ID, residency proof — average 15-30 documents per case), (2) eligibility verification against program rules (Medicaid: 200+ pages of state-specific rules), (3) cross-database checking (SSN verification, prior benefits, fraud flags), (4) determination writing, (5) appeal processing if denied. Current systems: state eligibility systems are a mix of legacy mainframes (25+ states still running COBOL-based systems) and modern systems (Deloitte/Accenture built). AI can: extract data from documents in seconds (vs 20-30 minutes manual), check eligibility against rules automatically, flag potential fraud or inconsistencies, and draft determinations for case worker review. The human-in-the-loop design is essential: Michigan's MiDAS automated system (no human review) wrongly accused 40,000+ citizens of unemployment fraud. Any AI system MUST augment the case worker, not replace them. Maximus ($5.2B) processes benefits for CMS and multiple states but uses labor-intensive call centers, not AI.

cla.rationale: Government benefits administration is served by large incumbents: Maximus ($5.2B, operates benefits call centers and eligibility processing), Deloitte (20+ state eligibility system implementations), Accenture Federal (HHS/CMS contracts), and IBM. These companies built the current generation of eligibility systems (often in COBOL, running on mainframes). MO is 4 because incumbents have deep relationships and multi-year contracts. However, the AI COPILOT layer is genuinely open: current systems are rule engines, not learning systems. An AI copilot that sits alongside the case worker — automatically extracting data from submitted documents, cross-referencing databases, flagging inconsistencies, and drafting eligibility determinations — augments without replacing the human decision-maker. This design pattern is critical: government benefits decisions MUST have human accountability, but the human can be 3-5x more productive with AI assistance. MA is 7 because benefits program rules are fiendishly complex (Medicaid alone has 50 state-specific rule sets) and training AI on these rules creates a deep moat. VD is 8 because improper payments cost $247B annually across all federal programs (GAO 2024) — reducing this by even 5% is worth $12B. DV is 9 because benefits caseloads are growing while case workers are quitting.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=ai_copilot, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $6.2B by 2030 (AI-specific benefits administration within $14.2B total government benefits admin market — document processing, eligibility AI, fraud detection, case management AI)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: State social services agencies: $200K-$2M ACV per state. County-level: $20-100K ACV per agency. Federal (CMS, SSA): FORTIFIED, only accessible via partnership with existing prime contractors. Most viable path: partner with existing state eligibility system vendors (add AI layer to Deloitte/Accenture implementations) or build standalone AI copilot that integrates with legacy systems via API. CMS is actively funding AI innovation through CMCS (Center for Medicaid and CHIP Services) grants.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Per-case-worker licensing: $200-$500/month per case worker. Per-case pricing: $2-5 per case processed (automated document extraction + eligibility check). State agency full platform: $20K-$200K/month. Gross margins 80%+. Revenue highly recurring: benefits are processed continuously, not project-based. Improper payment reduction creates measurable ROI: reducing improper payments by 2% in a medium state = $50-100M savings.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle: 12-24 months for state agencies (benefits modernization is multi-year procurement). Trigger events: CMS waiver approval, state legislature modernization mandate, IG audit finding on improper payments, case worker crisis (vacancy rate >40%). CMS funding announcements create procurement windows. APHSA IS conference is the primary distribution channel.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Benefits program rule engines (50 state-specific Medicaid rule sets, SNAP federal rules with state options, TANF state-specific requirements) are enormously complex to build and maintain. AI models trained on historical eligibility determinations (approved, denied, appealed, overturned) create accuracy that improves with volume. Integration with legacy state systems (interfaces, data formats, security requirements) creates per-state switching costs. Domain expertise hiring moat: engineers who understand both AI and benefits policy are extremely rare.

models.falsification_criteria: If a government AI benefits error creates a Michigan MiDAS-scale scandal that triggers legislation banning AI in benefits determination. If Maximus, Deloitte, or Accenture successfully builds AI capabilities within existing contracts, preventing new entrants. If case workers resist AI assistance due to fear of job loss or distrust of AI recommendations. If benefits program simplification (bipartisan proposals to simplify Medicaid, SNAP) reduces the complexity that makes AI valuable.

models.name: Grid-Scale Long-Duration Energy Storage
models.one_liner: Iron-air and flow battery systems for 100+ hour grid-scale energy storage — enabling renewable grid reliability beyond lithium-ion's 4-hour limit, addressing a $120B long-duration storage market need by 2040
models.macro_source: DOE Long-Duration Energy Storage (LDES) Earthshot target ($0.05/kWh by 2030); Form Energy iron-air battery development; LDES Council reports; IRA Section 48E investment tax credits for storage; CAISO duck curve data showing 10+ hour curtailment periods
models.deep_dive_evidence: Lithium-ion batteries dominate grid storage but are economically limited to 4-hour discharge — insufficient for multi-day renewable droughts (Dunkelflaute events). As renewable penetration exceeds 50% of grid capacity (California reached 100% instantaneous renewable generation in April 2024), long-duration energy storage (LDES) becomes structurally necessary for grid reliability. The DOE's LDES Earthshot targets $0.05/kWh for 100+ hour storage by 2030 (current lithium-ion is $0.15-0.25/kWh for 4 hours). Form Energy (raised $800M+, valued at $2B+) is building the first commercial iron-air battery facility in Weirton, WV — 750 MW manufacturing capacity with first deliveries expected 2025-2026. Iron-air promises 100+ hour duration at 1/10th the cost of lithium-ion per kWh stored, using abundant iron and water. Competitors: ESS Inc. ($ESS, iron flow batteries, struggling commercially — stock down 90%+ from SPAC), Ambri (liquid metal batteries, raised $200M+), EnerVenue (metal-hydrogen batteries, $368M raised). The LDES Council estimates 85-140 TWh of LDES needed globally by 2040, representing a $1.5-3T cumulative investment. IRA Section 48E provides 30-50% investment tax credits for standalone storage. The challenge is extreme: first-of-kind manufacturing risk, 10-20 year project lifetimes for utility contracts, and massive capital requirements ($500M+ to build a single Gigafactory). This is definitionally not venture-scalable — it requires growth equity, project finance, and DOE loan guarantees. Round-trip efficiency of 45-55% for iron-air (vs. 85-95% for lithium-ion) is a real technical limitation that increases effective storage cost.

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=hardware_ai, NAICS=22, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=hardware_ai, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

Incumbent firms in Utilities successfully deploy equivalent AI internally

models.name: Intelligent Property Services Marketplace & Operations Platform
models.one_liner: Unified platform connecting commercial properties with AI-matched, quality-verified janitorial, landscaping, HVAC, and maintenance service providers — targeting $100B+ US building services market
models.macro_source: Grand View Research: US janitorial services $76.7B in 2024 growing to $100.2B by 2033. US landscaping services market $130B+ (IBISWorld). Total NAICS 5617 revenue exceeds $230B across janitorial, landscaping, pest control, HVAC, and maintenance. 2.2M workers. Industry fragmentation extreme: 300K+ establishments at average 7 workers per firm. 100%+ annual turnover in janitorial. Property managers (CBRE, JLL) manage $30T+ in commercial real estate — they are the buyer.

cla.rationale: Market openness high — building services is extremely fragmented with no dominant technology platform. ServiceChannel (acquired by Brookfield for ~$1.5B) is the closest competitor but focuses on reactive work order management, not AI-matched provider discovery and quality optimization. Moat advantage moderate: marketplace effects compound (more properties = more providers = better matching = more properties) but providers multi-home across platforms. Value density high: commercial property building services spend $5-15/sqft annually — a 1M sqft portfolio = $5-15M annual services spend flowing through the platform at 5-10% take rate. Demand visibility strong: every commercial building needs these services, property managers are actively consolidating vendor management.

models.deep_dive_evidence: NAICS 5617 (Services to Buildings & Dwellings) is the largest sub-sector of NAICS 56 with 2.2M workers and estimated $230B+ in combined revenue across janitorial ($76.7B growing to $100.2B by 2033, Grand View Research), landscaping ($130B+, IBISWorld), pest control ($23B), and building maintenance services. The industry is extraordinarily fragmented: 300K+ establishments averaging 7 workers per firm. This fragmentation creates a massive coordination problem: a commercial property manager overseeing 50 buildings in 10 cities might work with 200+ individual service providers for cleaning, landscaping, HVAC, pest control, electrical, plumbing, and snow removal. ServiceChannel (acquired by Brookfield for approximately $1.5B) provides work order management for multi-site commercial properties, proving the platform thesis. But ServiceChannel is reactive (submit work order, route to provider) rather than proactive (AI predicts maintenance needs, matches optimal provider, verifies quality). The opportunity is a multi-service platform that: (1) AI-matches properties with pre-vetted service providers based on quality scores, pricing, availability, and specialization. (2) Provides quality verification through IoT sensors and post-service inspection (before/after photo AI, sensor data confirming cleaning completion). (3) Enables dynamic pricing and on-demand booking for variable services (snow removal, emergency repairs). (4) Aggregates small providers' volume for insurance, equipment purchasing, and training. The 100%+ annual turnover rate in janitorial creates chronic provider reliability problems — AI quality scoring and backup provider matching solves this. Property managers (CBRE, JLL, Cushman & Wakefield) collectively manage $30T+ in commercial real estate and are the key buyer persona. They want consolidated vendor management, quality assurance, and cost optimization across their entire portfolio.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Gig economy regulation (AB5-like laws) disrupts staffing platform economics
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $230B+ US building services market (janitorial + landscaping + pest control + maintenance). Platform take rate of 3-7% = $7-16B platform revenue TAM. Software/SaaS TAM (work order management, quality verification, provider matching): $3-5B by 2030.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible as the 'vertical marketplace for building services.' Start in one metro with one service category (commercial janitorial in NYC or SF), prove quality matching model, then expand geographically and across service categories. PE firms doing building services rollups are potential channel partners and acquirers. Capital requirements $10-20M for marketplace development and initial metro launch.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Marketplace take rate: 5-8% of service value. Average commercial property spends $200K-2M/year on building services. 100 properties at 5% take rate on $500K avg spend = $2.5M ARR. SaaS layer: $500-5,000/property/month for quality management and analytics. Gross margins: 25-35% on marketplace revenue, 80%+ on SaaS. Break-even at 200-500 managed properties.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: ServiceChannel $1.5B exit validates category. Property management technology spending increasing 10-15% annually. CBRE/JLL actively digitizing vendor management. COVID created permanent demand for cleaning quality verification. Commercial property insurance increasingly requiring documented maintenance programs. Labor shortage forces provider quality monitoring (bad providers harder to replace).
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Network effects: more properties on platform attracts more providers, better matching, more properties. Quality score data compounds (provider performance across hundreds of jobs creates reliable quality signal). Multi-category integration creates one-stop switching cost (property managers don't want 5 different platforms for 5 service categories). Geographic density matters: having 50+ vetted providers in a metro area is a defensible advantage. Property management group relationships (CBRE, JLL) provide winner-take-most dynamics within portfolios.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform, buyer=multi, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $30000000M

models.name: Live Event Production & Venue Operations AI
models.one_liner: AI copilot for live event production — automated scheduling, vendor coordination, safety compliance, and real-time operations management for the 4,600+ US entertainment venues
models.macro_source: QCEW NAICS 711310 (124K workers, 4.6K establishments, $48.8K avg pay, +14.3% emp growth); MarketsandMarkets event management software ($18.3B to $66B by 2033); OSHA live event safety requirements; NFPA crowd management standards
models.sector_name: Promoters of Performing Arts, Sports with Facilities
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 711310 (Promoters with Facilities) has 4,615 establishments employing 124,096 workers at $939/week ($48,830 annual), with an explosive 14.3% employment growth YoY — the second-fastest in NAICS 71. These are the venues: concert halls, arenas, amphitheaters, performing arts centers, and event spaces. Average of 26.9 workers per establishment, ranging from 50-person clubs to 20,000-seat arenas. The production operations challenge is acute: each live event requires coordination of 20-50+ vendors (sound, lighting, staging, security, catering, ticketing), complex scheduling with setup/teardown windows, labor union compliance (IATSE), safety protocols (crowd management, fire safety, emergency evacuation), and real-time operations management during shows. Event management software market growing from $18.3B to $66B by 2033 at 17.4% CAGR. The AI copilot opportunity: (1) Automated production scheduling — AI coordinates setup timelines, vendor availability, and union crew rotations, reducing a 3-day manual scheduling process to hours. (2) Safety and compliance — real-time crowd density monitoring via computer vision, automated fire marshal capacity tracking, incident management workflows. (3) Vendor and labor management — AI handles crew scheduling across IATSE/IBEW union rules, processes rider requirements for touring artists, and optimizes vendor selection based on past performance data. (4) Energy management — large venues consume 20-50 GWh annually; AI-optimized HVAC, lighting, and load management can reduce energy costs 15-25%. The challenge: venue operations teams are conservative, union relationships are complex, and safety cannot be compromised.

cla.rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): existing venue management platforms (Ungerboeck/Momentus, VenueOps, Prism) are legacy systems with minimal AI capability. The 4,600+ venue establishments represent a concentrated but accessible buyer base. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): production scheduling data and vendor performance records create switching costs, but the core scheduling/coordination capability is not deeply technical. Safety compliance features add defensibility. Value Density is strong (7): venue operators manage $2-50M in annual event revenue — a 3-5% efficiency improvement from AI operations management is $60K-2.5M, justifying $2-10K/month. Demand Visibility is strong (7): venue operators universally cite operational complexity as their top challenge — the pain is real and measurable.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=ai_copilot, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $66B (event management software by 2033, total). Venue operations specifically: ~$3-5B. AI-powered venue operations intelligence: ~$1-2B.
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: Momentus (formerly Ungerboeck, venue management, ~2,500 clients). VenueOps (event venue management). Prism (performing arts venue management). ABI (arena/stadium management). All are legacy platforms with minimal AI integration.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS: 75-80% gross margins. $2,000-8,000/month per venue depending on size. Average ARPU: $4,000/month. LTV: $96,000 (24-month retention). CAC: $8,000-15,000 (enterprise sales to venue operations directors). LTV:CAC of 6.4-12x.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: 100-125 venues at $4,000/month average. Target: mid-size concert venues and performing arts centers (1,000-10,000 capacity) not controlled by Live Nation or AEG. Timeline: 18-24 months.

falsification_criteria: Event management platforms (Ungerboeck, Momentus, VenueOps) build sufficient AI features that eliminate standalone AI copilot demand
Live Nation's venue operations technology extends to non-LN venues via licensing, capturing the market
Union resistance to AI-powered crew scheduling blocks adoption — IATSE views AI scheduling as threat to member work hours

models.name: Knowledge Worker Wage Insurance Platform
models.one_liner: Income protection and career-hedging platform for knowledge workers facing AI-driven wage deflation -- the other side of Inverse Baumol where 8M+ professionals need wage floor guarantees and AI-skill acquisition pathways
models.macro_source: The Inverse Baumol discovery (P-040) has a worker-facing side: 8M+ US knowledge workers in accounting, legal, financial analysis, and consulting face structural wage deflation. These workers need three things: (1) income smoothing during transition (wage insurance), (2) AI skill acquisition to earn the 56% wage premium documented by PwC, and (3) career pivoting guidance into roles where human judgment premiums persist. Fear friction (F5) is extreme -- these are educated professionals whose identity is tied to expertise that is being commoditized. Data compounding moat: each worker's career trajectory data improves the platform's ability to predict which skills will retain value and which will deflate further.
models.deep_dive_evidence: PwC AI Jobs Barometer: 56% wage premium for AI-skilled workers vs non-AI-skilled in same roles. This premium represents the value of the hedge. Entry-level knowledge work postings down 35% (Revelio Labs). Accounting wage growth decelerated 56% (engine P-040). Finance and accounting talent market 'showing real cracks' (Robert Half). The insurance product: workers pay $50-150/month for wage floor guarantees (if their salary drops >15%, the platform pays the difference for 12 months) funded by the premium pool. Bundled with AI upskilling courses (the prevention side of insurance). Underwriting uses occupational AI-exposure scores (O*NET-based, similar to engine's Polanyi analysis). Revenue model: insurance premiums + upskilling course fees + B2B partnerships (employers subsidize for retention). Actuarial basis: knowledge worker wage deflation is predictable sector-by-sector using AI adoption curves.

cla.rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=data_compounding, NAICS=52, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment

models.name: Electronics Distribution Dynamic Pricing & Demand Sensing
models.one_liner: AI-powered demand sensing and dynamic pricing platform for electronics distribution — predicting component shortages, optimizing allocation, and automating quoting across $200B market with 60-day lead time cycles
models.macro_source: F1: AI demand sensing reducing forecast error 30-50% in electronics supply chains (Gartner 2025 Supply Chain). F3: Semiconductor supply chain reshoring (CHIPS Act $52B) and China export controls creating structural supply volatility. F4: Electronics distributor margins compress to 5-8% gross — pricing accuracy is survival.
models.sector_name: Electrical and Electronic Goods Merchant Wholesalers
models.deep_dive_evidence: US electronics distribution is a $200B+ market dominated by large players: Arrow Electronics ($33B revenue), Avnet ($24B), TD SYNNEX ($58B, broader IT distribution), Ingram Micro ($47B), and Mouser/Digi-Key (high-mix catalog distributors). The semiconductor shortage of 2021-2023 exposed critical weaknesses in electronics distribution: (1) demand forecasting relied on customer-provided forecasts that were 40-60% inaccurate (double-ordering, phantom demand), (2) allocation decisions were manual and relationship-based rather than data-driven, (3) pricing was static in a market where spot prices moved 10-50% in weeks. The structural challenge: electronics components have 60-90 day manufacturer lead times, 18-24 month product lifecycles, and 50K+ active SKUs per major distributor. This creates a massive AI optimization surface. Demand sensing using end-market signals (auto production forecasts, smartphone shipment data, data center capex announcements, defense procurement schedules) can predict component demand 2-3 quarters ahead with 30-50% better accuracy than traditional methods. Dynamic pricing (adjusting quotes in real-time based on supply/demand balance, inventory position, and customer lifetime value) can improve gross margins 50-100bps — on $200B in revenue at 5-8% gross margin, this is $1-2B in value creation. Octopart (Altium subsidiary, component search engine) and Findchips proved component pricing transparency has demand, but neither offers predictive intelligence.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate-low — Arrow, Avnet, and TD SYNNEX have sophisticated internal systems and large IT budgets. The opportunity is in the next tier: 5K+ smaller electronics distributors and the 200K+ OEMs/EMS providers that buy through distribution. Moat advantage is strong: demand sensing models trained on cross-distributor transaction data create network-effect intelligence. Value chain depth spans pricing, allocation, quoting, and demand forecasting. Demand visibility is moderate — volatile electronics supply chains create urgency but enterprise sales cycles are long.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5B (electronics supply chain intelligence and optimization, including pricing, demand sensing, and inventory management)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: concentrated at the top — Arrow, Avnet, SYNNEX have internal tools. Mid-market gap: Octopart (component search, Altium), SiliconExpert (component lifecycle data, Arrow subsidiary), IHS Markit (now S&P Global, component data). None offer AI-native demand sensing for distributors.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $50K-$250K for mid-market distributors. $500K-$2M for tier-1 distributors. Demand sensing module: $5K-20K/month. Dynamic pricing: $3K-10K/month. Gross margins 80%+. Enterprise sales cycle 6-12 months. Land with pricing analytics, expand to demand sensing.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Target 50 mid-market electronics distributors ($50M-$500M revenue) at $100K ACV = $5M ARR. Wedge: component shortage prediction (still relevant post-2021 crisis — lead times remain 8-12 weeks for many categories). ECIA (Electronic Components Industry Association) events for distribution.

falsification_criteria: If Arrow/Avnet build proprietary AI demand sensing platforms that are superior (Arrow already investing in digital transformation)
If semiconductor supply chain stabilizes post-CHIPS Act, reducing volatility that drives demand for predictive tools
If electronics distribution further consolidates (Arrow+Avnet merger speculation), reducing the addressable mid-market

models.name: Building Materials Distribution Operations Suite
models.one_liner: AI-native ERP for the 50K+ independent building materials yards — demand forecasting on volatile lumber/concrete pricing, delivery scheduling, and contractor credit scoring in a $150B market
models.macro_source: F1: AI demand forecasting reducing inventory carrying costs 15-20% in volatile commodity markets. F2: Building materials yards face acute Silver Tsunami — NAW estimates 70% of independent yard owners are 55+. F3: Lumber tariff volatility (2-3x price swings since 2020) and Canadian softwood lumber duties (14.5% anti-dumping) create urgent pricing intelligence need.
models.sector_name: Lumber and Other Construction Materials Merchant Wholesalers
models.deep_dive_evidence: US building materials distribution is a $150B+ market with extreme fragmentation: 50K+ independent lumberyards, building supply dealers, and concrete/aggregate distributors. Key players: ABC Supply ($22B, roofing/siding focused), SRS Distribution ($10B+, acquired by Home Depot for $18.25B in June 2024 — validating rollup model at massive scale), BMC Stock Holdings (merged with Meritage to form US LBM, $10B+), 84 Lumber ($7B, family-owned). But the vast majority of the market is served by single-location or 2-5 location independent yards doing $3-20M revenue. Technology adoption is among the lowest in all of wholesale trade — many yards still use paper-based inventory, manual pricing based on owner knowledge, and phone/fax ordering. Lumber pricing volatility is extreme: Random Lengths Framing Lumber Composite has ranged from $350 to $1,700/MBF since 2020. This volatility makes demand forecasting and pricing intelligence critical — a $10M yard that mis-times a lumber purchase by 2 weeks can lose $200K+. AI-driven demand forecasting using housing starts data, permit applications, weather patterns, and commodity futures can reduce inventory risk 30-40%. Contractor credit scoring (construction contractors are notoriously slow to pay, DSO 45-60 days) using AI models trained on payment history, project pipeline, and financial signals can reduce bad debt expense from 1.5% to 0.5% of revenue.

cla.rationale: Market is wide open — 50K+ independent yards with minimal technology. No dominant vertical SaaS player. Epicor BisTrack and Agility ERP are legacy, not AI-native. Moat advantage is moderate: commodity pricing models and contractor credit data create switching costs but are not defensible moats alone. Value chain depth includes ERP, pricing intelligence, credit scoring, delivery scheduling, and supplier management. Demand visibility is high — every yard owner faces lumber volatility and contractor credit risk daily.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.5B (building materials distribution technology, including ERP, pricing, logistics — growing 12% CAGR)
vcr_evidence.competitive_landscape: fragmented legacy — Epicor BisTrack (dominant legacy ERP for lumberyards), Agility ERP, DMSi Software. None are AI-native. No modern SaaS challenger has emerged.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $15K-$60K per yard. Base ERP replacement: $1K-2K/month. Pricing intelligence module: $500-$1K/month. Credit scoring: $300-$500/month. Gross margins 80%+. Implementation services: $5-15K per yard (30-60 day deployment). CAC via dealer co-ops, LBM Advantage, Do it Best buying groups.
vcr_evidence.path_to_5m_arr: Start with lumber pricing intelligence module (lowest friction, highest urgency). 300 yards at $1.5K/month = $5.4M ARR. Expand to full ERP replacement over 12-18 months. Buying group partnerships (LBM Advantage: 3,100+ locations) provide distribution channel.

falsification_criteria: If Home Depot/Lowe's expand into B2B building materials distribution at scale (Home Depot Pro already growing), commoditizing the independent yard value proposition
If lumber price volatility normalizes (sustained $400-600/MBF range), reducing the urgency for AI pricing tools
If independent yard owners prove resistant to technology adoption even as Silver Tsunami forces sales — acquirers may just rip-and-replace systems rather than modernize

models.name: Intelligent Court Case Management & Justice Analytics
models.one_liner: Cloud-native case management platform with AI scheduling optimization, legal research automation, and access-to-justice tools for 17,000+ US courts processing 80M+ case filings annually — targeting the $8.2B court management software market
models.macro_source: F1: US courts process 80M+ case filings annually (state + federal). Court management software market: $5.6B (2025) to $8.2B (2030) at 7.9% CAGR. F2: 30% of state court judges eligible for retirement by 2028. F5: Strong resistance to AI in sentencing/bail decisions — COMPAS recidivism algorithm controversy (ProPublica 2016) still shapes judicial attitudes. Access to justice crisis: 92% of legal problems by low-income Americans receive inadequate legal help (LSC 2022).
models.deep_dive_evidence: The US court system: 94 federal district courts, 50 state systems, 17,000+ individual courts. 80M+ case filings annually (NCSC 2024). State courts handle 98% of all cases. Median time to disposition: 12 months for felony, 6 months for civil, 4 months for traffic/minor. Court case backlog grew 25-30% during COVID and has not fully recovered. Self-represented litigants: 60-75% in family law, 90%+ in housing/eviction, 95%+ in small claims. These litigants navigate complex procedures without help. Tyler Technologies Odyssey is the dominant CMS with ~2,500 court installations, but it is architecturally dated (Silverlight-era UI, on-premise deployment). Thomson Reuters C-Track and Journal Technologies eCourt serve hundreds more. The AI opportunity splits into three lanes: (1) BACK-OFFICE: AI scheduling that reduces continuances 25-40% (MIT study showed optimal scheduling saves 1.5 hours per courtroom per day), automated minute orders, transcript generation. (2) JUDGE COPILOT: legal research AI, sentencing guideline analysis, case law summarization (controversial — judges resist perceived erosion of judicial discretion). (3) ACCESS-TO-JUSTICE: citizen-facing AI that helps self-represented litigants understand procedures, fill forms, prepare for hearings. This last category has the least resistance and greatest unmet need.

cla.rationale: Court technology is dominated by legacy incumbents: Tyler Technologies (Odyssey CMS, largest install base), Thomson Reuters (C-Track), and Journal Technologies (eCourt). These systems were built in the 2000s with on-premise architectures. MO is 6 because courts are extremely conservative buyers and vendor transitions are rare (5-10 year replacement cycles, massive data migration risk). However, the ACCESS-TO-JUSTICE layer is genuinely open: self-represented litigants (60%+ of family court, 90%+ of housing court) need AI-powered navigation tools that incumbents do not provide. Legal aid chatbots, automated form filling, court date scheduling, and case status tracking for citizens represent a greenfield adjacent to case management. VD is moderate because court budgets are small ($50B total US judicial spending) but the access-to-justice market unlocks LSC, DOJ, and foundation funding streams.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.8B by 2030 (AI-specific court technology within $8.2B total court management market, plus $1.5B access-to-justice tools funded by LSC/DOJ/foundations)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: The CMS replacement opportunity requires 5-10 year sales cycles and is only viable for well-funded companies. The access-to-justice layer is more accessible: funded by LSC ($600M+), DOJ Access to Justice initiative, state bar foundations, and philanthropic orgs. Can build a sustainable business on $20-50K/year per court for AI tools without displacing Tyler CMS. 500 courts at $30K = $15M ARR baseline.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: CMS replacement: $200K-$2M implementation + $50K-$200K/year maintenance (high-touch, long-cycle). Access-to-justice tools: $10K-$50K/year per court. Citizen-facing: potentially freemium (funded by courts or legal aid orgs). Gross margins 70-80%. Government procurement applies.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: CMS sales cycle: 2-5 years (courts are the slowest government buyers). Access-to-justice tools: 6-12 months (funded by grants with faster disbursement). Trigger events: new chief justice, court modernization initiative, post-COVID backlog pressure, consent decree. NCSC provides centralized advocacy for court technology adoption.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Court-specific AI models (case law analysis, scheduling optimization, outcome prediction) require training on case data that is difficult to obtain at scale. Multi-jurisdictional knowledge (each state has unique procedures, forms, rules) creates scope complexity that discourages generic entrants. Integration with existing CMS creates switching cost.

models.falsification_criteria: If Tyler Technologies successfully modernizes Odyssey with AI features, preventing challengers from displacing the installed base. If judicial resistance to AI intensifies (courts formally ban AI-assisted legal filings, as some have after GPT hallucination incidents). If court funding continues to decline, eliminating budget for technology investments. If the access-to-justice AI tools produce incorrect legal guidance, creating liability concerns that halt deployment.

CMS-0057-F mandates electronic PA by 2027. AI PA automation can reduce processing time from days to hours. Approval prediction enables targeted clinical documentation improvement. Appeal generation AI recovers abandoned revenue. The CMS mandate is the forcing function -- compliance deadline is binary.
models.macro_source: Prior authorization is the single most hated administrative process in healthcare. Average PA takes 14 days. 34% of denied claims are abandoned (revenue permanently lost). AMA estimates $31B+ annual cost of PA activities. AI can: (1) extract relevant clinical data from EHR, (2) match against payer-specific PA rules, (3) pre-populate PA forms, (4) predict approval probability, (5) generate appeal documentation for denials. The unique timing: CMS mandate creates a cliff event where ALL payers must accept electronic PA by 2027.

models.name: Construction Insurance & Risk Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered construction insurance platform using jobsite data, safety records, and project analytics to price risk dynamically -- targeting the $45B US construction insurance market (workers comp, general liability, builder's risk, surety) where incumbents still rely on manual underwriting
models.macro_source: F1: AI underwriting using real-time jobsite data vs historical loss ratios. F4: Construction insurance premiums rising 10-20% annually due to social inflation and nuclear verdicts. US construction insurance market ~$45B. Insurtech market broadly: $152B by 2030 (Grand View Research).

cla.rationale: Construction insurance is dominated by large carriers (Zurich, Liberty Mutual, Travelers, CNA, Hartford) and specialty brokers (Aon, Marsh). The market is 'structurally stupid': premiums are based on payroll, revenue, and historical EMR -- not real-time jobsite safety data. No major carrier has built a data-driven, dynamic pricing model for construction risk. Startups: Shepherd (construction-focused MGA, $27M raised), Pie Insurance (small commercial, including construction), Cowbell (cyber but model applicable). Market openness is moderate: insurance is heavily regulated and requires carrier partnerships or MGA licenses. But the VALUE PROPOSITION is enormous: contractors spend 3-8% of revenue on insurance, and a platform that reduces claims by 20-30% through better risk selection and loss control creates shared savings for carriers and policyholders. Value density is very high: average construction policy premium is $15-50K per firm.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US construction insurance market estimated at $45B across four major lines: (1) Workers compensation: ~$15B (construction is the #1 WC market by premium). (2) General liability: ~$12B. (3) Builder's risk: ~$8B. (4) Surety bonds: ~$10B. Premiums have risen 10-20% annually since 2022 due to social inflation (nuclear verdicts in construction defect litigation), rising material costs (replacement cost inflation), and increased weather events (climate-driven property damage). Current underwriting is archaic: based on payroll volume, trade classification, and 3-year EMR history. No real-time data integration. Construction fatalities: 1,056 in 2023, OSHA penalties up to $161K per willful violation. Shepherd (construction MGA, $27M raised) is building a data-driven underwriting platform. The opportunity is to integrate AI safety monitoring data (from MC-V312-CON-003) with underwriting: contractors who deploy safety AI get dynamically lower premiums. This creates a FLYWHEEL: safety technology adoption reduces losses, which reduces premiums, which incentivizes more safety technology adoption. The insurance distribution chain (broker to carrier to reinsurer) is ripe for disintermediation through digital MGAs.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $45B (US construction insurance premiums; AI-enhanced underwriting/distribution captures 5-10% = $2.25-$4.5B serviceable market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: MGA model: underwrite and distribute construction insurance using AI risk assessment. Path to $200M GWP (gross written premium) in 5 years by writing 10K policies at $20K average premium. Take 25-30% as MGA commission = $50-60M revenue. Requires carrier capacity partnerships.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: MGA commission: 25-30% of premium. Average construction policy: $15-50K. Loss ratio target: <60% (vs industry 65-70%). Revenue per policy: $5-15K. CAC: $2-5K per policy (broker channel). Capital requirement: $5-10M for MGA setup + reinsurance capacity.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Annual policy renewal cycle creates natural sales cadence. Premium increases drive shopping behavior. Safety AI integration creates measurable loss reduction. Broker partnerships provide distribution leverage.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Proprietary loss data from insured projects (creates better risk models over time). Integration with safety monitoring platforms. Actuarial models specific to construction sub-trades. Broker relationships and contractor trust. Regulatory licensing barriers protect from casual entry.

models.name: Longevity Biomarker Analytics Platform
models.one_liner: Multi-omic aging clock platform for pharmaceutical clinical trials and employer wellness programs — providing biological age measurement, intervention response tracking, and aging trajectory analytics using epigenetic, proteomic, and metabolomic biomarkers
models.macro_source: Horvath epigenetic clock publications; TruDiagnostic GrimAge 2.0 commercialization; Altos Labs ($3B funding), Calico Labs, Unity Biotechnology longevity R&D; longevity supplement market $64B by 2028 (Grand View Research); NIH NHLBI aging biomarker initiatives
models.deep_dive_evidence: The longevity biomarker market is emerging from academia into commercial application. Epigenetic clocks (Horvath, GrimAge, DunedinPACE) can measure biological age with +-2 year accuracy, and more importantly, can detect intervention effects within 6-12 months — far faster than waiting for mortality endpoints. This makes aging clocks potentially transformative for clinical trials: a longevity drug trial that would take 10-15 years using mortality endpoints could show biological age reversal in 1-2 years. Pharma companies investing in aging (Altos Labs $3B, Calico/Alphabet, Unity Biotechnology, BioAge Labs) need validated aging biomarkers for trial design and regulatory submissions. The FDA's TAME trial (Targeting Aging with Metformin) is establishing the precedent for aging-as-indication. TruDiagnostic (raised $15M) offers consumer epigenetic testing at $350/test, with 50,000+ samples generating a proprietary aging database. Elysium Health sells consumer aging tests. But the B2B opportunity — providing aging clock analytics as a clinical trial endpoint for pharma — is larger and stickier. The data moat compounds: each sample adds to a multi-omic dataset (epigenetic + proteomic + metabolomic) that improves clock accuracy and enables stratified analysis (how does drug X affect aging in men vs. women, diabetics vs. healthy, etc.). Market sizing: 200+ longevity-related clinical trials currently active (ClinicalTrials.gov), with aging biomarker services at $50-500K per trial, plus employer wellness ($20-100 per employee for annual biological age testing). The challenge: regulatory uncertainty (FDA has not validated any aging clock as a clinical endpoint) and scientific debate about which clock best predicts healthspan.
